reviews.review_text: Updated 10/29 for the PC re-release that happened on 10/28:  Many of the worst issues in the original release of this game have been resolved, but if it came out as-is today I would still say the port is pretty disappointing. Many people who couldn't play the game at all before can get a playable framerate now, but even on a very high end system the frame pacing is very poor and results in a stuttery experience.   The texture loading issues that plagued the game on release are gone, but you still see shockingly low resolution textures during almost any cut scene.  Image quality is all over the board, but is improved quite a bit by turning off AA, CA, and film grain effects.   Speaking of effects, there seems to be a bug that scales the intensity of post-processing effects with the screen resolution the game renders at. The most obviously visible occurance of this bug is when lens flares are rendered. In 1080p, lens flares look more or less as they should. At 1440p you'd think Batman just had LASIK surgery because looking at a street light produces a double or triple lens flare corona that makes it very difficult to see what is going on. Considering the whole game takes place at night and there are more lens flares than a JJ Abrams movie this bug can get pretty irritating.  If you're a huge batman fan and you've been waiting to play this game, I'd say it is definitely playable now. If you're on the fence and were waiting to see whether they had turned a legendarily bad release into a good one for rerelease, I'd say wait until it is heavily discounted.  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Original review of initial release version:   One of the worst PC ports of all time.  This game had some incredibly misleading advertising. In the Nvidia gamework promo reel, posted to youtube by Nvidia on June 6 (only a few weeks before the game was released), they show ambient occlusion and rain textures - both of which are present in the console versions, and entirely absent from the PC version. The same gameworks promo trailer is also a full 60fps, but the game ships with a 30fps cap. By editing an .ini file you can remove the 30fps cap, but many have reported that causes other graphical issues such as textures only loading the very lowest detail level (they look pretty similar to the textures from a Nintendo 64 game).  Aside from the false advertising, this game can't even maintain a consistent framerate on hardware that FAR exceeds the recommended specifications. For example, despite having the game installed on an SSD, and running a 980ti with the latest drivers, I still get dips into single digit framerates in many situations. For example, any time I get in the batmobile, I am watching a slide show for a few seconds.  Save your money and wait to buy this game until it is fixed (if it ever does get fixed).
If you see a PC port from WB...    WARN A BROTHER.
My powerpoint presentation gets frames faster than this game.

Months ago this game was bashed by every PC user for the horrible launch. Since then I've watched and read dozens of reviews of both PC and PS versions and it was still getting mixed bad opinions. Therefore I had low expectations when I bought it a few days ago, only expecting the tech issues to be fixed.  Now that I've finished the game I can safely say it was a great and very enjoyable experience. I won't spoil anything here, not a big fan of the ending but it was a great story. All the little touches and details you would expect from the previous games are here as well. Never had a stutter or crash and I'm on a slightly above average PC.  Won't go in detail, just want to say this - if you were put off by the fail-launch and negative reviews since then, give this game a chance. I love the previous ones in the series, but this is the first one I almost completed at 100% (only riddler trophies remain and they are really a grind). And the top point of many reviewers that the CAR is shoved on you and takes away - I was afraid of that, but no, really no, it adds and takes sometimes but it's not in any way obtrusive.  If in doubt - buy on sale!

When I played Arkham Origins, I thought it was a fine game with some notable flaws that made it inferior to Arkham City, but all would be made right with the release of Arkham Knight. But that's not exactly what happened -- instead, I think Arkham Knight is a fine game with some notable flaws that make it inferior to Arkham City.  Let's tackle the first elephant in the room: the botched port and initial release. It stank up Steam so bad that it single-handedly  kickstarted  popularized the refund policy ( thanks to Link XL1 for pointing out refunds actually started a bit earlier than AK ), and it was the reason I held off on actually buying it until a good long while had passed, despite being a massive fan of the series. I can be brief about this: my brand new rig has 16 GB of memory and a GTX 1070, and the game runs at a near-constant 70 FPS at 1440p maxed settings while looking absolutely gorgeous. Now, I get that not everyone has had that experience, or will have that experience, but I can only judge the game on how it plays for me at this point in time, and I have no reason to complain. That's not to say I tihnk that putting out a release as broken as this one is in any way acceptable or excusable -- it's not -- but I'm not going to count it against the game in its current state.  The same can't be said for elephant number two, which is the Batmobile. The Dynamic Duo in this game isn't Batman and Robin, but Batman and his amazing rooftop-hopping car. It quickly veers from cool into silly and contrived, and about the only thing missing is the Batmobile doing inverted takedowns (it  does  hang upside down a few times, so that's not as implausible as it sounds...). They made sure you can't miss out on the experience by putting in vehicular combat and puzzles that require the Batmobile, but I found myself more frustrated than entertained by these sections. Despite what the game designers thought, it would have been completely fine if the Batmobile had just been there as a cooler way of getting you from A to B. Throw in the optional racetracks for the people who like that sort of thing, I'm fine with that. Have maybe  one  sequence where the Batmobile gets to slug it out with a tank or helicopter, sure. But repeated vehicular combat sequences and painfully forced puzzle sequences just detract from the experience. While you can avoid almost all racing and puzzles if you just don't go after the Riddler (as if!) the tank battles are there to stay. It's as if someone baked you a delicious, velvety smooth chocolate cake, except that they mixed in crunchy peanuts to chip your teeth on, because they read somewhere that chocolate and peanuts go well together.  There are a lot of things Arkham Knight gets right, too. The meat and potatoes of the game, combat and predator encounters, work as smooth as ever, and there are the requisite tweaks and new moves to keep things interesting without completely unbalancing things like the shock gloves in Origins did. There's a smorgasbord of villains on the loose in Gotham waiting for you to arrest them, and they all involve different gameplay, so you can easily mix things up without getting bored. The voice acting is top notch, both from the regulars and the guest villains (special tip of the hat to Dwight Schultz, who plays a terrifying Professor Pyg -- I was surprised to find out it was him when I looked it up). The story is engaging, and I'm happy to say that's still the case even if you had the identity of the Arkham Knight spoiled before you picked up the game, like I did. I especially like the way the writers justified the issue of Batman suddenly deciding to stick massive guns on his Batmobile (even if they do conveniently fire 'non-lethal rounds' when targeting humans). If this sounds a bit out of character for Batman, it's because it is... and you'll find out why as you play the game. Having said that, I'm definitely not a fan of the ending (the true ending you get with 100% completion), which is deliberately ambiguous on the ultimate fate of Batman and Gotham. It's not terrible, I can live with it, but it still feels like a cop-out and something the writers could absolutely have avoided in favor of a stronger statement. As a cap to the whole series, it's a bit underwhelming.  Arkham Knight gets an easy 'recommended' from me, but it's not as great as the final installment could have been.

I love this game. It's far from perfect, but it's a great game nonetheless. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it, especially to fans of the previous games.  Pros: -You are the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batman -You get to drive the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batmobile -You can hang people upside down from gargoyles -Good story with a wide cast of villains -Great ending to the series -Amazing voice acting, as always -Lots of references that comic book fans will appreciate -The game looks fantastic, even on the lowest settings -Gotham itself is extremely detailed -Way less Riddler stuff than in Arkham City (City had 440, this only has 243) -Tons of extra content, including side missions, collectibles, challenge maps, and New Game Plus  Cons: -Many people still experience serious performance issues -Combat is a bit of a step back from Arkham City -Batmobile is heavily overused in gameplay -Only a couple of real boss fights, and they aren't very creative or interesting -All Riddler collectibles/challenges are required to get the full ending  While it isn't as good as Arkham City, and there's more Batmobile than I would have liked, it's still a fantastic game and I would definitely recommend getting it if you enjoyed the previous games.  As for performance, I was able to run the game at the lowest setting at 1360x768 and get a consistent 60fps. I didn't encounter any issues aside from the occasional lag spike, but as far as I can tell many people still have problems running the game. For reference, here are my specs:  Intel Core i7-4770 (3.4GHz) Nvidia GeForce GTX 760 Ti 8GB RAM Windows 10

You may notice at the top of the page that the Overall Reviews are Mixed but the recent reviews are Overwhelminhly Positive. At first, I thought this was a joke the internet was playing, like how the Cory in the House DS game has a 9.5 user score on Metacritic, but then I read some of the reviews and some forum posts and saw that people are saying the game is playable now. So, I picked this game up cheap (the game's reputation has lowered its price on third party stores) and I played it. Let me tell you, it was definitely worth it.   Is the game playable? Yes. Is it well optimized now? Oh God no. There was a lot of stuttering when I first loaded up the game, or when I go to new areas in the open world. But, I'm a patient man so I was able to deal with it. It should be noted that I have a 4 year old card so some of the higher end GPUs will probably have better performances. Other than that, the only other bugs I encountered were small texture bugs. I never experienced any game breaking bugs.   Now on to the actual game. How is it? Well, my recommendation should tell you that I very much enjoyed the game. I think it's the best in the series (which is not an opinion shared by many). I felt the story was extremely well done. I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that the other Arkham games were really focused on the plot and the supervillians that Batman goes up against, but this game really explores Batman himself as a character. Again, some people were a bit disappointed by the story, especially with the reveal of the Arkham Knight, but I was fine with it. I was never a die-hard Batman comic book fan so I don't share the same point of view as those people.   The gameplay is where the game really shines. I loved everything about it. Even the Batmobile. I had a lot of fun driving around Gotham. At first, the driving controls felt really wonky, but once I got used to it, it felt really great. Now the tank mode. A lot of people hated it, but I found it very enjoyable. You can probably notice a trend here...  How about the ground combat? They improved nearly everything from AC. No longer can you 'spam Y to win'. They have added many new enemies into the game, such as electricty covered enemies and medics, that require you to change up your tactics. There is also a 'Fear Takedown' ability that allows you to take out multiple enemies in one go without the enemy being able to react, which helps makes Predator Mode faster and more enjoyable. Finally, when travelling around the city, it is mostly unchanged, but they did buff the grapple boost since the city is MUCH bigger this time around.   This game is a great conclusion to the trilogy. The story is very well done (but the ending was a bit weak), the presentation is godly (well, when everything is working properly), the gameplay is the best it has ever been, and the music OH THE MUSIC. The PC version is playable now and you can get it for cheap during a Steam Sale or on a third party site. If you are a fan of the Arkham series, you should get this game. If you are new, play AC first, then come to this.

I think it's important to contribute a review that doesn't just focus on the technical issues. I bought it recently and have played about 20 hours. I haven't had a single glitch in that time. Follow the recommended specs, and you should be fine.  For the game itself, it's both good and bad. I still like Asylum the best of the series. I think it was actually the right size in terms of gameplay with a good progression overall to both main and side quests. This game is enormous, and it's really not always in a good way.  First, the good:  The Batmobile is pretty awesome. I was genuinely surprised. I thought it would by clunky and pointless like most attempts to add vehicles into established series are, but it actually plays really well. I think the chase side missions involving the batmobile are some of the most fun in the game. The pseudo-destruction reaped upon the city as you mow down statues and cleave off corners of walls adds to the feeling that you're driving an incredibly powerful machine. Mowing down an entire riot of baddies sending them flying in all directions is also entertaining. It's over-powered, but the game compensates for that by locking off encounters that should be fought without it.  The new types of side missions are also cool. I like the addition of the flying drones, and the takedown method for them is clever. The different types of bad guys are managed well, and there are lots of creative opportunities for playing around with your abilities.  The Mediocre:  The story has its good points, but a lot of it is really melodramatic and predictable. Harley Quinn's voice is the single most annoying thing ever created. Picture everything she says as voiced by Jar Jar for added entertainment value. The way The Joker is handled is a lot of fun. I think that's the most entertaining part of the story. The part that's trying to be a Nolan movie just fell on its face for me. Yea, I get it already. Joker/Batman represent an ethical duality where they're both really two sides of the same coin. They exist outside the law pursuing their own view of the world at the expense of society based solely on their own beliefs. Blah blah blah. Please stop beating me over the head with it like it's not a simple, well-trodden idea. It works really well when they treat it as satire. The Joker has some great moments openly mocking you or egging you on. A number of times I wished I could actually choose to do what he suggested. That would've made a much better game in my opinion. There's also some good chatter of the generic bad guys commenting on elements of the world or just their own generic nature. When it tries to take itself seriously, it becomes dull in its trauma.  The Bad:  This game is huge. This seems like a weird thing to cite as bad, but it's so absurdly large that it becomes genuinely aggravating. The side quests are the biggest example. There's an entire wheel of side quests. I'm not sure how many there are exactly, but I'd estimate around 20. They're not just go somewhere, do the thing, and finish the quest type of deals. You go do the thing, and then five more of that thing appear an hour later. So you go do those five, but then still five more appear another hour later. After fifteen to twenty-five of them, you might finally be done. That's the case for nearly every single one of the twenty different side quests. Some things aren't even official side quests but still need to be eliminated anyway like the aerial drones.  So you clear out a sector of the map. Then you progress in the story a little, and all of a sudden that sector isn't clear anymore. It's not filled with something new and cool though. It just has a few more of exactly the same time-consuming thing you already cleared out the first time. It's fun clearing out the aerial drones the first 5-8 times. When they start appearing four more at a time in the late game, it's just painful. The checkpoints would also be fun just a few times, but there are like 40 of them to clear out. Many of the side quests are really just the same thing in a 'different situation.' Rescuing firefighters, clearing military checkpoints, and clearing out watchtowers all involve taking out exactly the same clustered group of baddies in basically the same way. You're just doing it for a supposedly different goal. Every single one of those will have to be done so many times to fulfill their own quests that you'll have no desire to finish them. My hat is off to anyone who has 100% this game. That's a Sisyphean task to me.  It goes further. There are 243 riddler puzzles. I kid you not. I'm actually bored just by the idea of going after them all. It's obvious someone just went through the map after they finished this massive city and stuck a trophy in every single place you could possibly fit one. It's obnoxious. All of this goes against basic game design principles. Have a clear and varied progression that increases in challenge. Most of the content in this game is the same thing over and over. The unfortunate part of that is it really takes away from the parts of the game that are well-designed and do present a varied challenge. I understand they were trying to make a huge epic conclusion, but they really cluttered it up and made it shallow by throwing in too much of the same kinds of content.  Synopsis:  Overall I recommend it. I paid about $13 for it on sale, and I think I got more than enough good content for my money. I'd pay up to $20 for it. Pay the price tag if you really love the series and know you can run it. The story isn't bad and does have both fun and cool moments. The batmobile is awesome to play with, and the city is fun to fly around sporadically wrecking baddies. Explore the more varied content until you feel like you've seen everything you want to, and then quit. Much of the extra content and side quests quickly become overly similar and boring. Don't plan to 100% the game. For reference, I did 100% Asylum and loved it. I wouldn't recommend even trying to 50% this one in terms of completing all side quests and clearing all sectors. It's not a fun task. Play through the main story and explore, and you'll have a good time with it. I'd say 7/10 for a rating.

I should start this by saying that I am a fan of the series. I still think the Arkham games are a must play for anyone who likes games, console of P.C. I even went as far as playing through this game even when it first released just because I have a huge appreciation for what the Arkham games brought the table when it comes to world building, art and game design. With that said, the release of this game was a sham. The game was unplayable for a huge chunk of the P.C. fanbase and even those of us who could play it had to deal with countless issues. The season pass was shady, as usual, and months later we've come to find that the DLC that we got was just... disappointing- barely adding anything worth experiencing.   Bugs and DLC aside, the game itself is a bit of a disappointment. The story feels flat and unsatisfying, Riddler is extra annoying with his unnecessarily large amount of trophies and really out of place Riddler races. The Batmobile was a thing you were forced with deal with rather than a fun addition to the game. The cast seems interesting and promising but fails to deliver; I really wanted to see more of Robin and Catwoman, Batman's interaction with his constantly-falling-appart family, anything. It's the last game in the series, give the fans closure... but no. Instead there's a repetitive and predictable story filled with the same tropes and structure anyone who's read a Batman comic in the past 10 years has seen over and over again.   With that said, the gameplay is still good ol' Arkham. Combat is still fun and snappy, beating up thug after brainless thug is still satisfying. The game is gorgeous when it wants to be and the art design is still awesome. I guess that's a plus. Let's face it, if you're a fan of the series you're probably going to get the game anyway but, as much as it pains me to say it, I would hold on to that thought. Wait until it's in a better condition or even better, wait for a  very  deep discount.

First of all, there's a 30 FPS cap, that's bad... You can easily fix it with a quick googe search, so it's good now, right? Kinda... Not really... The game is not well optimized, we need some stutter fix. When i just spin the camera i drop from everything between from 68 to 21 FPS. Super annoying when i'm gliding, as it can drop to even 1 FPS. I even used the performance test in the game and got solid 48+ FPS atleast, it looked smooth and quite sexy. Not what i get in the game though, it's not as sexy. :/  As long as it is like this, i do not want to recommend it. But atleast in the little sequence where i got into a fight, it was good, it felt like Batman combat, smooth 40 FPS, hehe...  EDIT: Other than that let's review the rest of the game. As of now i've gotten a bit more play time, so i'll break down somme of the elements in the game.   Combat:  I love it. The basic combat is easy and satisfying, it looks smooth and cool and you just land a sick punch after another. There are some more advanced combat, where you can sneak upon enemies and take them down easily in a chain from 3 to 5, a mechanic that makes it easier to take down armed enemies and it's a reward for stelathing.   The Batmobile:  It looks amazing, it's such a massive tool and has a beautiful design. The driving however, feels too heavy, it feels like you're driving a boosted tank, steering it is kinda weird, but powersliding works fine. There is however a combat mechanic in the batmobile where you kind of control it like a 4-legged sliding robot. This mechanic feels great, really. You can strafe with small boosters and steer through tight spaces easily and your winch to pull down stuff on the map is awesome.   Story so far:  SPOILERS, maybe?   I'm still just in the beginning, but the main villain is Scarecrow(I love Scarecrow) and it's about his new chemical experiment(zombies, kind of?) and so far the interaction and cutscenes are pretty cool. I must say, it gets you in the story fast and keeps going like that as of now.     Graphics:  This game is beautiful. On High ofcourse. It does look good Low, but you can see the lack of details up close, especially on the batsuit. The rain/weather looks good enough to make a darker atmosphere. But as it is poorly optimized i'm running my game on Low still. Could go High, but too many frame drops in movement.   Memory:  It's a really RAM heavy game. I have 8Gb of RAM. While playing on Low and no AA. 3 Monitors, no programs other than Steam open. ~85% memory usage. Open Google Chrome, 95-100%. Just a heads up.  PS. Will edit as the game gets updates and I get further in the story.

So I liked all the Arkham games, including this one.   In terms of gameplay, this is not a great departure from the last three games. You are Batman and you alternate between jumping from rooftop to rooftop beating up random dudes and then having fisticuffs with crowds of jerks. Like Arkham City and Origins, it's still an open world sandbox game wherein Batman fights to protect a city that seems to be populated exclusively with dudes who are lining up to rob a bank or knock over a jewelry store. Seriously, besides one building of cops, a couple of firefighters and Batman's assorted sidekicks, the entire city is just a pack of dip♥♥♥♥♥. It makes you sort of wonder why saving it is even worth it in the first place.   Anyhow, that aside, the main innovation is you have the Batmobile, which is a tank thingie that's fun enough to use. Nothing groundbreaking, but it's not like the Batmobile segments aren't fun or whatnot.   The story meanwhile is pretty strong, although due to the comic book origins of the series it pulls a lot of punches. I think this is supposed to be the last of the Arkham games, so you'd think that the creators would be more willing to kill characters. I mean, it's not like if you kill them in this game they're deleted from the comic book forever guys. But in spite of that, there are some incredibly good scenes and I was very interested from start to finish. Some plot twists are presented a bit too obviously (the identity of the Arkham Knight is painfully obvious for about three hours), but most of it still comes together pretty solidly.   Until you get to the ending.   Or well, I should say 'Until you see what the ending involves'. Because in order to actually see what happens at the end you've got to collect every single mother♥♥♥♥ing Riddler trophy. All 250 or so of them.   I don't understand Rocksteady's obsession with those ♥♥♥♥ing things. Is it just a petulant idea that if you go through all this trouble making a big sandbox city that you ought to put ♥♥♥♥ around to make sure the player goes around appreciating all of it? Ugh.  I ended up watching the ending on Youtube. It was alright. But the fact that the game locked it behind tedious collection quests is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.   Still, beyond that it's a good game. I'll probably play some of the DLC.

The fluidity of the combat, and the swiftness of the stealth. Batman has also never looked better, at launch the port was very incomplete, but now it runs quite well. Hopefully companies learn to put more effort in their pc ports, but only time will tell. At 30$ this game is a steal and I highly recommend it.   TL; DR Pros: +all of the gameplay +stellar voice acting +plethora of easter eggs for diehard fans +really detailed and beautiful world +updated graphics engine +improved port greatly since launch +replay value w/ side missions, riddler trophies, more challenges etc.  Cons: -Overused batmobile at end of the story -batmobile stealth -lack of boss fights -occasional glitches   Overall this is probably my favorite game of last year and I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the previous entries in the arkham franchise especially if you want to see the conclusion of what happens after arkham city. Highly Recommended.  9/10

I've withheld my review on Arkham Knight til it came back up on the store so it will not be considered a pre-release review. First, let me say that I pre-purchased the Arkham Knight Premium Edition back at the start of June due to the being a longtime Arkham-series fan, and had actually had my hopes up that this would be as phenominal a game as it had been advertised in previews/trailers.   When the game originally launched, I could barely play it, as it was so horribly unoptimized that I was one of the 90+% of people that had to use a community-discussion workaround to make it playable. After I did get it up and running, the framerates I got weren't the best, but the game was quite playable with some moderate frame drops in overly busy areas. I completed the main storyline and a good amount (but not all) of the side content, and was satisfied with the story. However, I knew this was not the game I paid for, and sat down to wait for Rocksteady and Warner Brothers to clean up the mess they let Iron Galaxy Games make of the pc version.   Over 3 months later, the September patch came out, and at that point I couldn't even launch the game due to changes they'd made in the patch. This infuriated me, even moreso due to the fact that the pc DLCs had still been held back and the console players were still enjoying their games while the pc community was still in patch limbo.  Another month later, just a few days ago, another patch is promised to be released... and what did we get? No major changes except that they allowed the cumulative DLC-backlog that the original game-owners were due to finally be recieved and played. All the bugs/glitches from September were still there, and I still couldn't even start the game. I was able to figure out my particular issue and get into the game again, but the damage was done. I'll play the DLC from what I'm still owed in the season pass, but I frankly don't have the heart to even bother replaying the game again.   This whole 4-month (and soon to be half a year at this rate) fiasco just reeks of incompitence and flat out apathy on the part of the developers. The pc version of the game should NEVER have been outsourced to a 3rd party to complete. The fact that Warner Brothers re-released the game in this state and offered people who purchase it all the prior Arkham games is just a flat-out slap to the face, as it literally amounts to nothing, since people will have probably already had purchased most if not all of those games.  In conclusion, I cannont recommend this game as it is at this current time. It's a shame that the conclusion to the Arkham series had to turn out like this; I enjoyed many of Rocksteady's games in the past, but now I'm leery of anything they produce in the furture for pc, as I don't know if it'll get outsourced again.

Batman Arkham Knight is literally all over the place in terms of its content. Sometimes I think that it's a solid 9/10 game, but at other times it can be a 3/10 game. The first few hours of Arkham Knight are superb, they show off everything the game has to offer, and contain a stellar story. The ball was raised extremely high up at that point, but then you get to the rest of the game. Between the nonsensical and downright boring padding thats added on after the main story, (which by the way adds about 10 extra hours to the game) and the lackluster narrative, Arkham Knight takes that highly raised ball, and slams it through the poorly-textured floor in its final acts. Not to mention the performance which is all over the place with my GTX 970, sometimes I get a consistent 45+ FPS, while other times it can go as low as 15 FPS in the span of 5 minutes. There also just isn't much to do, after the story you have the option of New Game+ or playing one of the five challenge maps they have to offer, that's it. In the end, I don't see how a game that took 4 years to make, and had multiple studios working on it, could only muster about 18 hours of actual gameplay to offer to consumers. I wouldn't recommend buying this at full price, let alone on PC. If you have to play it, borrow it, or rent it, as its not worth 59.99+ just for 18 hours of gameplay. In the end, I give this game a 5.5/10 - Slightly Above Average.

TL;DR - 9/10, RockSteady fixed the issues that plagued the PC release, another great Batman game! If you liked Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, GET IT!   WARNING - MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD!!!  =-=-=-=-=-=-=  This is very much like Arkham City in design, but RockSteady has added a few wonderful things to the mix which keep it fresh and new. The new suit lets you get around the city more quickly and the new Fear takedowns are fun, but the real beauty in this game lies in the addition of...wait for it...   ... the BatMobile.   *Disclamer: I am HORRIBLE at driving games. Utterly awful. Can't do it. Never could.  If there is one area where this game ***could** have fallen apart, the BatMobile and driving around the city is it. The open world game Mad Max had time trial missions that were almost impossible to complete and that robbed me of some of the enjoyment of the game. However, RockSteady has avoided every possible pitfall that I could think of with driving around in Gotham and has made the addition of the BatMobile another exercise in fun. If *I* can finish the driving challenges in this game, ANYONE can. The car-to-tank mechanic allows for easy maneuvering around tight turns and narrow areas, and the coolness factor of the car and the tank cannot be overemphasized.  Now for the negative: I did have to go to the controller for the driving time trials, as well as one of the side missions during the game. If, like me, you are a completionist when it comes to open-world games, you'll probably need a controller to get through everything.  Am I nitpicking? Pretty sure I'm nitpicking. Yeah, I think I'm nitpicking.  I've played through about 15% of the main storyline and some of the side missions, and I'm hooked. Great Riddler puzzles, lots of combat combos, all the good stuff you've come to expect from RockSteady's Batman games.  PROS ------ - All the good stuff you've come to expect from the Batman series - Great new suit - BATMOBILE!!! BATMOBILE THAT CONVERTS INTO A BAT-TANK!!! - Did I mention the BatMobile? - Gotta love the BatMobile!!! - Did I mention that the BatMobile converts into a FREAKIN' TANK??!!?!!? - FREAKIN' BATMOBILE!!! THAT CONVERTS INTO A FREAKIN' BAT-TANK!!!  CONS ------ - Some parts of the game work better with a controller than with a mouse/keyboard setup

When Batman: Arkham Knight first released, I was hesitant after hearing so many problems being shared with the game that I didn't install the game for a long period of time. Come time to play, I only experienced minor lagging and after a few updates there were no more issues in the performance department. Nevertheless, the wait was worth it! Batman: Arkham Knight has everything you could have asked for with the colossal and dark Gotham City. The Batmobile is integral to the majority of the game but I'd say it struck the balance between gliding and driving just right (besides, those combat sequences in Battle Mode are a lot of fun and break up travel, and never unnecessarily). The Gotham City Police Department is the Batman's rock in this game where Commissioner James Gordon's character steps into the spotlight the most out of the rest of his appearances in the series. Nods to the previous titles involving certain villains are made and some new faces will come as a surprise. The beginning is eerie and the graphics throughout the game are the best I've seen in a superhero game. Batman: Arkham Knight dwells on the the theme of fear and shows us that fear in many ways isn't a weakness at all. It's the only thing that keeps us wary, not weary. In being aware, we're not really afraid at all, not even of who we are and what we've come to be. Batman: Arkham Knight may not be the best superhero game but there's no reason not to settle for being one of the greatest in a series of great superhero games.

Disclaimer: The only reason that I don't recommend this game is because of the performance issues on PC. These issues are still prevalent even after the latest patch (re-release), and greatly detract from the game. Now that that's out of the way...  The actual game is fantastic. Even if you've played the previous games to death, the combat will still feel pretty fresh and rewarding. The story is also pretty good. When I finished the game I was kinda blown away by all the twists that are crammed into this game. If you are an avid Batman fan then you might be disappointed by where the story goes, but there are still many rewarding parts of the story for you. Some of the side missions do feel tacked on, but they will also surprise you in the best possible way - trust me! Perhaps the best part of this game is the presentation. Every scene in the game feels 'hand-crafted' in a way... Like the developers sat down and said, 'How can we make this look dank af?' They probably also had a similar discussion about the textures as they are extremely detailed. Even if you zoom in on objects their level of detail still holds up.   Too bad then that all this hard work goes to waste on the PC port. If there were a few stutters here and there, then I would be okay with it. But this game is plagued by stuttering and low frame-rates. It's disappointing that the actual enjoyment of such a stellar game can be marred by something that WB promised to fix so long ago, and that Nvidia should have picked up on after sponsoring the game with their new graphics cards. If you really want to get it on PC then wait until they actually fix it properly.  TL;DR: Great game, don't buy it on PC.

Batman: Arkham Knight was nothing short of a trainwreck at release and remains today a bitter disappointment for me.  For starters I'd like to point out as a disclaimer that my general taste for the Arkham games may be a bit out of common bounds since I genuinely liked Arkham Origins and all it had to offer, so when I say that Arkham Knight is the worst installment in the series you can take this as by far the most subjective and biased statement in this entire review. Moving on.  I don't think there's much need to go what was the most glaring issue of this game for most of its post-release lifespan, the absolutely godawful performance and practically non-existent optimization. To summarize for those who somehow missed it, the game ran terribly, was locked at 30 fps (unlocking the framerate would at the time cause severe performance issues and bugs), and was in fact so difficult to run on even the most modern rigs that WB Games pulled the game altogether from Steam until they could manage to fix it - and that fix took a long time to come, with a blatant disregard for the few loyal consumers who got the game and its season pass since DLC for the PC version of the game was also significantly delayed.  But all of this is pretty much deprecated info left here for history's sake. The game runs well nowadays, albeit still suffers from a few FPS dips and it's a massive ram hog, but the opportunity of adding more RAM (up to 16gb) and a SSD fixed those issues in great part for me.  Performance issues aside the game does look stunning, and there isn't much to go against the general prettiness of the whole thing. It's consistent, the design of everything is great, some of its later sequences are legitimately breathtaking and it finally gets faces right for the first time in the Arkham series. As far as being a visual treat goes, Arkham Knight is legitimately one of the best looking games I've ever played both from a purely graphical and also a design standpoint.  Sadly there's a lot wrong with the game in ways that in my opinion far outweigh the prettiness of the graphics. So let's start with the two core mechanics of the game which have been the pillars of the series since the very beginning, combat and predator sections.  Combat which in my opinion was always the more interesting part of those two sections suffers in this game from feature bloating. Rocksteady said at some point that Arkham Asylum's gameplay was designed as kind of a rhythm game where Batman had to sync up his hits to the music and while that concept was thankfully scrapped the way the whole series builds its combat is obviously still based on that concept, and the difficulty comes from both keeping up a good pace and dealing with special enemies accordingly. However in Arkham Knight there's so many different types of special enemies that the player will actively spend more time performing really specific tasks to dispatch them than have fun just beating thugs up, to the point where the 'free' part of freeflow combat just kind of disappears. Alongside the returning types from AA and AC there's now electrified enemies who cannot be touched at all no matter the angle and must be hit with the batclaw to discharge the electricity and charging guys who can only be stopped with a batarang or by getting out of the way. This latter type of enemy also causes the camera to pan towards them so they're actually visible no matter what but it can also be fairly disorientating especially in more crowded fights. Finally there's enemies which have literally all of the above traits and these are a ♥♥♥♥♥ to deal with. They're huge, meaning they require beatdowns to take care of, they can switch to blades so you need to do the knife counter, they can electrify their fists forcing you to use the batclaw, and they can get shields - and they switch in less than a second which in theory would force you to stay on your toes but in reality only slows combat down to a crawl as you cannot possibly deal with them quickly.  Then there's the predator segments which frankly I've never quite enjoyed but this game really manages to make them far less fun than any of the previous titles. You very quickly start to run into enemies with heartbeat sensors, and disruptors which block access to detective vision on top of drone operators and a bunch of other stuff that kind of also force you to stop playing the game as you want and instead focus on really moving slowly to apply the same formula to the same types of enemies over and over again.  Speaking of upgrades there's some new stuff in there alongside the returning skills, notably the ability to lock and throw gadgets on enemies from a gliding position, although I've literally never used this because the situations in which it actually is useful are close to none, and it's not a really fun skill to operate in its weird implementation. Fear Takedowns are also a neat addition but only serve to simplify some aspects of the game further while encouraging exploits.  A lot of missions and side activities also revolve around tagging along with a second character, allowing for switching at will, and while it's a cool concept that works well on its own the complete inability to play any of them in free roam even though Arkham City had that feature is really weird and makes it feel unfinished.  There's a third part to Arkham games and that's the detective stuff. As far as this goes I thought AK was a bit weak since there's relatively few detective work involved due to something we'll talk about later. The few cases we get to go through and solve are pretty fun however and the Season of Infamy DLC does add a lot more investigating to the game which is a welcome change.  Now there's a new thing that the game added which every piece of promo material made sure to hammer home, and that's the batmobile. Put simply the batmobile is one of the most god damn annoying, shoehorned features I've seen implemented in a sequel in a very long time. At first the concept sounds neat and yes the car does control wonderfully well but the sheer quantity of missions and tasks that require the batmobile is so overwhelming that it really takes away from the experience and that whole feeling of 'oh crap I'm driving the batmobile' really becomes 'oh no I'm driving the batmobile again' before you reach the second half of the game. There's a lot to do with the batmobile, way too much in fact as nearly every single case, side-activity and story mission requires use of the batmobile at least once.  So what about the story ? Rocksteady hasn't exactly graced us with any groundbreaking storytelling up until this point and this doesn't really change much. Without spoiling anything in case you still want to experience it the whole thing revolves around a really, REALLY stupid concept and the recycling of old ideas done better in the comics or in other adaptations. It's not a good story by any means and the way it's told opens one new plot hole every mission.  As a final slap in the face story-wise the game locks away the true ending of the game behind 100% completion, and completing this game 100% is horrible due to one and ONE thing only; the god damn RIDDLER. This game has an ungodly amount of trophies to collect, a lot of which require the batmobile. Basically the riddler started as an amusing side activity in Arkham Asylum to slowly degrading into a horrible grindy mess.  Then finally there's the DLC practices. When this game first came out there was barely anything on side content and the dozens of brawl and predator maps that the previous titles had are now completely gone as the vanilla game had barely three or four maps instead. While DLC did a lot to add to that list, I as a customer was genuinely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the amount of content that the previous games had by default but that was locked here behind a paywall.  All in all I think Arkham Origins was a better game, and this one is best left ignored.

I really wanted to give this game a good review, I really did. For one, it's an Arkham game, so you would expect all of what made the other games great. The good news is, that's all here - the plot, combat and other elements are bigger and better than ever. So it pains me to give this game a bad score, and I'll explain why.  THIS GAME RUNS LIKE ♥♥♥♥. There it is, plain fact. Unlike the other games in the series, this one was handed out to an external port developer - never a good sign when you hear it's a multiplatform game - which goes some way in explaining the performance problems. Also, inexplicably for a pc title, it's locked at 30fps ingame (even though the benchmark tool is frame unlocked). The real problems many people have been reporting are to do with the texture quality, very limited and half-♥♥♥♥♥ graphics options, and frame rate issues (which are apparently caused by the restrictive Denuvo DRM the game sneakily enforces on you). I have a reasonably good PC, and was surprised to see that I couldn't even reach 30fps on normal settings (even though Arkham City reaches a stable 60 on max settings). This also ties to the texture quality issues - some areas, enemies and environments have disgustingly low resolution textures, even on the higher detail levels. How could the publisher release the game in this state? Graphically, the game looks like City but with added forced motion blur (which I have yet to find a way to disable) so it's surprising to see how bad it runs. Add to this the frequent stuttering when moving rapidly across the map (which given the size and detail, I can kind of forgive Rocksteady for).  So all in all, the game is a beautiful diamond in the rough clay of performance issues, DRM and lazy porting. I am quite disappointed, as the game's new additions - the batmobile, improved combat and flight etc. are brilliant. I would advise you to hold off buying this until they release patches to fix most or all of these issues. AND PLEASE, PLEASE REMOVE THAT STUPID 30FPS LOCK! WE ARE NOT CONSOLES, ROCKSTEADY!

Review will have spoilers for previous Batman games.  Story -   Even though the Joker, perhaps Batman’s greatest nemesis, has died, it seems the city has not evolved for the better with the disposal of the mad clown. Scarecrow has taken his place in order to demolish the entire city, instead of occupying himself with petty crimes. He has released a fear inducing neurotoxin all over Gotham City, making everyone go crazy and do whatever they can to run away from their (imaginary) fears.  When the city is evacuated, only Batman and a handful of law enforcers take up the fight against the city which is currently crawling with criminals. When Batman receives Intel from Oracle, commissioner Gordon’s daughter, that Ace Chemicals is the brewing spot of the toxin, Batman spares no effort in trying to stop the madman. Sadly, it seems another evildoer is out for Batman, who is also in cahoots with the dreadful Scarecrow. This mysterious figure is known as the Arkham Knight, who looks like a Batman copycat with a more ‘mecha-like’ suit.  The main plot of the game progresses in a fairly fast pace, if you solely concern yourself with the main quest. Overall the story feels like a theatrical experience.  Graphics -  Batman: Arkham Knight looks stunning. Whilst the city shows not that much life in the sense of many inhabitants running around, it does so in many other ways. You’ll be cruising through streets with buildings with heaps of details, great textures and a lot of the smaller obstacles are destructible. Whilst the latter may not sound that impressive, it shows a lot of interactivity with the city and even more, that the developers wanted their city to be alive.  Characters in the grim city look detailed, albeit that some enemies are overused. Batman and the main characters all look great, with the same dark vibe surrounding them. It seems the harsh existence has taken its toll on all the warriors of justice and this is quite clear with how everyone looks.  Overall the game aims for a very dark atmosphere and it more than succeeds in accomplishing that goal.   Sound -  With mood setting music, loud punch noises and enough explosions, the sound also does its best to set the mood. Whilst everything is already top notch, it will still be the voice acting that steals the show. The voice of Kevin Conroy will immediately be recognized by longtime Batman fans. As he has been voicing Batman on many occasions since the nineties, he is simply a top asset for the atmosphere of the game.  Gameplay/Combat -   Combat feels intuitive but also stiff at the same time. Punching your foes into submission and pulling off basic counters works quite well and will make sure the combat is rather fluent, while on the other hand the extra commands and combos feel annoying, as they are often only available for a very short amount of time. The same can be said for aerial attacks, as the command for the much appreciated attack does not always appear/trigger when you want it to.  Of course the game offers ample upgrades for you to choose from when you gain more experience. Like in many games, Arkham Knight works with different skill trees where you can choose new upgrades, combos or skills from. The options seem rather confusing at first, but after a bit of investigation they become easy to work with.   Conclusion - Recommended   Batman: Arkham Knight proves to be a great mix of gameplay, graphics and sound with a grand, yet grim, story-line that reigns supreme. Whilst the Bat-mobile proves to be an overused asset of the game, you’ll still find plenty of other things to do that will occupy you for hours to come.  Outside of the main objective there’s enough of side material for you to process. You’ll be able to ‘solve’ the Riddler’s puzzles, which is simply gathering collectibles and there will be other side quests available as well. Enough content if you’d rather level up a bit, before tackling the main problem at hand.  Truth be told, in many ways I feel as if this review is only scratching the surface of many areas in the game. That being said, I’d rather keep it a bit shorter for you to discover more about the gadgets, side quests and of course the main plot of the game.

It is such a shame that they boned the PC release of this game so hard, because Rocksteady is a solid developer and this is a great addition to the Arkham series. The symptoms of the terrible port still persist, although I would say that the game was about 80% okay for me. The biggest problem I had was that, in racing around Gotham in the Batmobile, the game is forced to load tonnes of textures incredibly quickly, and when it failed to do so fast enough it would freeze and think for about 10-15 seconds before resuming again. Because a lot of the driving requires very fast reflexes, this could at times cause considerable frustration, and unfortunately this happened almost entirely one the first island, which soured my initial opinion. Other than this though, there was really only the occasional noticable bug that didn't get ironed out as the QA manpower was diverted elsewhere during the release crisis. This game was rightly made an example of, as WB's despicable release deserved no forgiveness from consumers, however it's a shame that it had to screw over what is actually a really good game by a really good developer.   Now, beyond all that, let me say that this is one of the best looking games ever made. I read a debate on this topic that argued between this game and Star Wars Battlefront, and while Battlefront is all style and no substance, Arkham Knight has more than enough substance to satiate those coming from Arkham City. It again ups the ante over its predecessors and delivers the entirety of Gotham for us to play around in, and while Arkham Origins ostensibly did the same, Rocksteady actually managed to fill the space with character. The sheer amount of time that must have been spent on the art of this game is absolutely mind-boggling. Almost every inch of the city feels specifically crafted rather than copy-pasted, and on top that there're dozens of unique indoor locations to boot. The NVIDIA enhancements are pretty stunning too – the way the rain plumes off of your cape as you leap into flight never gets old - although most of them will test your hardware.  In regards to gameplay, it’s much the same as the previous games, with a few new gadgets here and there. I'd heard a lot of complaints about the amount of Batmobile in the game, and I personally can't really see where the negativity has come from. The Batmobile combat isn't the most elegant, but neither is the hand-to-hand combat. Although I quite enjoyed travelling around in it, it can also be abandoned for the majority of the game, and travelling on your own is a viable alternative when you level your skills up enough. In short, I didn't find it to be an unwelcome addition to the game.  This is the fourth Arkham game though, and there are signs of the franchise tiring. The Riddler’s riddles felt lazier and many literally spelled out the answer in the riddle itself, many of the villains make their third or fourth appearances and really started to feel recycled, and the combat system seemed (at least at the beginning) even more self-guiding than before. Some of the tasks also seemed more like busy work than before, but that might be a related to the sheer amount of them they've used to fit the size of the city, as well as my own personal weariness of the 'open-world formula'. In saying that, the story is genuinely intriguing and I can't seem to put the game down. I played 21 hours in the first 2 days at a time where I was getting burnt out really quickly with other games, and I’d often find myself saying ‘one more mission’ until it was 3 in the morning.   TL;DR - This is a great sequel to Arkham City, and exposes the fact that, while they own the franchise, in developing Arkham Origins WB didn’t actually understand what made an Arkham game so good. AK continues to keep the core gameplay intact whilst expanding the scope of the game, however, I can't see them being able to expand any further from here on. I can’t see them creating a bigger game world, or doing much more with the established gameplay, or using the same characters again without it all seeming tired. I haven’t finished this yet, and perhaps the plot gives it away, but I hope they don’t keep bashing out endless games in this vein, because I don’t know if there’s much more of the well to draw from in this same way. If this is the swansong of the series, it’s a shame that the release was such a clusterf**k, and as a consequence has scarred the game permanently. If you can get it cheap in a good sale, like I did, I highly recommend it, but I wouldn’t pay full price, as despite the fact that it's a great game, it’s still broken in a number of ways.

Luckily I ended up running Batman: Arkham Knight a lot better than the first couple of hours. Somehow a clean install of the AMD 15.6 beta driver did the trick, or at least I think it was clean installing it. I'm not even sure why I'm bothering with a review at this point, since it's (temporarily) not even possible to buy it any more on Steam. Anyway, about the game itself:  + Bigger and it can be even more good-looking than Arkham City. Emphasis on CAN though, because the PC graphics settings are still downright awful. + Gliding has been expanded greatly and it's even more fun. Ejecting yourself from the Batmobile to reach the skies never gets old. + New gadgets and tricks to neutralise enemies and strategically plan your attacks. + The hallucinations are great, especially   the Joker's   monologues are hilarious.  + Subtle changes and funny Easter eggs in Gotham City due to   being exposed to Fear Gas  . + Dual play combat was fun.  +/- Fear Takedowns were cool, but like Knock-out Smashes they give away your position. So unfortunately if you like using stealth to remain unseen and unheard for the entire section, it's not the best option. +/- Even though the Batmobile is a fresh and exciting addition to the series, it's getting shoved down our throats rather a lot. At least half of the time it wasn't necessary.   - Main story is heavily disappointing and underwhelming, I thought all the super villains were working TOGETHER to hunt down the Bat. Turned out it's pretty much every man for themselves again. - The secret and mysterious identity of the Arkham Knight was painfully obvious after   Batman starts to hallucinate about   a certain individual. - Side quests are forgettable, except for the Opera missions. - You're being forced to do uninteresting side quests to unlock   Operation Knightfall  , the game's ending. You even have to collect all ~250 Riddler trophies and riddles to unlock the full ending. - I'm not a fan of the ultra gritty redesigns of some characters, I preferred Asylum and City's 'comic book realistic' designs.  When all is said and done, it's a good game and definitely worth buying in normal circumstances, but I still don't recommend this PC version in its current state. Even though I ended up playing it rather stable and smooth for the majority of the time, there are still a lot of people having technical issues.

Oh boy. Batman Arkham Knight, the fourth in the Arkham series and the third developed by Rocksteady, this is without a... incredibly dividing game. When this game was released back in June 2015, it was a more disasterous launch than the Challenger shuttle. The framerate was ♥♥♥♥, glitches were everywhere, and the PS4 had better graphics than the max version. Numerous people have put this on their 'Worst of 2015' list because of this. So. What do I think of this atrocious excuse for a game?  It was pretty good. Not my GOTY, but I think it would be in my top 10 of 2015. Now, before you crucify me, just hear me out, alright? Put the gun down... HEY, PUT THE DAMN GUN DOW...  STORY: You are Bruce Wayne, AKA Batman. After the death of The Joker in Arkham City nine months post-Arkham City, crime rates have declined in Gotham and it seems that things are normal. However, The Scarecrow threatens to unleash his fear toxin upon Gotham, causing the city to evacuate and for Batman to get back into his suit and go after him and restore peace to Arkham for possibly the last time. However, a militia lead by the Arkham Knight, a villian who nobody knows anything about, has teamed up with Scarecrow, causing things to be more difficult than they would usually be. The story is alright, it isn't as good as it was in City IMHO, but it was better than Origins.  GAMEPLAY: Combat is refined, it feels better than it did before. Stealth is there, and it feels more viable. Still, it feels awesome to beat thugs up, and while that still is an option, it is a bit harder of one than before. There's a new FEAR takedown system, which lets you take out up to three thugs (five with upgrades) before you go into combat. There are medics now who revive enemies you knocked out and give existing enemies a boost, take those out ASAP or else it will be harder to deal with. The usual thugs from the last games are there, too. Boss battles are fine, nothing as awesome as the Mr. Freeze battle, but it's fine.  We also have the Batmobile now, and let me tell you... eh, it's alright. It isn't as awesome as I wanted it to be, it feels a bit lighter than it should have been, but at the same time, I don't get where people are coming from when they say it's terrible. It's pretty fun, and I liked using it.  GRAPHICS, PERFORMANCE, AND LEVEL DESIGN: Okay, let me say this first and foreforth: I don't know if anyone else will have better luck with a different rig. That said, I had no issues at all. None. I think that all of the issues are fixed as far as I can tell. Graphically it looks amazing too. And don't go all 'But dog, it looks better on PS4, nyeh!' SHUT UP! It still looks good. So shut up. Gotham looks good, it has a lot of details to it, all three islands are nice to be around. The open world looks nice, there are a lot of cool places to explore, and I can't complain  CHARACTERS, VOICE ACTING, AND DESIGN: Batman is voiced by Kevin Conroy like the last couple times, and he does a good job. Scarecrow is played by one of the guys from Fringe, he's spooky as hell and is the best voice actor in this whole thing. The Joker also kinda has a role in this, and Mark Hamill still kicks ♥♥♥. Other than that... well, it's kind of weird. I mean, the voice acting is top notch, but it seems kinda emotionless. Kinda hard to explain. Character design still looks good, no complaints there.  SIDE ACTIVITIES: You're Batman, you got a lot to do. Save firemen, save Catwoman from the Riddler, ♥♥♥♥ around with the Arkham Knight's militia's stuff. Some are better than others of course, I get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at the thought of doing the Riddler trophies and challenges, but ah well. There are also the AR Challenges that you can play, if you're into those, you can play them.  FINAL VERDICT: I don't blame you if you're still a bit butthurt about the performance issues day 1, but it shouldn't cloud your judgement of this game. 8/10, if you like the Arkham games, or are a big Batman fan, it's now $40 off sale, I grabbed it when it was $24. If not, maybe wait for a future sale where it's off more.     How many more bones would you crush? How many lives will you destroy in pursuit of what you call justice? You are the product of everything you fear; Violence, Darkness, Helplessness... All that remains is for you to watch as I drag your beloved Gotham into oblivion.

This is the best Game of the Series.  Let's adress the elephant in the room right away... Performance. Does it run better after the re-realease? Yes! A lot better... but still only acceptable. It's definitely in a playable state tho. The FPS in the game ranges from 10-20 in 'over the city views' (which are very rare) to stable 55-60 on foot and during fights. Batmobil drops the FPS a bit (45-55).. apart from some occasional drops it's fairly stable. I'm playing on Normal Graphics settings with Gameworks turned off.  My PC doesn't even pass the 'recommended' settings, so i would say it's pretty okay. However - the fact that other triple A games run much better on my PC is the reason for my 'acceptable performance' statement. Another thing you should prepare for are crashes. They seem to occur more often the further you progress.  I had about 10-15 crahes in total during my playtrough while most of them were during solving Riddles for the 100% completion. I was about 75% into the Story when i had my first crash. The rest of them was during mentioned 100% completion which you need if you wanna see the ending. ----  Now that we are done with this, let's start with the review of the actual game. Graphics are gorgeous, the story is one of the best of the series, batmobil feels like a batmobil should feel like. The combat is more fluent and responsive than ever (excluding the Red Hood DLC more about that later). Only the Environmental takedowns and the 'knock guy with shield down' doesn't seem to work sometimes.  Locking the 'real' Ending behind a 100% (or 120%) completion may seem annoying at first but makes sense. This is the last game of the series and if you follow the story you will understand why. Just make sure to be bring a lot of patience with you - especially when you are about to solve all of the 243 Riddles.. yes.. 243! Took me 3 days.  The DLCs for Batman (the extra 20%) are nice, introduce some known villians and can really be seen as fan-service for the fans of the Arkham series.   The Arkham Episodes (playing as different character e.g. Batgirl, Harley, Red Hood etc.) are sadly a bit too short. Most of them can be done in about 15-30 minutes. The only longer on is Batgirl which takes about an hour. The Red Hood DLCs introduces some nice new combat moves and style but seems to be a bit clunky. Sometimes Red Hood was just standing there for 1-2 seconds after a takedown or special move not letting me control him while being beaten to death. Apart from that just another load of Fan-service for DC and Arkham lovers.  Overall i would say it's a recommended purchase. You get loads of content, especially if you like to collect stuff.. The performance issues are mostly fixed at least to an acceptable and playable state. DLC and Arkham Episodes are just awesome. Here's what's up with the game, as it stands, just after release:  Cons:  - Poor performance for anyone with mid to upper-level hardware  - Even if you can run it well, the game will use a ridiculous amount of memory (my game got up to 12GB out of my 16GB of installed RAM before I had to restart the game due to the game locking up repeatedly)  - Compared to PS4, the PC port is missing a slew of graphical improvements, including rain textures, ambient occlusion, and many other shaders/visual effects.  - The game is locked at 30FPS unless changed in an .ini file, and then the framerate wibbles and wobbles all over the place.  Pros:  - If you can somehow run the game, like I can, it still plays just fine, until memory issues happen and you have to restart the game. I've only had to do this once, and I'm 3/4ths of the way through the game.  - Even with missing visual effects, it is still a very pretty game, even if it doesn't hold up as well to other recent games.  Wait until the issues are fixed to purchase this game on PC. Otherwise, get it for PS4.

While a good game on its own, Arkham Knight doesn't quite satisfy in terms of being a worthy conclusion to the series. It is still a great game on its own, providing plenty of high-quality, polished gameplay, that I can recommend without hesitation.   A good open world game as far as mechanics and execution go, AK does many things right. The Gotham City is probably the best crafted one in the series, allowing for convenient exploration both on foot and inside of the Batmobile. The side missions are fed to the player at a great pace, allowing for logical and nearly seamless dipping between the side stuff and the main story. What enhances this quality is the fact that many of the side missions require the player to wait. The antagonists leave trails or establish their positions as the story progresses, some objectives are impossible to achieve until Batman can bring in his car to a specific island of the city and, probably my favourite part, many of the missions require you to notice sound cues and follow them. This is quite brilliant, making some of the side-stories to appear more naturally, instead of magical markers showing you everything you need to know. Overall, the open world aspect is fantastic with the exception of Riddler trophies, which are probably the most tedious one in the entire series; a surprise, given that a fair few of them were unexpectedly clever. Sadly, the majority is just an annoying busywork and locking a side-mission conclusion beyond getting 100% of them, while traditional for the series, pains me so much more this time. Needless to say, I lacked the patience to do this.  The gameplay lives up to the high standard set by the design: combat is the smoothest, most dynamic yet, not afraid to throw tonnes of enemies that require old and loved tactics to overcome; but also introducing a few new ways of dealing with the peskiest of adversaries. While the combat received slight polish when compared to the older games, the stealth is where the true revolution happened. Fear Takedowns are a fantastic and satisfying tool, with an interesting balancing mechanic of recharging after stealth takedowns, an action much harder to perform after inciting panic among the enemies. Several gadgets received new functions, uniquely tuned against the new opposing forces, broadening the possibilities of the player. Mobility in stealth sections was improved as well, opening the areas for a much more interesting design.   The variety is further built upon with the most notable toy of them all: the Batmobile. I didn't find myself hating it, personally. It makes exploration faster and brings player's attention to the ground level, which holds some of the surprises, and the usual combat feels good. Not as great as the on-foot fighting, but the hordes of enemy drones do introduce a proper combat dynamic. Car chases, however, get old after just a few of them, and it doesn't help that one of the classic enemies was included for a little bit of a different flavour in a few chases. They just got barely anything going for them, boiling down to a long drive and waiting for when you can hit the attack button again. Once. The boss fights, when in the car, have a similar problem: they are either an exercise in frustration, dragging for far too long or both. I much preferred Riddler racing tracks which, despite requiring a lot of repetition to get them damn perfect for the challenges, served their purpose well and actually amused. Similarly, the new traversal options and weapons contained within the Batmobile breathed some fresh air into the 'riddles'. Overall, a great addition.  Now, just like the open world was great, the story is... well. Forgettable might not even cut it. It has some moments that surprise, but over the course of the hours, it becomes blatantly obvious that the person in charge of writing the story had no idea what to do with it. Scarecrow is completely wasted, coming off as a weaker, bland and lacking villain who basically just rambles on about everything. His appearance in Asylum was more impactful than the leading role, that is how bad it is. The trend of bad storytelling is taken further with the titular Arkham Knight. While an expected nod to the comics, he comes and goes without much of an impact. Definitely a missed opportunity there. Shockingly, the side missions are written much better, at least some of them. For every intriguing, emotional little bit, there is an episode that is short, unengaging and its absence wouldn't hurt the game one bit. And that is on top of half the rogue's gallery having 'revenge' as the sole reason for being in the game. I expected better of these characters, and the game has some of them taken to proper depth. We are even given unexpected and daring conclusions to two of the well-established villain's stories, something I enjoyed seeing and continues the tradition introduced by the ending of Arkham City. Overall, writing is mixed, but the main plot disappoints severely.  And yes, even on a decent setup the game still has hiccups during Batmobile sections, but it is nowhere near unplayable. 9/10  Launch woes and potential performance problems aside, this is another excellent entry in the Arkham series by Rocksteady.  When I bought the game at launch it would not run smoothly on my dated gaming rig. Since then I have bought a new PC, and the game has been patched up a bit, so it was running at a smooth 60fps throughout with all settings maxed. Be warned, you will still need a beefy PC to pull this off.  As far as gameplay goes, it's much of the same from the previous Arkham games. Except for the Batmobile, which is foisted upon you regularly - dare I say I enjoyed the Batmobile bits for what they were worth.  The storyline certainly goes through peaks and troughs but overall it sets a captivating backdrop for all of the Bat-shenanigans and keeps you driving forward to the conclusion.  Visually, the Arkham universe has never looked better, and there's plenty to do to help you explore every nook and cranny.  Overall, the general criticisms you will read levelled toward the game itself (forgetting the technical issues) are warranted. If you consume the game in bursts you will likely not grow weary of the myriad gameplay beats and eke out many hours of Bat-joy.   Definitely a must-play for fans of the Arkham series.

**Note: If there was an “Indifferent-thumb” icon, I would have given it a hard press**  Endorsement: “Great for Newcomers. But indifferent for returning fans”  My experience with Arkham Knight on PC was vastly different from others, I hardly had any crashes or graphical hiccups. The real problem is that this game does not have a gratifying resolve, regardless of gameplay or story. It is just lukewarm. There is so much here that could have made it the best Batman-game on the market, but it is arranged so poorly that it resolves into being “just another” Arkham-style game.  Pro:  01) It’s another Arkham-style game** 02) The Batmobile is kinda fun 03) Harley Quinn’s “booty sequence” and well-designed V-cut top  Cons:  X1) It’s another Arkham-style game, but it gets outclassed by Shadow of Mordor in comparison.  X2) Scarecrow is supposed to be the Main Villain, but “you know who” and Emo-Kylo Ren’s twin brother hog the spotlight; but thank god because Scarecrow says “Fear” more than all of the Scooby-Doo-films combined in saying “Scooby-snacks” (and they’re synonymous)  X3) Everything is poorly arranged and feels jimmy-rigged together. Wasted characters and gameplay opportunities, 2nd-rate story arcs, not to mention the overuse of a unique concept (Batmobile) just render the game as “lukewarm”  X4) The underusing of Harley Quinn in this game is ludicrous. Rocksteady knows how to make micro-campaigns, a “Blood Dragon-esque” campaign for Harley Quinn-fans would have easily made shovel-loads of money and saved the game from its lukewarm reception  To Fellow Harley Quinn-enthusiasts:  Rocksteady made a big deal about our favorite psychiatrist in black & red tights being playable, but she is vastly underused to the point that I asked myself, “Why even give her a ‘Story Campaign’?” She is fun to play as in AR Challenges; but this is no Mega Man X’s ZERO Micro-campaign, rather a cheap, unfulfilling promise to many of us who want to play a Harley Quinn starred Action-game (even if it is a Micro-campaign)  Verdict: If you want to play another Arkham-style game, this is an option. It is no magnum opus like Arkham City or well-crafted experience like Shadow of Mordor. If this is your first Arkham-style game, you may love it; but to other fans of the genre it really is just indifferent when compared to the other titles

This is an OUTSTANDING Arkham game, but it comes with a very big IF...  ...If you can run it without issues. I was one of the lucky ones, I guess, as I was able to play the game on my system (MSi Dominator Pro GT60 2pe w/ 8GB Geforce GTX880M and 24GB RAM) from day one and did not have any of the issues that others had (though I did have to turn off the smoke physics and debris physics to get playable framerates). A lot of people did not have such luck, and so this game has rightly got a lot of negativity.  But, if it does run well enough on your machine, then you are in for a treat, because this is a great continuation and completion of the Arkham games saga. Batman still batmans like a BATMAN! BECAUSE HE'S BATMAN! The fighting is just as smooth and excellent as it was in Arkham City (and lacks whatever tweaks ruined the flow in Arkham Origins), the Batmobile, while overused, is a lot of fun. The story is great. The side missions are great. The Riddler stuff is tedious, but that's kind of expected at this point, and it has a pretty good pay-off in terms of the satisfaction of beating that jerk. ;)  So, yeah, I am recommending this game, but with that huge caveat: it may not run well on your system, and so you may end up having wasted your money. Only buy this if it is at a price point at which you don't feel it would be a waste if your machine can't handle it now (and don't buy it all if you don't ever expect to have a machine that can play it well). Or maybe consider getting the console version (though if you are like me, you may prefer playing Arkham games with kb/m) which is at least guaranteed to run.  But, if you do get it, and it does run on your machine, then you are in for a treat. :)

This game truly ends the Arkham series on a great high note. The graphics and mechanics were as great as I was expecting and even a little more with the seemingly ability to do anything you wanted as the batman.   I have heard of many reports of glitches and errors however the only ones I found were ones already present in the other games (e.g. bodies merging with walls). I also did not experience any crashes or frame drops using the batmobile.  The batmobile felt amazing to me to use and fluent to drive. The ability to switch from pursuit and attack mode so easily was great. I was expecting the batmobile to be a cheap gimmick to boost sales of the game however, I found my self driving more than actually flying as I was having so much fun with the car. The fight sequences in the car were also great and I felt I won off pure skill.   The combat system in this game was just amazing. Being able to just move so much more fluent was so amazing. What also made things great was the increase of special takedowns (Batmobile and enviromental). These made the game fell really fluent but as well make it look really cool. I believe its hard to deny the fighting in each game gets better with ever new release (including Origins), it just makes me sad this is the end of the series. Some of my favourite combat moments were with companions which to me made it feel even more fluent but as well made it look so cool. They truly did much better than expected with that mechanic.   Spoiler Warning:  The story for me was great in how it presented batman in the continuing struggle between himself and joker. I really enjoyed flying around the city to find the joker sitting and monologuing about something. The ending of the campaign where you run around as joker in a destroyed world that was great and was an absolute find screw at the same time. Ultimately, the story was great with nice little easter eggs from preivous games scattered around the place. My only negative part of the story was with how they dealt with deathstroke. That was soooooo dissapointing. It was so anti-climatic when all it took to take out deathstroke was to destroy the tank. Here was the game creator's chance to redeem themselves of deathstrokes poor portrayl in origins and they just made it into a crappy side quest. The fight sequence should have been the most over the top destruction fest where it truly felt like there was a lot at stake.   Ultimately I thought this game was epicly compelling, visually, mechanily and story-whise. The game compelled me to go back and play the older titles and to play it over and over again.
