I didn't like this very much.  Technically, it was fine in my experience. I ran it with an overclocked Radeon HD 7850 with 1 GB VRAM and 8 GB RAM, which should not be sufficient by a long shot seen the official system requirements. But it ran smoothly at around 30 FPS at 1920x1080 Resolution and Graphics mostly on Low, but Textures on Medium (which officially requires 3 GB VRAM!). I didn't have any issues. So in my experience, the game is technically rather solid (at least as long as you are okay with 30 FPS, which I am).  Now to the Game itself: The parts where you're running and flying around and doing things without the Batmobile are as good as they ever were, and the level design sometimes was really good. However, I found the formula getting a bit stale at this point after having played all the three other games, but then again, this is a sequel and I guess I cannot expect too much innovation.  Then there are the Batmobile tank fights and Batmobile stealth sections. Driving itself feels fine, and fighting and predator stuff seemed fun at first, but got repetitive and annoying pretty quickly. And all this is so out of character: Batman driving a Tank, shooting at people, cars and tanks and wrecking the city (regardless of the fact that some shy elves seemed to rebuild everything after Destruction-Batman left the scene). They had a big part in me finding the atmosphere lacking in this game compared to its predecessors.  The story and storytelling and characters aren't very inspired either, to say the least.   I found the story inane, implausible and forgettable.  They tried to tell a more personal story, but it lacked heart. This Batman is one of the most ridiculous over the top bad4ss Batmans ever that even 'All Star Batman'-Frank Miller would be ashamed of it. This Batman hardly ever shows any emotion. Though the whole story is about loss and family and the need to rely and trust others etc., it left me cold. Batman seems just so emotionless, full of himself and odious even to the people he is supposed to like.   The villains I found bland, especially compared to the other Arkham games. No real bossfight anywhere in the game's main story, although I have to admit that I liked the final confrontation with the Arkham Knight. It just isn't a real boss fight either. I am absolutely happy not to have a bossfight, but in a Batman game with clear villains, this seemed very anticlimactic.  So story-wise, this is the worst Batman game in my opinion, all grandiosity and spectacle and no heart.  I also felt like it had less 'Batman atmosphere', at least compared to Arkham Asylum, which is my favorite anyway.  Of the few side missions I played, some seemed good, but the majority I found rather to be repetitive busywork. I dislike that they didn't really feel optional like in the predecessors, as Alfred constantly bullied to please do some of the side-missions 'the developers worked so hard to put all that open world Ubisoft crap in there so please Please PLEASE play that, why wouldn't you now Master Bruce?'; and more importantly because you have to complete quite a considerable part of them to 'finish' the game in the sense of playing until you see the credits roll and have a satisfying conclusion. No thanks.  Despite all this critism, fun can still be had in this game, as the core mechanics still work and are fun, and all the other things that made the predecessors good games are mostly still here, but on the other hand they often feel like they are overstaying their welcome. But ultimately, there are in my opinion too many weak and annoying parts to recommend Arkham Knight. For me, this was not worth the time I invested in it.

I'll level with you. Batman: Arkham Knight was the game I've been waiting for for the last several years. I have a great deal of love for the previous games in the franchise. I was absolutely amazed by the story of Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. As a rampant fan of the 1990's animated series and a well read reader of the comics, I saw and recognized all the little easter eggs and story elements that the Arkham games had drawn from. I am the core demographic that the game was marketed towards. So when the PC port of Arkham Knight released this morning in absolutely abysmal shape, I was more than a little upset. I spent over twelve hours trying to resolve issues ranging from broken Xbox One Controller support to stuttering performance to hard crashes within the first few seconds of the game. I never advanced into the story any more than that.  What little I could explore in the game, including the game's graphics options and PC benchmark stress test demo, told me just how poor of a port this game was. At least on the PC. The benchmark frame rate lingered in the low 20's even on the lowest graphics settings on my pretty respectable SLI gaming rig. And when I went to change those graphics settings, I found the options very much lacking. There are only a few changeable settings including little more than resolution, texture quality, and shadow density. The rest of the settings were entirely nVidia GameWorks and Physx settings.  To make matters worse, the game's benchmark showed headache-inducing levels of motion blur, film grain filters, and depth-of-field effects that are completely unchangeable in-game. To turn them off, you have to quit the game and go into the game's installation folder, and manually edit the game's .ini file.  I was in shock. Arkham City had all of these settings in the in-game menu years ago. This is 2015. I couldn't believe Rocksteady had devolved so much in their historically stellar PC support.  Then I saw a developer post on the game's official forums admitting that the PC port of the game was handled 'by an external PC development partner'. Turns out Rocksteady didn't handle the PC port of the game at all.  Now... I consider myself an avid gamer. I'm well aware that day one PC releases are just expected to be broken until a few patches iron out things. But... This goes even further. The game performs so poorly on my high-end gaming rig that I am SERIOUSLY considering returning the game and boycotting it out of principle. I never do that, and it guts me to even consider doing that to my most anticipated game of the year... But the way WB handled this... It's just so... disgusting.  In truth, the more research I do in my quest to find out what happened with the development process of Arkham Knight, it became more and more obvious that Warner Bros. Studios had a heavy hand involved with the development cycle of the game. I'm not sure the blame can actually be placed on the Rocksteady developers for this one. It looks more and more like the majority of the issues with the game are from the involvement of external sources.    Verdict: Do not buy this game until the issues are fixed.

TL:DR is the game is good enough to warrant a purcahse if you think you can run it and if you enjoyed the previous entries.  So let's get the obvious out of the way - this game had an utterly unforgivable launch. I will not buy from Rocksteady again. The only reason I had to purchase this game was the investment I had in the universe itself.   NEGATIVES: - Tank warfare... Like really? Weak. - Major boss fights end up being car fights, utterly ridiculous. - Performance issues, regularly skips frames - They ruined freeflow and combat in general. By adding ridiculous amounts of enemies who you can't just up and attack, they make maintaining flow almost impossible. On top of this, the prioritizing for which enemies you attack (i.e. the game assumes I intend to instant takedown a brute instead of an unarmed goon) is also botched. I will try to disarm and destroy a shield and end up attacking someone with a baseball bat. Just in general, the combat has taken a huge step down in playability, enjoyability, and flow. - FEAR takedowns are way too important. I get it, Batman has a new gimmick. Don't make it a necessity for stealth. - Instead of locking a Riddler cutscene to his quest line, the actual story's conclusion in its entirety is locked until you 100% all the default missions. Including 240 riddler trophies... - DLC is very short, but because I bought this so long after release, I felt the lower price was fair.  POSITIVES: + Still an Arkham game. The story, as botched as the intro is, ends up being fairly fun. It's no where near as good as City or Asylum, however. + Batcomputer data is fun to read, even though it isn't as extensive as City's batcomputer data. + The batmobile is actually pretty fun. It's just not the right game or universe for the kind of combat they shoehorned in. + Voice acting is, for the most part, on par with the other games. It's not phenomenal, but it doesn't distract. + The batmobile riddles are mostly pretty good. Some are cheap as hell though. I spent twenty minutes working on a riddle only to discover I needed an upgrade that is unmarked and unmentioned by anything, and you only get it by doing certain riddles - but that's not enough for me to consider them all bad. + You can play, provided you have the DLC, as a lot of characters in AR mode (new challenge mode) + Dual team combat is a blast. I wish they had focused more on this than FEAR and batmobile combat. They could have made the game co-op with a little more work. + Graphics are superb when the game isn't dropping frames + Satisfying ending mission, use youtube for final cutscene (which is less satisfying to the point of being frustrating)  All in all... Lots of mixed elements here. Overall I think I got my money's worth, but I'm really invested in the franchise. For someone who just wants to play an Arkham game, I suggest City.

This game is awesome. I dont know why this game gets so much hate, It is fun and interesting and is on par with Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. Batmobile adds some cool mechanics to the gameplay and story. The game was running very smooth on my rig. Will describe what PC i have and what game settings i've used, maybe it will help someone. So, my rig: CPU: i7-2600k@4GHz; GPU: MSI GTX970 Armor; RAM: 12Gigs DDR3@2133MHz HDD: 9 years old (!)Western Digital HDD with 7200 RPM; OS: Windows 7 pro 64-bit.   I started to play game version downloaded on 9th of November. Please note that i closed all background programs except Steam and BAK. (You want to play this game smooth? Pls close Pronhub and Youtube and torrents, guys c'mon!) I ran this game on Nvidia driver v.355.82 (not last) and havent messed with .ini file or third-party tweak programs for BAK. Game settings i've used: Resolution:1980x1080 V-sync: OFF Max FPS: 90 Texture Resolution: High Shadow Quality: High Level of Detail: High Film Grain: OFF Texture Filtering: Anisotropic 16x Anti-aliasing: off (without it i have 78-110 fps all the time, so just experiment with it) Motion Blur: OFF (who need dat s h i t anyway?) Chromatic Abberation: ON Interactive Smoke: OFF Paper Debris: OFF (these two are causing the most stuttering) Enhanced rain: ON Enhacned Light Shafts: ON.   I've noticed that stuttering in this game was caued by Smoke and paper debris! Turn them off and you good to go! Also note that for some weird reason forcing Anisotropic Filtering from Nvidia Control Panel also caused some stuttering (for me anyway) so try experimenting with it or set it to 'Application Controlled' as i do for this game. Also set Power Consumption in NVCP to 'Max Perfomance' isntead of 'Adaptive'. It also helps.   So with PC and game and system settings mentioned above i got no CTD, almost no stuttering at all (once or twice after 3 hours of gameplay and it quickly vanished) and trully great game experience. I hope this helps.   Batman Arkham fans will LOVE this game.  10/10 Will ask about DETONATOR again!

Despite its problems, this game isn't as bad as most of the internet claims it is. I remember reading it ran like crap on high-end computers yet with my GTX 980 and now aging i7-930 it did just fine at 1440p, running at a buttery smooth cinematic console-level 30FPS... Despite that it only crashed twice, which I attribute to upgrading to Windows 10 since the game was fine after I reinstalled it, and I never got forever stuck in a Riddler room like in the sad excuse of a game, Batman Arkham Origins. And thank Joker that this is not Arkham Origins.  Was it worthy of a 'last hurrah' of the Batman series? The launch said no. Still I only had major lag related with smoke effects, and that's fixed by turning them off in the Gameworks settings. I had the rest of Nvidia Gamework's options on, and recorded a lot of the game with Fraps, and still had no lag for 90% of the game.  Now onto the actual game. $40 DLC is a ridiculous price for the content they so far haven't released. The graphics are stunning, the cutscenes are smooth and the animations are great. The gameplay and combat is just as good as previous Batman games, although I always missed counters in this one, and the puzzles are even better than before. The side missions are disturbing and the main story is long and completely comic-book worthy. The enemies sound great, the events feel like Batman, and the game is in general just awesome. I had a lot of fun, and although it's not everything it should have been from the beginning, it's much better than Origins and still gets a recommend from me. Of the seires it's become my favorite, with City being second, Asylum being third, and Origins being so dead last I wouldn't put it on the list. In fact let's pretend Origins doesn't exist.  I would probably wait until they fix all the issues on PC before buying, if they ever do, or get it on a console if you have one.

I've finally completed 100% of the game and unlocked the true ending. Did I enjoy it? You bet!  I've played all of the Arkham Games and I, like many others, wasn't too happy with Origins. Rocksteady is back at the helm for this game and it's GOOD. RS wrote a great story line with excellent scripts for the entire cast. The story is is the best out of all the games in the series and while you definitely expect certain events to happen before they actually do happen the orchestration of the events make you enjoy every second of the story.  Something about Origins' fighting gameplay always felt off to me. Like the beat of a song being screwed up. RS has implemented their trusted combat controls and controlling Batman is as fluid as it was before. Major Batman villains are worked into the story in a non-forced manner and create a fun filler experience during the main story or after you complete the main story to activate the ending. If there's one bad thing there it's that you NEED to do those side-quests to activate one ending. And then you need to 100% the game (including Riddler Trophies) for the true ending. Seriously? Collect all Riddler trophies? I've done it just to do it and I hated every minute of it. I think I spend 10-15 hours on those damn things alone. I felt like Rocksteady spread my cheeks and forced those effing trophies into my happy, carefree world when they stripped me of my trophy virginity. I fear I cannot play any of the other Arkham games ever again without shedding a tear if I see another green '?'. So spare yourself the misery and just look up the true ending on YouTube instead.  The Batmobile is a forced addition into the game and it's a little overdone, but not to the point of boredom. I also feel that the Batmobile sequences are done very well and tight controls make it extremely rewarding when you're up against seemingly impossible odds. It's BATMAN after all! There were one or two times when I was extremely frustrated by a seemingly impossible task, but once I did complete the mission it was one of the most rewarding events in my gaming history. Kinda like when you beat Ganondorf for the first time but without the confusion that followed.  Graphics look great even on Medium settings. It certainly looks as good or better than Origins. I have 2 780 Ti's (not that it matters because this game doesn't support SLI) and I can play on 5900x1080 on medium settings. That's not as good as I'd hoped but still much better than how it was at launch, apparently. If you have SLI cards change the game to be in windowed mode without borders. Somehow it just runs better that way than in fullscreen mode even though it looks exactly the same.  52 hours in, 100% completion, am I going to play NG+? You bet I am. I can't wait to go through the story again. It's that good. Thank goodness the Riddler trophies carry over *shudder*.

It's gonna be very hard to be objective about this one, so I won't try to separate my review into positive and negative observations.  I'm gonna cut the suspense; Don't buy this game in its current state, because the optimisation, or lack of optimisation and its performance issues are unacceptable. It's one of the worst ports ever seen, and most importantly, this kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t must stop.   Did I enjoy Arkham Knight? Absolutely. It's more of the same thing, in a polished version.The designs are very good, with some debatable choices for some characters, notably the Batsuit, or Penguin, but I personally found every choice really enjoyable. Gotham feels like it always should have felt; Dark, sexy, ancient and mysterious.   The gameplay is a bliss; I really liked the inclusion of the Batmobile. I loved the driving sensations, I liked the tank battles, I liked the puzzles using it, and I liked how it helped the navigation into Gotham to feel smoother, with enhanced gliding sensations as well.   Batman feels more powerful and has more possibilities than ever, with really fun combat and a predator system which feels great and refreshing with more agressive enemies, more restrictive gadgets.Not that you will feel real difficulty while playing the game, especially if you already played the previous installments in the series.  The story is more enjoyable than the Arkham City ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, but it lacks depth, is filled with plot holes, and while it has its fan service moments, with notably one character which presence made me smile a lot, what saves it from being sucked into oblivion is its very good presentation and directing.  There are of course some sidequests appart from the main story. While some of them, focusing on interesting villains, are really enjoyable, some others felt redundant and useless. And there comes my second point preventing me to recommend this game; THIS GAME IS NOT FINISHED.  There's not really any challenge maps, with only eight to ten dedicated to combat AND stealth. While you can play other really fun characters during the story, with a neat dual play system, you can't select these characters for the challenge maps. There's barely any content in the main free roam mode, with four to five interesting sidequests, the rest being boring generic and repetitive missions, mostly the mandatory Riddler challenges, which are smore frustrating and tedious than ever ;  The strategy of Warner Bros and Rocksteady are to give content for the next six months, content like new characters to play and new sidequests, which you would gain by paying 40 euros for the season pass.  And this is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.   Selling a poorly optimized and unfinished game to fans is not something I can accept, and for that I can't recommend Arkham Knight. Which is a shame because it is a fun game, but for now, it is an alpha, and I would say that even if there wasn't any technical issues. I loved it, but wait a year for its GOTY, or buy it at a low price on other sites. In any case, wait for a patch.   Oh, and ♥♥♥♥ YOU Warner Bros games for being an evil and greedy corporation with no respect for its customers, and ♥♥♥♥ YOU Rocksteady for not being able to not sell your soul.

TL,DR: If you're computer is solid and you like Batman or enjoyed any of the other Arkham games, you should really buy this. Turn down some of the more intense settings like physx or enhanced light shafts, and you should be good to go.   Let me start by saying I work with computers and i built my own computer (core i7-4790k and gtx970, 16gb ram).  I know lots of people are having trouble running this game. When i first started it up, i checked online for optimal settings (i believe the game runs Unreal engine so it should be tweakable). I ended up using a tweaker, Batman Tweak Tool (google it, its on steam forums) to make sure the most intensive options were disabled for smooth gameplay. I did notice a tiny slowdown in tank fights later in my game, i also did happen to update my video drivers and windows 10 (1511 update) the day before, so that might have changed something.  Running the game aside, i love this game. LOVE IT. After 20+ hours of playing through and beating the main story (working on completionist stuff at this point), i would have to say this is the BEST arkham game ever. In fact this is one of the best games i have ever played, period. The side stories are all fleshed out, the main story is really good, the game has a solid atmosphere (although every once in a while the radio chatter can get annoying, like if you go near any car, there is a criminial going 'oh no its batman, floor it!'). For about half the game, i had my dad watching me play. He doesnt really like video games but even he was into the story and puzzles. Overall, the game is pretty much everything you could want from an Arkham game. Well, i think ive said enough, time for me to go solve some Riddles :P

My GTX 960 does pretty for the most part.  Aside from all the controversy regarding its release and the performance for many people, I think this very well may just be the most polished game in the Arkham series. The story is back up there in quality with Arkham Asylum, which is commonly lauded for its tightly-woven story. The combat and stealth are, I believe, the superior iterations compared to other games in the series. Fear multitakedowns are really satisfying. Gotham feels like a believable world, for the most part. The atmosphere of the overall game is really well-done.  Then there's the whole batmobile thing.  I liked the batmobile. Once you get used to how it handles, it's real fun to use. I think they did a good job bringing the batmobile into the game technically speaking (and ignoring things like framerate drops). My main issue with the batmobile was how prevalent it was in the core gameplay of the game. It felt like every 5 seconds the developers were trying to shove the damn thing down your throat because they were so proud of what they made, which got kind of obnoxious. Things that didn't need a batmobile section got a batmobile section. The vehicle combat was fun, but got really exhausting towards the end of the campaign. The whole thing was definitely a little overplayed.  Also, everything being destructible, while INCREDIBLY entertaining and super cool, seemed a little out of character for Batman. I thought it was a little odd.  That said, I'd recommend the game to those who are willing to risk seeing whether or not it works on your system. If you're a fan of the Arkham series then this game is definitely a must-play. It's a shame the release of this game went the way it did because it really is a great game.

I promise I'll give you the most honest review of a game series I love, summarised the best I can.   Let's start with   Performance  , the one concern most people, even myself were/are curious about. It doesn't perform consistently well, you'll get plenty of good averaging FPS but there are times it drops at the least demanding scenarios. It's certainly playable but it will never be truly fixed or great.   6/10 Performance  .  Gameplay: It remains relatively similar to previous titles, there are a few additions to provide variations to the usual gameplay style.   Story: Great, except the Boss Battles.     Predator scenarios include a range of different mechanics now, be it to yourself like Fear Takedowns or enemies who have devices to detect your location if you use Detective Mode. It provides a increased challenge to the game, something which I personally enjoy, the predator scenarios dont always play out the same.      Combat has seen the addition of tag teams with Robin/NightWing/Catwoman, remains all good.     Then there is the Batmobile.  The emphasis on the Batmobile, it clouds a large portion of the game, the story/game is over 60-70% Batmobile? I enjoy racing about the Gotham but every other mission was blow these tanks up, avoid these Cobra tanks (♥♥♥♥ THOSE). I didn't mind using the Batmobile to get out of particular sitatuions etc but man it was just TOO MUCH imo.   I can't recommend a game which is still buried with bugs, performance issues, or call it 'BatMobile Arkham Tank' if you will.    tl;dr - If you can deal with the various Bugs, over use of Batmobile, inconsistent performance, Get it on Sale. £10 or less.

I am huge fan of the Arkham series, and my expectations were high for this final chapter in the series. Sadly, this game is a mixed bag. Luckily there is more good than bad here, but the bad can be very frustrating.   I hate most of the Riddler segments. Didn't we take him down three times already? He was not needed here. The Batmobile felt out of place. I play these games to soar from rooftops and punch criminals in their faces, not to drive. The tank segments were sometimes fun, but not fun enough to justify forcing us to drive.  Other than that, a lot of what makes these games fun is intact and better here. The graphics, story, voice acting, combat, gadgets, and overall sense of being Batman are in full effect. The combat is especially tight and responsive, which is nice after the less than perfect Arkham Origins. The way the story cleverly explores the mind of Batman is brilliant.  Arkham Knight is a flawed but fine ending to the excellent Arkham series. Hopefully this won't be the last time we don the cape.

Another epic trilogy is over. First Nolan's, now Arkham. And both of them managed to raise the dark knight to unbelievable heights. Unlike the movie, the game literally makes you 'be the Batman', experience the struggle of a fearless vigilante against the largest gangland the world has ever seen. In the finale of the Arkham trilogy Rocksteady studios play their last card and remind us that, first of all, a world famous superhero is...a simple human being like you and I, when, inspite of everything, no matter how strong you are, your heart and the ability to feel will crush even the unbreakable ones. This time Batman's humanity is exposed to everyone. We've never seen the mighty night cry, doubt or blame himself. We've never seen him weak or suffering, let alone feeling sorry for him. One night will turn his world upside down and make us, the players, worry about the unstoppable, as we thought before, icon of the world culture. To my mind, Rocksteady studios were able to create not only the best game about Batman but the best superhero game ever. After all there is no better way to know what it feels like to be a superhero...because the dark knight, a human, is the closest one to you or me. Not a mutant, not a god or a bitten by genetically raised spider student from Marvel's universe. 'Be the Batman'. Anyone can be the batman.That's the whole idea of the dark knight. No matter who behind the mask is. What matters is what kind of person you are. I don' know what Affleck will do with Batman and I don't really care because for me everything great that could happen to my favorite character has already happened. These two trilogies is the summit of the dark knight's glory. Applause. Curtains down.

Before I begin my review let me clarify a couple things first. When this game originally released I did not own my PC so I did not experience first hand the bugs that occured for many users when the game was first released. I will admit that even though I love the Arkham series (and mostly anything with Batman), I was hesitant to buy the game. However, once I built my new PC I was looking for games, and this one piqued my interest.  To get to the point; I LOVE THIS GAME! I have yet to expeience any crashes/bugs/glitches which is always a plus coming from a game that was initially littered with them. I can play on maximum graphical settings at 60fps, and I only get noticeable framedrops when there is alot going on the screen (racing the Batmobile in Gotham).   PROS:  - Great Story: It is really hard for me to decide which of the Arkham games have the best story, but good golly Batman, this one was suspensful! - Great Aesthetics: The graphics on ultra settings are amazing, and great environmental design. - Character Models: Definitely the best of the Arkham series by far, especially Catwoman's which is waaay better than Arkham City. And, the alternate costumes actually appear in the cutscenes. Finally! - Familiar gameplay with added mechanics: I was able to jump right in and pick up where I left off from the other games, which is nice, and the takedowns are just as satisfying as ever. - Voice Acting: Great voice acting.   CONS: - No Open-World for Other Characters: There is a mod for this (which I use), however it would be nice to have this in the game without needing a mod. - Very Little Replayability: Not that the other Arkham games had this once you tackle all the other challenges, but this game does lack the Predator and Combo maps that I used to love/hate in the previous iterations. I just bought the season pass, so maybe that will keep it going, but I ahte having to spend more money on games just to make them better. - Not enough dual combat encounters: I may be being a little picky here, but I think Rocksteady missed a great opportunity to allow Batman and Robin to fight crime in the city side by side! Playing as both characters in the open world would be so sick, but alas you must buy the DLC which comes with a few 'challenge maps'.  No Category: - The Ending: While a think that the ending was a good ending that fit the story, it really left me wanting more, and wanting to see how they other characters continued to live on. - DLC: Immediately I bought the 1989 pack. Those models for the costume and the Batmobile are incredible. If I were to reccomend the packs to purchase however, I would say only buy the Season of Infamy, the Matter of Family, and the Red Hood/Harley Quinn packs. Honestly, the other character 'episodes' were lacking. As far as costume go, they are all fantastic and I would highly reccomend them, but I'm sure that people would prefer to pick and choose. (But for the love of god, bring back the BTAS one! D:)  Final verdict: For me it was worth the $50 I spent. The season pass maybe not so much, but if you are debating whether to get this, just wait for a Steam sale and pick it up, because this game is great. I have a single GPU, and I have heard that those running SLI are the users experiencing performance issues. I cannot confirm this since I am not running SLI, please consult with a review that is running SLI before you buy if necessary. Also, there is a banchmark video for this game on Youtube which is running on a machine with my specs so I also highly reccomend watching that.  My PC Specs (for others convenience): - AMD FX-8320 (Clocked at 3.5GHz, no OC yet) - Cooler Master Hyper EVO 212 CPU fan (never seen it reach more than 50*C) - EVGA GTX 960 [4GB VRAM] - 16GB DDR3 1600 RAM - Samsung EVO 850 250GB SSD - 1TB Western Digital Blue HDD (Installed game on this one accidently) - ASUS Sabertooth 990FX R2.0 MOBO - Other items that are not relevant to this game experince :P

So yes. Batman Arkham Knight had a horrendous launch. So bad that it was pulled from STEAM so the developers can work on it. I experienced one crash so far but with the 6 hours of gameplay, that was about it. No other hiccups. No BSOD's. No other errors. My fingers are still crossed but so far so good.  As for the game itself. It remains true to the previous Batman titles. The fighting is still very fluid and controls perform well. Using the Batmobile is a nice touch to the series but feels a little 'arcady' at times. The story is also done very well. Of course your main goals are to stop Scarecrow and the new Arkham Knight, but the side missions they included make it enough to not make it feel too linear.  The graphics are absolutely beautiful. The level of detail on the characters are amazing. And the city has a very dark, gritty feel to it.   Im not a huge Batman fan but the Arkham games do manage to draw my attention and keep it. Numerous times in the game you really do feel like the Dark Knight. Whether it is being a detective and solving puzzles or being stealthy and taking out enemies.   So despite the abysmal launch. I can attest that most of the issues have been ironed out (at least in my experience). SO I say give it a try. WARNING - SPOILERS AHEAD:   This was a hard thing to write about as there has already been so much said about this game. I have absolutely loved the Arkham series as a whole, but even still, Arkham Knight was ultimately a bit of a disappointment for me. I won't go into the whole bit about the dismal PC port - that's been talked about to death. I think it was simply a title where Rocksteady really strove for something - a certain game direction/goal - and yet didn't quite make it. Despite some absolutely brilliant pros, the cons simply couldn't be overcome, so let's do those first:   CONS:    1. Rocksteady really doubled down on the Batmobile. Granted a lot of folks asked for the car but the problem is, I just didn't find it *fun* to drive. In fact, it was very hard to control and I think my Batman not only killed 500 people, but ended up destroying hundreds of millions of dollars worth of property as I couldn't stay on the damn road half the time ! Add in the bit where you had to use it for the absolutely horrid Riddler missions and upgrade it to take down certain villains and you end up with a car that turned into an essential character. I HATED that I felt it necessary to use my first few dozen upgrade points on the damn car in the hope that it might be less painful to drive. It was a cool design, but was much too integrated into gameplay.   2. Riddler. I've unlocked 100% of the Riddler trophies among all 4 games and I never EVER enjoyed them. I have obsessive compulsive disorder though and feel the NEED to do them. Roleplaying as Batman also means I can't cheat or let Eddie go free so I have to do them ALL. This game at least gave us much fewer trophies to hunt than before which was good, along with a few varieties (bomb guys, car races...grrrr), but I swear Eddie was more obnoxious than ever. I mean, how could you not do 100% just to shut him up and enjoy the satisfaction of punching him in his stupid face? The normal Most Wanted questline to save Catwoman was more than enough thanks, especially considering those *AWFUL, AWFUL* race tracks !   3. Story. I found the story very weak. It was easy to guess who the AK was and I was disappointed that the Scarecrow was not actually in the game very much. But overall, there were some truly obnoxious areas to play through like the Batmobile vs the Excavator area, the Batmobile vs the AK super tank and the Batmobile vs Deathstroke in HIS Supertank. The airships and underground areas were not very fun to play through either. I felt like the genreral story tempo was just 'off' - after you face AK and learn who he is, it felt like that was coming to the end - yet then there was suddenly MORE tank fights ahead (I can't tell you how discouraged I was to finally clear all the tanks, bombs and checkpoints - only to have them all reset after DS takes over). Soooo much recycled content.   4. Robin, Nightwing, Azrael and Catwoman - the gang was all herre, looking great and ready to help Batman at a time of greatest need, yet they were all woefully underused. And no, saying Bats wanted to protect them is just a cop out from not integrating them more into the story. I mean, Nightwing is insanely popular - GET HIM IN THERE ! Rocksteady seemingly did the impossible and made Robin kick-♥♥♥ and cool yet they then decided to stick him in a cell and use him as Bat-bait! The supporting cast deserved better.   5. Performances. Whoever voiced Gordon, Deathstroke and Two-face were terrible and I hate to say it, but Kevin Conroy's performance was wooden at best. No, I don't buy the whole 'Batman was sick' thing - he was monotone through the whole game and frequently pronounced words weirdly 'I have to get to Bris-Tol immediately !'.   6. No free roam. Seriously - fans have been asking for this for how long now? I know there are mods out there, but RS would win a lot of brownie points back from fans if they would simply let us roam around the beautiful city they created with the hero of our choice (and don't tell me it's not possible RS - there are mods out there that can do it easily enough - just give us something official please !  Pros:  1. It wasn't all bad. Rocksteady deserves to take a bow on their interpretation of Gotham City. I frankly loved Arkham Origins version as it was *really* dark and gothic with lots of room to roam around, but I have to give the edge to RS's version as the scope of it is brilliant and was the highlight of the game for me. It's true - part of the Batman mythos for me is swooping around the large cityscape canyons between skyscrapers and gothic buildings. The structures here are higher, the addition to the newer, modern buildings on Founders Isle are great, the industrial areas and the entire lower level areas mixed well with Chinatown and more traditional gothic structures. It was a joy to nosedive off the top of Wayne Tower and glide through the city while swooping onto cars, etc. The water and rain effects were wonderful too !   2. Performances - Mark Hamill and John Noble were both *outstanding*. My only regret with John was that I wish we had more of him. I understand that this was his first voice acting gig; I hope it is not his last. Mark really outdid himself though as Joker was a major, major highlight throughout the game. The song and dance number was the most entertaining part of the whole game for me ; ) Oracle, Robin, Nightwing, AK, Riddler, Penguin were all top-notch as well.   3. Combat and predator moves - just when I think they couldn't refine their combat system anymore, they go and prove me wrong. Additions such as medics and heavy weapons guys add to the challenge, as do gadgets such as the wonderful voice modulator. Dual-mode fighting was a lot of fun too. A shame the grapple gadget Batman stole from Deathstroke in Origins didn't make it into this game, that was the one thing I was missing.   4. Challenge modes are fun and varied.  In closing, this game was - for me at least - an admirable misfire. I applaud Rocksteady for having the ambition to put a lot of effort into building a massive city to explore and attempting to infuse a new style of gameplay into what is, granted, a very established franchise that is getting long in the tooth. But at this point in the franchise, there is no exscuse for a weak story and AK suffers from that. The new Batmobile gameplay was a major addition, yet it was not very entertaining (it was actually outright tedious and obnoxious at times - lookin' at you Riddler and Drone army). The PC technical issues undermined the whole experience with frequent crashes and weird graphical glitches. Sadly, I feel that will be the real legacy of this title, at least on PC; certainly not the story or gameplay and that's a real shame. All in all, not the worst game I ever played; if you decide to get it, I recommend making sure you're buying it on sale.

(Written before the big patch has been released.)  Quickie Review: It's overall enjoyable, but not worth getting at full price. SCORE: 5/10  Pros. -Good, but pales in comparison to its predecessors. Sits firmly in 3rd place, above Arkham Origins. -Plenty of new features and some expanded on (like detective work from Origins). -HUGE city to explore, with new or expanded ways to travel that's a blast. -It's fun as hell roaring around Gotham in the Batmobile. -Decent story, but very thin and disappointing. -One really great surprise that wasn't advertised. -Fantastic character and voice work, as always.  Cons: -Arkham Knight's identity is blatantly obvious if have any familiarity with Batman lore. -Scarecrow - who was advertised as the main villain - plays THIRD string to two other villains. Worse, he's barely in it, your encounters are minimal. Massive disappointment. -The final mission or 'boss' fight is a joke. It's hollow, completely story-driven, with no challenge. -Tank mode gets tedious very quickly. Its mechanics are nowhere near as deep as brawling or predator mode. -Do you like blowing up lots of drones and fighting endless hordes of soldiers? Like, 60-70% of the time? Then this is the game for you!  Let me start off with this: my thumbs up is despite the massive controversy on Arkham Knight's PC release. I made the mistake of pre-ordering it, even getting a big gaming PC after years of laptops. This was the game that made me decide whether to go PS4 or PC. And honestly, there weren't (and still aren't) enough console excluvies on the PS4 that interested me enough to warrant getting it. Not when I can use my Steam backlog and get games ridiculously cheap.  But honestly, despite those problems, I find myself agreeing with many reviewers who gave it scores like 6 or 7/10. It's a massive disappointment after the hype. I regret pre-ordering it and paying full price for it. I would've said that even if I bought it on PS4.  THE STORY & CHARACTERS  The story feels paper thin compared to previous games. There are few twists or turns in the game and fewer villain encounters in the main part of the story. Most villains are disappointingly stuffed into side missions. Worse, game's big mystery - the Arkham Knight's identity - is so blatantly obvious from the first line he utters, that by the time he's finally revealed, the game is nearly over and it's pretty much meaningless. There's a third villain along with Scarecrow and Arkham Knight who plays a major role in the game. Without spoiling it, they appear most often through the game, stealing the spotlight from the two villains who SHOULD have been the focus. Scarecrow especially gets the short stick, relegated mostly to taunting you on the city's big screens, overusing the word 'fear' in his speeches. The final mission isn't even a mission or a boss fight. It's an unchallenging, story-driven walking simulator for the most part.  Where Rocksteady excels, though, is the characters and voice work. Kevin Conroy always knocks it out of the park as Batman and everyone else shines as usual. Although, while I enjoyed John Noble's Scarecrow in this game, he's kind of ho-hum for what I expected. Almost all his lines are fear this or scare that. It gets old very fast. One surprise return - and the voice actor - is a constant pleasure.  BOSS BATTLES  This game's boss battles are by far the most disappointing. Compared to Asylum, City, and even Origins, there are absolutely no good boss battles. All those villains in the side-missions? Most of them, you encounter three or four times, doing the exact same thing every time before they get away. Few of them even get a good, satisfying final battle. The final encounter with The Riddler is kind of fun, but it drags on and isn't very challenging. In terms of boss battles alone, Arkham Knight stands in a very low last place compared to to the others.  THE GAMEPLAY  You'll spend the vast majority of the game fighting bland soldiers and especially battling tank drones. The game's biggest criticism was 'too much Batmobile' and they're right. The Batmobile is shoe-horned into nearly every aspect of the game. Riddler, for example, forces you to drive on race tracks, which goes ridiculously against his character and his previous challenges. Many puzzles require the Batmobile's tank mode to solve.  The tank battles? They're fun at first. At first. But the reason that brawling and predator mode were so much fun in prevoius games (and to be fair, in this game) is their depth. You have so many options to dispatch enemies that no encounter is ever the same. Not so with the tank battles. They become so formulaic and tedious - especially fighting the bigger drones you need to sneak behind to destroy - that you'll be sick of them by the third encounter.  Where the game is great is, as always, the brawling and predator modes. Like previous entries, there have been massive improvements to both modes, making it a constant treat to take down thugs and soldiers. Many new gadgets introduced in this game are fun, like the voice sythesizer. There's a new predator feature where you can take out half a dozen thugs in one fell swoop, which never got boring for me.  I also like some of other new features added to the game, like teaming up with other members of the Bat-Family. It adds a new dimension to the brawling and honestly, it wasn't used enough. I also think it could've been expanded on a little so every fight wasn't just 'build up special meter, do dual takedown, repeat.' I also think those dual takedowns should've given you the option to take out more than one thug at once.  The problem, though, is the overuse of the tank battles. They take such huge center stage that the brawling and predator modes get left to the wayside. It feels like the developers shoe-horned the tank elements into the game as much as possible. Which, as I said, gets old fast.  THE CITY  If there's one place the game excels - much like Arkham City - it's the city itself. Gotham never looked better and it's an absolute blast to traverse it. Gliding and grappling has improved since City. Now, when you launch yourself from a grapple shot, you can fly arond the city at speeds that even Superman might struggle to keep up. It's incredibly satisfying to zip and glide around the city. And while the Bat-Tank stuff gets old, I never got tired of rumbling around in the Batmobile. Some have complained about its lack of control, but I didn't have a problem with it.  One thing that I enjoyed greatly about the game was Rocksteady's use of the police station. You need to revisit it often for story purposes, side stuff, collecting, but it's fun to come back and see the cells slowly fill up with bad guys you've captured. It's especially satisfying seeing the super criminals slowly fill up one section of the station.   SIDE MISSIONS  As I said, most of the villains featured in the game are disappointing. They're fun to encounter at first, but every counter is exactly the same. Then there's hunting down the Arkham Knight's forces. Ugh. Trust me, you will get tired of the endless amount of side stuff to do there. They're all just so tedious and repetative. It's a major disappointment.  OVERALL  I know it sounds like I'm heavily criticizing the game. This was a major disappointment for me. This was supposed to be Rocksteady's big homerun. Instead, it ends as a low point on the game. Overall, I liked it. It's worth playing, but I don't recommend paying full price for it.

I don't often review games, nor do I typically like speaking bad about them. The fact that these words even exist is proof of how much this game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.  TL;DR: Do not buy this game for PC. Better on console but even then still buggy. Really disapointed.  Anyway, my story. I was a pre-order of this game, I downloaded day one and tried to start playing. Those of us that remember what that was like, will remember the agony and disappointment. But I knew the problems that the game had, I also knew what a .ini file was. A couple notepad edits later, the game was fixed.  I have no idea why this worked for me, or how. Might have just been my system, or good modifications to the right file. But it was running at a solid 120 FPS and most settings were turned up to high (texture detail was lowered to get rid of some screen tearing).  I loved the game, it was fun. Tank combat was a little out of place but I enjoyed it. One of the few I suppose. It still had a LOT of problems: texture popping, hit detection, combo keys not registering, not to mention stuttering, screen tearing, FPS drops, and Nvidia's additions screwing us AMD users over.  Anyway, I beat it a while back, and moved on. Until recently when all the DLC had come out, and I had a $20 steam code burning a hole in my pocket. So I bought the season pass. I started playing the new game plus. I realized that it was still kinda fun. Then the different realization. NOTHING had changed. My modifications to the .ini file had been overwritten by some of the updates so it ran like a monkey in a bat-diaper. Tank combat was still kinda nice. Combo keys (alt-# is terrible to use as combo's, especially when it takes the blood of a virgin on a blood moon to get them to trigger) were still broken.  When trying to make a person happy, you give them control. Too much control can make people feel overwhelmed, but some control is better than none. New Game plus (NG+ from now on) was going fine. Until I got trapped in a corner repeatedly when special combos refused to execute (my usual virgin was out on buisness, moon was only a blue moon).  Could not change difficulty, could not reload save, could not reset NG+, unable to skip death cutscene (probably my biggest peve of them all, once or twice is alright, makes you madder I get that. However at the five mark it is just annoying)  Not exactly happy, then I noticed something else. Game crashes if you hit too many keys trying to find the key to skip death cutscene.  Thought I would try the Arkham episodes. Broken as the rest of it and even more frustrating (that catwoman robot fight 'boss' is absolute dolphin crap). And the default control hints for the Red Hood story pack were in Play station form.  This may seem like a rant of a frustrated casual. And in part it is, I mostly play the arkham games for story anyway. But when a developer promises support, fails to give it (I know what WB said to all the articles, at about half a year since launch, then it faded away) and then just moves on? Makes me hesitant about future games on the PC, let alone from WB or Rocksteady. Games SHOULDN'T launch buggy. You are not buying a complete product (like a kettle without a handle, I mean it will work but... not what you were looking for), you are buying some big wigs desire to get something released to the ravinous wallets (I was guilty of this, love me some batman, but pre-ordering is not a good thing, but that is another rant).  My point is, I gave you a chance to fix it, I gave you my faith. I have a pile of kettle code that compiles without a handle. And I have a request for a refund from steam (for the seasons pass). PC players are getting shafted of late with buggy console ports and rip-offs. I know we may not be as lucrative as we once were, but we are still a player base.  Don't release dolphin crap, train or release your monkeys, find a PC division and let them work on it with time and dedication (maybe not Iron Galaxy next time) they might produce something that is worth a buy.

I'm sure by now you all have experienced/seen/heard about all the technical bugs/glitches/performance issues. I'm not here to talk about that. The fact is Arkham Knight has to be one of the saddest games to grace my library. It's sad because you can see the developers writing themselves into a corner with the story, coming to feel over burdened to incorporate the batmobile into every thing you do, and trying to give you an experience that is far from what batman fans truly wanted. If they had focused on the story and characters more and not even bothered to put in the batmobile they could have focused their time and efforts on the story and performance.  SPOILER ALERT: Joker comes back and the experience with him has got to be the hands down THE GREATEST thing I've ever experienced in a batman game. From the world changing around you, to the joker popping up in places that made me fall out of my chair laughing, Mark Hamill delivers so much to this game. Honestly that's what we all want as batman fans. Nobody cares about the 'plot', it's just white noise to expereince the amazing characters, so to speak its the characters that drive every story line and if the devolopers had just realized this we could have had a great game. Let me be clear here: the overall story isn't good in my opinion. It's long and confusing, had me wondering why they put certain things in, and only had a few, though amazing, memorable moments unlike the past games. The Joker sub-story is what I'm saying made this game for me. SPOILER ALERT: I called the arkham knight being Jason Todd when he was announced. It was so obvious that the whole game I felt it was just a chore getting to the climax. It gets to a point where they beat it over your head that he is Jason. What I'm also trying to say is that Arkham Knight had the potential to be possibly the best batman villian. Imagine everything you have learned over the past 3 games being thwarted by an enemy that knows Batman to his core. They could have blended this psychological aspect with the Joker portion and just UH WHY DIDN'T THEY DO THIS. If they ever do a overhaul of the game completely rework the second half of the game. Instead of the Joker arch ending and the Scarecrow arch going on forever have batman stop the gas bomb, ♥♥♥♥ have the gas bomb go off first thing in the game, Batman and his crew are safe and they save the city but because of so much exposure ot the fear tocxin the Joker comes in DURING THE SECOND HALF AND THE ARKHAM KNIGHT PLAYS ON BATMANS FEAR OF BEING LIKE THE JOKER AND CMON HOW DID THEY NOT SEE THIS.  On the note of characters I have to say graphically I have never been more dissapointed. Honestly if they had just copy and pasted the models from Arkham City it would have been more enjoyable then playing as a gorilla batman, with his skinhead robin sidekick, and a preppy looking nightwing. Gameplay wise another aspect the developers should have focused on was the co-op sections of the game with catwoman, nightwing, and robin. That was all the inovation we needed.  In conclusion the little details really are what you should play this game for. They expanded to far and sacrificed the things that should have been given the most attention. Again I cannot tell you how amazing the joker section of this game is. If you are a huge batman/joker fan PLAY THIS GAME. I would like to mention the level designers did an AMAZING job creating Gotham City. They take in the Tim Burton style over the toppness mixed in with Christopher Nolans run down and grimy of the Dark Knight movies hats off to guys. The Harley Quinn DLC is worth mentioning as an amazing take on the character as a batman lore fan, though short I enjoyed it. Not really a review more like my thoughts and critiques but I hope it helps you on deciding to purchase this game if it ever gets back up on steam.

Despite the overwhelming prominence of game-breaking bugs and lag that was never actually patched, the story was also thoroughly bland and poorly planned, leading me to believe that very little effort was put into the final game of such a highly acclaimed and respected series in AAA gaming.  For me, the only fun part about the game was getting the notification that Steam planned to give full refunds to the game's original owners who got screwed over by Warner Bros.  Don't waste your time on this game; play one of the earlier games in the series like Batman: Arkham Asylum or Batman: Arkham City and save yourself the feelings of disappointment and unfulfillment brought on by this game.

When it finally works, Arkham Knight impresses immediately. The detail of the city is astonishing, the character models are amazing, and the overall feel of the city is just incredible. The addition of the batmobile is fantastic while in pursuit mode. Where things get rocky is the Batmobile’s battle mode. The gameplay with this feature is not bad. It just doesn’t feel like Batman, and it is used around every turn. The rest of the gameplay is pretty much what you would expect, more of the same but cooler, and refined to perfection. Gliding is more enjoyable than ever, and side quests are far more satisfying.  The story makes good on Scarecrow’s threats to bring out all of Batman’s worst fears for the world to see. As a result, as a character remarks later, Batman loses his “mystique” that he had in the asylum and arkham city. It effectively delves into Bruce Wayne’s psychology, and at times I even was worried that Bruce was losing his mind. This makes for an exciting plot that is routinely interrupted to make sure players check out the previously mentioned side quests. This keeps the tone uneven. These strange jumps in tone all culminate into an ending which leaves more questions than answers but leaves you thinking about it for hours to come.  It is very much a Batman Arkham game, and it certainly builds on its predecessor in mostly all of the right places. The graphics are amazing, but battle mode can be tiresome, and the ending leaves polarizing opinions as far as satisfaction. In spite of faults it is a superb game and well worth the hefty price.

Great game! I love the stealth aspect plus all the gadgets Batman has to play with. Be aware the PC version of the game locks even with the high-end hardware. I've heard EA Games will produce a fix for this issue in September 2015, why it will take that long is unknown to me. Another owner of the game published a temporary solution in the STEAM COMMUNITY to the problem. Once the game has started change the display to Windowed With Border mode. Alt-tab out and start TASK MANAGER, click the 'Processes' tab and locate and right click 'BatmanAK.exe', click 'Set Affinity' and remove the check mark from 'CPU 1, and CPU 2', click OK, alt-tab back to the game and change the display back to 'FULL SCREEN'. This has allowed me to play the game for hours althought it still locks up from time to time. The game is fun to play. If you like multi-tasking you will love this game since you have several missions going on at the same time. You will often find part of another mission that can be completed on your way to the location of your chosen mission. I recommend this game and the Season Pass.

This positive recommendation is hesitant. I have a lot I want to say about this game, but it can be summed up as: If you liked the other Arkham games, then whether or not you like this one will likely be dependent entirely on what you think of the Batmobile.  I personally don't enjoy the Batmobile all that much. I think it is reasonably well implemented, but it is the one part of the game that doesn't make me feel like I'm Batman. And when I think about replaying this game, it is due to Batmobile sections that I feel that I would rather replay Arkham City.  The rest of the game is overall well made, and I've been quite impressed with it. They've added a lot to combat, primarily through new enemy types and behaviors. While some of the additions take a while to get used to, for the most part I think they are good. I also like the environmental takedowns. Team-up combat is also pretty well implemented, and I like those sections a good bit as well.  There is a lot to like here, and my only major issue is I feel that the Batmobile has too much of a part, as I personally don't like it. If you do enjoy the Batmobile, then I imagine you'll enjoy this game tremendously.  I haven't commented on technical issues, as I seem to have mostly been spared them, and I think they'll get them ironed out anyway, so they don't have long-term relevance.

What a long and strange trip it’s been from Arkham Asylum to Arkham City, back into the past in Arkham Origins and now for the final confrontation in Arkham Knight.  Let me say that I bought AK after the game had been pulled from stores and was extensively patched. Right now I’m running the game at maximum, including all Nvidia options for rain, etc., which should tax my graphics card to its limits. The game runs mostly fine, however. Yes, there’s some few drops below 60 fps and some micro (or macro) stuttering every time you start the game and summon a certain automobile. No idea, must be assets loading. Sucks either way. Maybe this is remedied if you install this on an SSD. In any case, the game is more than playable right now. At least for me. The game is also just stunning, graphics wise. Gotham never looked better, though it’s hard to understand why the city apparently changed its layout 3 times…  Now, first and foremost, Arkham Knight is a good game all in all. It’s most likely even the best in the series, all considering. It’s not like Arkham Origins just a rehash of the previous game, it is improved (and sometimes made worse) in almost all aspects, so here goes:  Combat: The freeflow system has been further improved, animations are a bit smoother, the flow of combat is a bit better. However, the biggest issue I had with this game was the sometimes insane amount of enemies that get thrown at you, especially those invulnerable enemies that you have to dodge or stun or whatever. That alone wouldn’t be that bad, but the game’s camera does a VERY bad job at giving you enough overview to see exactly what’s going on. Is an enemy about to charge or fire upon you? Which enemy are you even targeting currently? And that’s another thing. One would assume that with 20 enemies present your character would attack the ones who don’t counter you, yet he likes to do that very often, which can literally mean your death when your character suddenly jumps out of view to attack a stun baton guy…Since you can only vaguely dictate which opponent to attack this is unforgivable and I can see this really having a negative effect on a higher difficulty level.  Gadgets: These are pretty much the same, but slimmed down a bit. You now access them via a radial menu instead of the d-pad, which really interrupts the flow of the game. There’s nothing really new here…sadly.  Batmobile: This is THE new feature in AK. You will be using the Batmobile a lot. In puzzles, in combat, in traversal…just about in every situation. You can even remote control it. The Batmobile is cool, but it a bit overused. Also at times it controls absolutely horribly…  Upgrades: The system has been improved in comparison to AC. Of course you also get to upgrade your Batmobile! Getting every upgrade will require you to 3-star all challenges and pretty much complete the game I’d say. I’ve had about 70% of the upgrades at the end of the game I think. They’re mostly not spectacular, but pretty neat.  Enemies: The game adds 3 new enemy types as far as hand to hand combat is concerned, if I remember correctly. There’s the drone commander, who steers a small drone that can detect you, a “big” gunner that can’t be taken out with a silent takedown, which adds a new element to predator missions, and a medic, who can revive fallen enemies. Apart from that there’s the new drone army, which you fight in your Batmobile. Basically 4 or 5 different sorts of tanks. Those tank fights are rather boring and get annoying pretty quickly…sadly.  Collectibles: Yes, Eddie’s back and he’s got a whopping 243 trophies, riddles, destructible objects, etc. in his arsenal. It’s going to take you ages to get them all, but at least the puzzle mechanisms are fresh and new. Too bad you still have to take out the “green” thugs to get more locations. I couldn’t bother. It’s just too much. The sad thing about this is that you not only need to collect EVERYTHING to actually fight the Riddler in this game, but to also unlock the “secret” and final ending…boooooooo. I mean it’s cool to have a reward for those soldiering through all those trophies, but something as essential as a secret ending that completely changes the ending of the game? Meh…  Challenges: These are unlocked during the story mode, but you need to also meet a certain requirement to actually play them, for example, dive for x meters or whatever. The challenges comprise of tutorials as well as combat, predator and batmobile missions, which you can 3-star for an upgrade point. These can also be unlocked and played from the main menu once you have unlocked them. The races are the real highlights here. Those are extremely cool and fun and involve our beloved Edward.  Skins: Once unlocked or purchased via DLC you can actually play as a different incarnation of Batman in the main game (I chose Batman of the Future I think…so edgy and works well with the Arkham Knight). There are also skins for the other playable characters as well as the Batmobile.  Main story: This quest line is epic, you can’t deny that. It’s got everything: drama, action, slow paced segments, more drama and an incredibly good ending. I won’t spoil anything. The Arkham Knight, however, kinda got on my nerves the further the game progressed since he is by far the weakest character in the game, at least later on. He’s just boring and petulant and not really a threat, which was kinda disappointing. He also repeats himself all the time and gets more and more angry…meh.  Side quests: There are quite a few side missions to complete, whether it’s to foil the Penguin or Two-Face, a cult preacher, a serial killer, etc. All of these missions are usually unlocked at a certain point in the game. Only the “destroy this, destroy that” missions I had to find myself more or less. The most intriguing story line is probably revolving around the Riddler, who captured poor poor Catwoman. This quest comprises of a series of riddles, challenges and races, however, Eddie will get on your nerves sooner or later. There’s only so much “herpa derpa, I’m smarter than you, you can never solve all my riddles” banter you can take…especially after having played all 4 games in a row…  Bosses: This is probably THE weakest part of the game, because it doesn’t involve a single boss fight. Yep, that’s right. Sorry to spoiler this, but I think it’s huge. “Boss fights” in AK consist of either a) AC side mission style with an endless number of minions and the boss fighting with the group, having a health bar…b) that boss being a big ♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who can only be damaged after hitting a few of the smaller minions and performing a “team takedown” or c) a tank battle. After the phenomenal boss fights of Arkham Asylum and Arkham City this is a REAL letdown…  Verdict: Good game with some improvements, but also some letdowns. Great story, good gameplay, fun elements, but a lack of diverse and interesting boss fights hurts it real bad. Get it for the conclusion of the epic storyline.  DLC: See individual story DLCs, since steam thinks this is already too long. Once again you can't change the difficulty in the DLCs...bummer. Have fun dying if you like to play on easy.

I had held off from getting the game at first, due to all the negative feedback. I decided to wait until it was fixed and put back on sale, only to hear of people still complaining of problems. But with WB offering a full refund, I decided to go ahead and bite the bullet, figuring the worst case scenario would be if it sucked and I got the refund, I could put it towards the purchase of Fallout 4.  Well guess what? It plays awesome! Yes, even the Batmobile! Combat and movement were silky-smooth, with nary a graphic hitch in sight. And I played it on my monitor's native resolution (1680x1050), which I think helped in the FPS department.  In case you're wondering about my specs, here they are:  Intel core i7 CPU (factory setting) nVidia GTX 970 8 Gb of Crucial Ballistix system RAM Windows 8.1 ASUS Sabretooth Z97 Mk 1 Motherboard  If your system is anything like mine, you should be golden. Although I suppose I should mention that you may want to run nVidia's GeForce Experience program to properly optimize your game. Interestingly enough, it does not enable the graphical bells and whistles like enhanced rain or interactive smoke. And I think that's where people may be encountering problems. But the game itself just looks so gorgeous as-is that I don't think you'll miss them.  As with Mortal Kombat X, it paid to hold off until things were fixed. But hopefully WB will learn their lesson from this after such a public debacle.  That having been said, at this point I think many of the complaints are coming from a small, vocal minority. Namely, either hardcore PC enthusiasts and tech-heads who have everything on their machines turned up to eleven, Windows 10 users complaining about the memory requirements, or - even worse - trolls just looking to kick WB when they're down 'for the lulz.' Given the current 'mixed' status the game has been receiving, that's a big step up from the 'mostly negative' status it had at first. And I feel that there's probably a silent majority for whom the game runs fine.  So, in closing, to those of you who have a rig like mine and running under the same OS, you ought to be fine. For those still complaining? To paraphrase Jay-Z, 'If you're having game troubles, I feel bad for you son. I've got 99 problems, but Batman ain't one!'

Short version: ...yeah, I think it's okay now.  Long version: Read on.  WARNING, HERE THERE BE SPOILERS  So I waited since day one for the patch, and now that I've gotten 100% on normal difficulty, I have to say: I had some problems with Arkham Knight, but it wasn't enough to keep me from liking it. Probably the last Warner Brothers game I'm picking up considering the big fiasco regarding this port, but at least it seems they took/are taking the time to address our grievances.  + The visuals are GORGEOUS, if the Youtube channel BatmanArkhamVideos is any indication (seriously, I envy them); the character animation in particular is wonderfully fluid and damn near lifelike, leagues ahead of the stiff mannequin-like motions in cutscenes in prior Arkham games. (Not that there aren't occasional oddities though.) + The combat and predator gameplay is just sublime, with lots of new tricks and twists added in (I had a blast with the Fear Takedowns, for instance). It's more difficult, but more satisfying IMO. + Very memorable side missions, especially the Perfect Crime one. + Great voice acting, not to mention Kevin Conroy stepping up his game after being so wooden in Arkham City. + Scarecrow is best villain. Like, really. Not to mention what he does in the finale proves he's worthy of being one of the A-listers in the Dark Knight's rogues gallery. I'm also glad that Hallucination!Joker, even with all his screentime, was kept somewhat to the sidelines plotwise, being an entirely internal conflict for Batman; the plot makes it clear that Scarecrow and Arkham Knight are the main threats in play here. + The Batmobile and Bat-Tank were decent enough. Though the tank is a bit...iffy in terms of lore, I can give that some leeway for the satisfying gameplay.  +/- Running this on my machine, I don't get 60fps that often, and the game lags sometimes (especially during car chases and going through places with tons of NPCs). But for me, it runs well and consistently so; with all that's happened regarding this port, that's really all I can ask for.  - The AR Challenges got old after a little while. I kind of miss the way the other games did it, featuring setpiece moments as replayable challenges. (Like, you could have the airship cargo hold as a combat challenge, or the last room in Arkham Knight HQ as a Predator challenge, for instance. But nope.) - Paul Dini isn't present, and it shows. The plot, while otherwise decent and has a spectacular finale, seems to rely too heavily on kidnappings to keep things moving along and gets a tad repetitive. - Arkham Knight's identity being obvious, of course, both in-game and out. And also not being an original character. (Technically, they were right in that it's a new IDENTITY, but...) - Azrael and Hush/The Identity Thief were utterly wasted, and we never got to see Jack Ryder as The Creeper. The hell?  Verdict: Uh...mixed feelings, but leaning towards positive. If you like the Arkham series, have a higher-end machine, and are interested in this game, I'd at least think about it. I have definite reservations about buying it right off the bat though. I'd try the console version first if you can, to see what you think of it.

This game is pretty incredible. So far its a suitable finale to the Arkham Trilogy. There are a few hiccups. There is a lot of Batmobile-focused combat, so if you don't like the Batmobile, you're in for a long night. There is less focus, I feel, on melee combat as well. As someone who enjoyed beating up a horde of 40 goons single-handedly in Arkham City, I miss the melee combat. The much-touted 'dual play' system has, so far for me, only appeared in one main questline and one side mission, even though I'm now in the third act of the game. Still, the Gotham City in this game is, in my opinion, the best Rocksteady has ever created. The aesthetic of the city is different then Origins or City, a bit brighter and more chaotic, but it looks gorgeous. The Batmobile, overall, is a bit hard to control but I found it fun once I got the hang of it. The voice acting is superb, as always, as are the Predator encounters. Unfortunately, I still cannot reccomend this game, even though I'm finding it thoroughly enjoyable. The only reason I've been able to play this far is that I got lucky. I've been able to play at 35-50 fps pretty consistently, with the occasional drop to around 25-30 when using Grapnel Boost, or in the middle of intense melee combat. I'm using a GTX 760 with an i5-3570k CPU. I installed this game on my SSD after finding it entirely unplayable on my HDD. I cannot hit 60 fps in this game in 1080p, and that is UNACCEPTABLE. Other users are unable to stay above 30 fps with hardware that is signifcantly better than mine. I'm incredulous that, in 2015, a major games publisher like WB Games is incapable of releasing a game that runs at 1080p, 60 fps on hardware that is more powerful than a PS4. Speaking of PS4, the PS4 version of this game contains Ambient Occlusion effects, while the PC version doesn't. Rocksteady has just publicly announced that this game was designed to run at the same graphical level as modern game consoles. In other words, this game is not going to look or run better than a machine which was years out of date when it was released. WB and Rocksteady's behavior regarding this game has been abhorrent. I would refund my game if I could, even though I am able to play it, but I purchased it on Green Man Gaming and can't get a refund. I'm afraid that we've lost a once respected developer and publisher to the easy money on consoles. This is the last time I will preorder a game by either of these two companies. Check out the megathread at  www.reddit.com/r/pcmasterrace  to learn more. I'm disgusted. I truly am.

Credit where credit is due. At this point, Arkham Knight performs fairly respectably - certainly not the worst game on PC in that regard - with all the settings you'd expect to see, and the game itself is quite fun, especially the latter half which features less shoehorned Batmobile sections (though still lots of Batmobile combat). I quite liked it at the end of the day, even if I maintain that it's the weakest in the series (excluding Blackgate).  Skip the season pass, though, unless it's steeply discounted. Half of the expansion content is very good, but all of the standalone missions are the worst they could possibly be. An amazing finale to one of the best superhero videogame series of all time. There's a few bugs, and a lot of users are reporting some game-breaking stuff (I've had none of the major issues, and the game performed pretty well for 30+ hours. The first patch broke the main menu's framerate for me though), but Arkham Knight is well worth experiencing.  Arkham Knight takes the series' excellent combat and stealth mechanics and improves on them in virtually every way. The biggest new feature is the Batmobile, and it feels like you're using it as much as you're travelling on foot. This makes it feel less gimmicky than it otherwise would have been, but I feel as though it's relied on a little too much. When it transforms into a tank and you're taking down unmanned drones, the game feels significantly less like a Batman game. That being said, it keeps things from getting stale.  The story is fantastic, and easily the best in the series. I won't spoil anything here, but Rocksteady and the excellent cast of voice actors (including John Noble's absolutely perfect performance as Scarecrow) have really outdone themselves. There's one big plot point that falls a little flat, but the rest of the game more than makes up for it. You do have to finish every side mission to see the ending (yes, that includes over 200 Riddler trophies/challenges!), but most of them are entertaining and well put together. The sections with Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing assisting you are great fun.  At time of writing, the Harley Quinn story is the only DLC available outside of a few skins, and whilst it feels unique (Harley's version of Detective Mode is extremely well done), it can be finished in about 15 minutes. Still, it provides a short prequel story of sorts, as opposed to just being challenge maps like the Robin and Nightwing DLC from Arkham City. Speaking of which, there aren't any challenge maps in this game - there's 23 ranked challenges, but they're not confined to separate maps. They all take place within Gotham City.  Overall, a great game, well worth playing, and a top contender for Game of the Year. Well, maybe runner-up to The Witcher 3 anyway :p

By some miracle, my old GTX 960 was able to run this game at a high FPS and with the graphics set to max. Even stranger, it seems that reducing any of the settings actually made the game run slower. So I played through it, gave it about 40 hours of my time, and here's what I've learned:  1. The tank battles are amazing. But there are far too many of them. Upgrading feels empowering and never like a chore, and however unrealistic and un-Batmanlike it may be, just charging through the city, pedestrians, cars, and all, feels great.  2. He's the same old Batman. In nearly every way. Nothing fazes him, and he's rarely faced with defeat. And he's about as stiff as he's always been. This can be a good thing, but sometimes one wishes for a bit of narrative (and aesthetic) variety.  3. Which brings us to the aesthetics. Somehow, being able to play at max settings with a decent FPS (most of the time), Gotham City is without a question the best playground Rocksteady has given their players. It is way more immersive by means of the living, breathing menu system with absolutely TONS to do anywhere you look, and because of the impressive roster of villains they have you interact with (read: beat up). This is wondrous for the lore, and there are an infinite number of references to Batman stories past. The city is always rainy, dark and gritty, but also bright and neon, shiny and reflective. Even the smallest details will be appreciated. The Batman series (minus Origins, I don't know what that was) has been known for introducing hundreds of marginally small changes instead of a few huge ones, and this is true here. You're getting a similar experience design- and graphics-wise, but it's satisfying.  Bottom line, it was an enjoyable experience to play this game, but the changes to come with the update (whenever that will be) will be much appreciated.
