Okay, so there's a lot of bad publicity surrounding Batman: AK, and much of it rightly so, but I want to focus on the game itself and not jump on the 'my AAA game is broke' bandwagon.   I've got nearly 20 hours in on a PC with little to no problems with the game graphically speaking - granted, I have not performed any benchmarking, frame tracking, etc but I have yet to run into any fatal crashing, lock-ups, or freezes. I will post my computer hardware at the end of this review.  The game is introduced in a stunningly beautiful way and completely captures the player's attention - after the diner I couldn't wait to experience play under the mantle of the Dark Knight. I am no stranger to the Arkham series and any player who has experience in any of the previous games will very quickly adapt to combat mechanics, traversing across the city, and solving the game's puzzles (often in the form of the Riddler's obstacles). Veteran players will also readily recognize Riddler trophies and puzzles, and the subtle hints through the use of Batman's audio monitoring system.   The game features some new additions, most notable of which is the Batmobile - personally I was cautiously optimistic about this addition as there is a certain aura of reverance engulfing this particular vehicle. However, as exciting as it can be to finally drive the Batmobile Rocksteady seems to force its use onto players in a nagging way rather consistently - it is noticeably clumsy, its use can slow down gameplay (in terms of time, not graphics), and frequently its use is just absurd. There is one particular Riddler puzzle that comes to mind that requires the use of the Batmobile and while the puzzle itself is intriguing, I literally facepalmed at how far Rocksteady went to forcibly incorporate the Batmobile in the riddle... let alone the rather silly Riddler races. The whole idea of a Riddler race track, while meagerly fun, simply does not mesh with the Batman atmosphere or the Riddler's theme. The Batmobile's remote feature acts to compound the vehicle's necessity and while the car won't fire on Batman... it will fire on police cars. Further, it is nearly impossible to destroy (at least, in part) Gotham City in some fashion while driving around - in fact, the destruction is so noticeable that makes the player question just how committed Batman is to actually protecting the city. Speaking of protecting Gotham City, some of the game's sidequests virtually destroy the city and after a while the player starts wondering just how much city will be left standing after Batman 'defends' it.   The upgrade (or talent) system is similar to previous installments with many of the same upgrades taken from similar titles (added armor, reduced combo requirements, etc) and combat mechanics are nearly identical with the exception of dual take-downs which can be exciting but are really only implemented in specific areas with a number of enemies to fight. Also, the game introduces added environmental interaction during combat sequences: Batman can throw a thug into electrical panels, actuate security systems to isolate thugs, and he can perform vehicle take-downs... that is, he can glide onto of a car and throw the driver out similar to what is seen in the movies and cartoons. There are also a few new gadgets at Batman's disposal but they are rather seldomly used.   Perhaps the game's biggest problem is repetition. While the game does offer hours and hours of side missions and dialogue, much of this is completed in the same basic formula... fight off a number of drone tanks in the Batmobile (nearly always the same engagement), chase down Firefly (its only enjoyable the first time), or simply brawl against an increasing number of thugs, militia, and automated guns. After a while, you just want the achievement because you feel you've already completed the task two dozen times.   Now, what the game does get right is story telling and it is very clear where directors Bruce Timm & Paul Dini leave their mark. For the sake of spoilers, I won't say too much, but if you are a fan of the cartoon series you will easily recognize many story elements. Also, there is a specific narration that never gets old and I am personally glad to have it - it simply wouldn't be an Arkham game without it. While I think about it, there is one particular 'rescue' mission in the Gotham Movie Studios during which I refused to progress - I just sat back and enjoyed the ambience. If you are a fan of the villian, you will too. Scarecrow also adds quite an intimidating element to the game, but John Noble's Australian accent clearly beams through many times in the game.   In short, the game hardly revolutionizes any mechnic and often times stumbles along in what new features the game adds.   All in all, I'd likely give the game 7/10. NOTE: For those wondering, I am playing this game on a severely under-spec laptop that does NOT meet the minimum system requirements listed on the store page. As such, I consider 25-30fps an acceptable performance, though I wouldn't if I was playing on a higher-spec machine. My review is labelled positive for this reason, in addition to really enjoying the game; please read this note before unnecessarily downvoting my review.  Batman: Arkham Knight is the third and final entry into Rocksteady's universally acclaimed Batman: Arkham trilogy. The high quality of the previous two entries by Rocksteady (Arkham Asylum and Arkham City) means Arkham Knight has a lot to live up to, especially so since it's the last Arkham game we're going to see; fortunately, it lives up to expectations in every regard. Storywise (avoiding spoilers), the game has you playing as Bruce Wayne/Batman in Gotham on Halloween night, when the Scarecrow threatens the entire city with his fear toxin, thus forcing the city to evacuate. His plan to drown the entire city in fear with the help of his mysterious ally known as the Arkham Knight is Batman's biggest threat yet, and makes for some pretty excellent storytelling; Rocksteady again display their maturity in regards to telling a good story, as there are plenty of compelling emotional moments and the Arkham Knight's reveal is an impressive display of narrative prowess. The Joker's death in the previous game lingers over the characters and makes for some very dark and engrossing storytelling. The open-world of Gotham is also the most impressive map out of all the Arkham games; the entire map is open to the player right from the start, and the densely-packed cityscape makes it a perfect urban playground for Batman's activities. It is obvious that a great deal of love and care has been placed into designing this interpretation of Gotham, meaning players get to experience an open world that has a significant personality of its own. Gameplay from the previous games has been polished and reworked extensively. The usual rhythmic melee battles are here in fine form, with Batman's punches, kicks and counters all feeling very tight and responsive. Nobody has mastered this kind of melee combat like Rocksteady, who have had two previous games to refine this formula into their most efficient yet. There are a solid variety of gadgets on display, with both old and new devices joining the fray for use in both combat and puzzle-solving. The newest gadget I should mention is the Batmobile; an all purpose vehicle and tank that the player can use to speedaround Gotham and engage in firefights with other vehicles. I was worried how the inclusion of a vehicle would translate to this game, but I was pleasantly surprised by the way the Batmobile had been integrated into the gameplay. The driving handles very well, the tank battles are a hell of a lot of fun, and the puzzles involving the vehicle require just as much thought as the ordinary ones. In short, gameplay is polished and solidly refined, and is easily the best Arkham game for this very reason.  I should mention the controversial performance issues that have been plaguing this game since its launch; many users have reported the game unplayable, but on my under-spec machine I maintained a stable 25-30 fps for the duration of the game. I have no complaints performance wise, but I can easily understand those who have. In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Knight is my favourite Arkham game and a stunning end to such a fabled trilogy of games. The strong narrative in combination with perfected gameplay makes this a solid choice for GOTY 2015, and is one of those unforgettable games that reminds you why you began playing video-games in the first place. Highly and thoroughly recommended.

~~~This game was reviewed on a GTX 1070, 32GB DDR4 RAM @ 2400MHz, i7 6820HK @ 3.8GHz~~~  ---   Oh, how this game loves you... and hates you, too.   Oh, how at times its gameplay is masterful with such refined adeptness, but then so repetitively boring and frustrating. Oh, how the story is so intricate, nuanced, and deliciously brooding and yet full of cliche teen-angst and predictable-ness with ample clout for eye-rolling. Oh, how the visuals cascade your eyes with splendor, until the damn game crashes on you,... again.   I really love this game; I really hate this game, too. It's a crazy and yet totally sane dichotemy.   No spoilers ahead, but a few points to illustrate the above preamble.   1) Vehicle combat just blows. Sure, it's fine for about 30 minutes, but becomes such a chore late in the game, it completely detracts from the brilliance of being Batman. Did I mention being Batman is brilliant? Yes, it most certainly is. Unfortunately, this brilliance is marred by You being the Batmobile as much as You being the Batman. Point: the Batman is awesome; the Batmobile sucks.   2) The Arkham Knight, while a new character (sort-of) in the Batman cannon, is a lame-♥♥♥ villain, especially so when the plot finally culminates to his reveal. Even considering this is a video game based on a comic, the amazingly ludicrous lengths this character goes to annihilate the Batman (and where did he even get the money to invest in an ENTIRE army seemingly the size of North Korea's?), is borderline comical, especially once the 'reveal' happens. Color me critical, but I just can't look past the melodramatic teen-ansty-ness of the Arkham Knight. But! Minding this aside, the story is quite entertaining, with concise and to the point cutscenes that continually drive the momentum of the story (until the Arkham Knights talks...some more). It's as if the game appreciates your curiosity and intellect to piece together and predict the direction of the story to only slap you in the face with another bantering, banal commentary by the Arkham Knight. Point: the story is great; the Arkham Knight pretty much sucks.   3) This game is gorgeous. Like (and I usually don't start sentences with 'like') it's absolutely stunning. The character animations from lip-syncing to body-movement and fluidity of combat are simply phenominal (2015/2016 standards). Even though the game takes place at night, the city streets are dazingly detailed and there are so many nuanced atmospheric effects on screen, it's a relentless avalanche of visual-splendor. And yet, even after the debauched luanch over a year ago, the game crashes, and regularly. Sure, when it's running, it runs well, but I experienced a crash every 20 or so minutes of gameplay - far, FAR too often. Point: it's visually stunning; it also crashes A LOT!  So, how in the Gotham (notice I replaced 'world' with Gotham, because I'm clever) does this game fair? Well, despite its clear shortcomings, it's still oh-so-good... until it's oh-so-bad.   I can so recommend this game, until I don't want to anymore! I'm flummoxed. Perhaps you will be, too, or won't?!?

I've been stunned by how many AAA titles are locked to 1920x1080 resolutions, even when having options for larger resolutions (Dead Rising 3, I'm looking at you). Arkham Knight worked right out of the box and had no issue reducing screen size down to 1980x1080 for the pre-rendered cutscenes.   It's truly tragic that this game will always have such a bad reputation on PC, even once it's been fully fixed, but I hope publishers learn from this and start doing QA properly. The PC gaming market hasn't been this stable in years, so piracy should no longer be a reason for companies to short-change us.

I, for one, am enjoying the game immensely. The combat system has me head over heels with how many different possibilities there are for taking people down, and there's just enough challenge to not make it seem like I'm button mashing and free-flowing like a god. Game runs fine with some stutters (had a big issue earlier, but not worth refunding). The story has me captivated and the side quests are just so much fun to do. I hate not being able to do some of them, but I know it's good not to rush them. Contrary to the other reviews....this game is as amazing as I expected. I personally give it an 8/10 in it's current state which is likely to change after a patch or two. This ,however, is based on my personal experience during 20 hours of gameplay.  Pros : -It's BEAUTIFUL & runs VERY well (I honestly haven't witnessed a single hiccup or framerate drop) -Great improvements to overall gameplay mechanics -A new and very detailed environment -Combat mechanics have been vastly improved -Great uses of GameWorks and Physx features -Great storyline so far -Some things that may be construed as spoilers.... -I'm loving it so much that my first session lasted about 20 hours and felt like 3 or 4 hours at most.   Cons : -Batmobile controls were a little hard to get used to. -It's currently capped at 30 FPS (more of my opinion on this below) -It stops responding after it closes and I have to click 'Wait' or 'Close' in a Windows dialogue. There's no delay or anything.....just an extra mouse-click.    I occasionally feel sorry for developers now-a-days.....and this is definitely one of those cases.  This game is awesome and well worth the money, wait and anticipation, if you don't start ****ing with settings because you can't live without 60+ FPS. I'm sure it's capped at 30 FPS for a reason and is most likely temporary.  With all of the settings increased to their current maximum, this game is beautiful and runs VERY well.....as long as I don't change the FPS cap. Honestly......this game @ 30 FPS does not bother me AT ALL. The small amount of motion blur it applies totally smooths out the frame rate.  I'm not sure if it actually does not like some hardware configurations or if all of the negative reviews are from people who insist on changing the framerate cap or do not have the hardware to run it. Guess what happens when I change the FPS cap.....it runs like ****.  My specs (all stock settings): Intel i7-4820K 3.7GHz 32GB G.Skill Ripjaws DDR3 EVGA X79 Classified Board (1) EVGA GTX 770 Classified 4GB (4) WD Black RE4 500 GB HDDS's  **** Updated Statements *****  I pre-ordered the Deluxe version (game +season pass). I enjoyed the game for 40+ hours (It ran fine for me with max settings @ 30 fps). BUT.....the instability (or the inability to play at all) that the vast majority of people have experienced, combined with the delay of PC DLC and over 2 month wait for a remotely decent patch leaves me tempted to not buy another Rocksteady or WB game for the next 5+ years (hoping they get their **** together and learn not to rush a release....if it's not ready, delay that **** and get it right) unless it's on sale and proven to be stable. It's inexcusable to release a game in that state.  For their sake, I hope they have something planned to make up for this massive blunder (although I highly doubt it). It'd probably be the one and only thing that would make me even consider buying another one of their games for full-price (much less pre-order) ever again...... and I didn't have any problems playing it at release, I just have the utmost sympathy for all of the people who eagerly anticipated this game only to be screwed upon release and left hanging for over 2 months for a decent patch.

HOW TO FIX ISSUES WITH THIS GAME:       Game crashes or had bad performance:  1. Verify your game cache  (Library --> right click game --> properties --> local files --> verify integrity) . There was an issue with the preloading. 2. In graphics options, disable all the  'Nvidia Gameworks'  options. There seem to be the major cause of the slowdowns.      Game only runs at 30 FPS:  Open  <Steam folder>\steamapps\common\Batman Arkham Knight\BMGame\Config\BMSystemSettings.ini . Find the line that says  MaxFPS=30.000000  and change it to  MaxFPS=60.000000       Mouse sensitivity is too high:  Open  <Steam folder>\steamapps\common\Batman Arkham Knight\BMGame\Config\BMInput.ini . Find the line that says  MouseSensitivity=30.0  and lower the value until it feels comfortable  (You need to restart after each change)     MY REVIEW:   I'll write a full review when I'm finished, but for now, I'll just say that once you get through all the manual setup, this game is  fantastic . I  do  agree that for a $60-100 game, the need for all these fixes and workarounds is upsetting  (don't companies QA their games anymore?) , but this game is so good now that I can actually play, I'm willing to look past that.

OK, So I've just completed the Scarecrow mission (is that the main mission by the way?) What I've noticed since day 1 - obviously the initial release was pretty poor (but playable for me all be it at 30/60 fps) - I started the game and probably played a good few hours, but decided to wait for the first patch for the improved and much needed performance. (so my experience wouldnt be ruined) I then played on the September patch, and things were massivly improved, the extra in game effects and 90fps are far superior - I played a bit more, but still I thought I'd wait for the October patch (I was busy with other things anyway). October patch and at first it seemed like a downgrade - I play on some serious hardware i7 4770K @4.4Ghz, MSI 980Ti Gaming @ ~1400Mhz with 32Gb of system RAM! Also I have a G-Sync monitor @1440p (ASUS ROG P278Q). I had the latest Hotfix drivers initially 358.59 and the game was running awful. So I downgraded to 358.50 and things were still bad - however, turning off G-Sync made things much better (358.59 were supposed to fix some G-Sync framrate issues) Finally I went back to 358.59 after removing the drivers properly with DDU and things seemed much improved with G-Sync ON. What I do notice is, that for no apparent reason the framerate occasionally drops from ~80fps (with everything on max including gameworks) to 40fps, but also the GPU usage falls to 50%, this seems to happen when nothing much is going on and can be in a scene with low complexity - odd.) Other than that, the framerate has been very good and the game has played mainly smoothly - I should hope so too with this hardware. (I can't remeber the September patch having this problem) On that note I have very much enjoyed the Scarecrow campain, of note has been a very interesting story line and some absolutly awesome vocal acting, especially from the Joker - well written lines from all characters. The character detail is also superb, with all the main villains being superbly rendered and animated. Some great cutscenes too and very decent gameplay. So all in all things are on the up, I would love to see the GPU usage bug squashed ASAP, I think I will pause my gameplay again until this patch is released. Although still not perfect I would say great work so far considering the mess it was in on initial release, and please continue PC support even if the PC crowd is a bit fickle and hard to please (quite rightly so!) A great game that I would highly recommend - especially when all the bugs are fixed - please hurry! P.S. How do you get the consolation software that we are supposed to get for free? It's not in my library and is full price in the store. Cheers, Jon.

I have played and finished the game (aside from the Riddler trophies) and have not had any major issues playing the game. It ran perfectly during my marathon gaming session with it, and it looks beautiful. As for the game itself, Rocksteady has delivered another fantastic game, the gameplay mechanics are tight and enjoyable, and it all fits in perfectly to the Arkham Universe.   The only negatives I have with the game are story related. It didn't feel as big as Arkham City in terms of side quests, and I found the limited amount of time you get to play with a side kick a rather missed opportunity. There are a few other main story issues I had as well, primarily in the later parts of the game, but all of those enter the spoilers realm.   So to sum it all up: it ran perfectly on my PC, they perfected the gameplay elements from the previous games in the series, but they made some questionable story choices that made it not quite live up to the finale I wanted. If you are a Batman / Comic book fan, this is a must get game (play the others first though), and for gamers I would still recommend it as it has some great gameplay mechanics.

I was at work all day yesterday hearing about all the problems with the PC port of this game. I was worried I wouldn't be able to play it when I got home because many of the people reporting problems had more expensive graphics cards than I do, and mine is an AMD which I was led to believe would spell D-O-O-M for my prospects of playing Arkham Knight.  However, I found that all the fuss was about nothing. Yes it is locked at 30 fps by default, but that was an easy fix. I simply installed the most recent AMD drivers before initializing the game, then changed the 'Max_FPS' value to 60 in the BMSystemSettings.ini file and it ran perfectly. I played for 6 hours straight and didn't see so much as a hiccup. So here I am telling you that this game is awesome! People have also been complaining about drops in framerate and the addition of the Batmobile, which I think it's a really clever addition, especially how it is frequently used to solve puzzles.  Overall, there is a LOT to do in this game. I'm only 24% through the main story, which is very captivating (no spoilers, but a few of the scenes I've witnessed show how this title earned its 'M' rating from ESRB. This is my first time writing my Steam review, but I wanted to give this title some praise, as I think everyone has really overreacted to the initial problems. Let me be clear, in my experience, the game is by no means 'unplayable,' and I expect to continue playing it through completion on PC.   Oh, and one more awesome touch I noticed. This is the first PC game that has actually read my PS4 controller as such and makes use of the light bar and vibration features, which was an awesome change (normally I have to run a program that causes my PC to read my Dualshock 4 as an Xbox 360 controller, which can cause confusion when you have to press X. Seriously, they are both even blue!)

I'll preface this review by saying that I've had no real issues with performance. There has been the odd framerate stutter here-and-there but nothing consistent. Based on the overwhelmingly negative response out there it seems I've been very lucky. So obviously approach the game with caution.   Moving past that, after about four hours with the game my feelings are mostly positive:  Being The Batman feels even more like being The Batman than before. The new takedown moves that are quickly unlocked - cool multiple stealth takedowns and the seamless, flowing environment takedown - are brilliant additions. This is smile inducing stuff in an already solid as hell combat engine that has always been the core of this game's appeal.  Arkham Knight is a rarity for me in being the right kind of big-budget spectacle. Modern premium releases often make me think about the insanity of games development but it is rare that that reflection is positive. They can often feel like hollow and stale experiences, especially when they are serialised, and make me crave indie game excitement and creativity. Somehow Arkham Knight doesn't.   I can deeply appreciate the polish everything has been given. A costume change is given the amount of cinematic clout many games would struggle to bring to a heavily directed fight cut-scene. The effortless way it flips to a closeup accentuating the Batmobile's pimped out Batman symbol rims, glowing red hot, after a successful leap across a bridge gap. It's overblown and extreme and the man-hours invested is insane. But it's the right kind of overblown and it is utterly fitting to what is, at its core, still a fine game. A delicious decorative icing on a Batman cake that already has the most organicly rich and flavour packed combat and city-soaring in the ingredient list.  It's the kind of game that I can't help but imagine taking back in time to explode the minds of early video game developers!  Because of its robust core systems and great world design there aren't just moments of cool the game directs you down. The potential to be cinematic without ever leaving the safety of gameplay remains from the previous titles and with the stunning graphics it is heightened.   While pinging through the air near the start of the game, getting to grips with how to fly again, I ended up off-course and suddenly perched on top of a bit of scenery surveying the city. I paused, stopped trying to play and just took in what was on screen. Crouched on a huge, overgrowth covered gothic statue with an insane, twisted, crazy vision of Gotham lit up before me... Hugely cinematic and totally unscripted - the kind of jaw dropping that only this sort of size and spectacle can create.  It's not really about the views though, it's about connecting kevlar covered fist to thug face and combat feels as brilliant as ever. I don't know if something this flowing, tight and intuitive can ever feel tired and the ways in which you can pinball between enemies is now even wider. A new Streets of Rage Game using this system would be welcome (I wish for this with each new Batman game. I guess I feel Skate and Blaze are somehow better than Batman). ;)  So this is all good stuff. But that Batmobile...   Don't get me wrong, it is uber cool in a lot of ways. It looks amazing and when it is an option to quickly get around it is a fun extra in the 'I'm The Batman' arsenal. It won't get used often but every so often the urge to launch like a scud missile from it kicks in.  However, when something in a game this big-budget has this much time put into it to make it look cool as cool can be you can be damned sure the developer is going to rinse all that they can from it.  I don't want to play a tank game.   I certainly don't want to be back-and-forthing in greater than usual amounts to complete simple progression because of the new tank option.   The Batmobile has its tricks and they are fun the first time... except you know as they happen that you will have to do them over and over as you continue and they will never be as fun as gliding and swooping and punching people while being Batman.   So to summarise, it is good being Batman again but it would be better if there were less things stopping Batman effortlessly gliding to the next bit of brawling. That's much the same in every one of the games in this series and possibly why the first is always going to be the stand-out. It is a tighter and more intense experience despite (or because of) the lack of city swooping (and now Bat-tank grinding) freedom.   Arkham Kinight is huge and impressive and good. It just needs to be more focused and move forward without making the player move backwards three times for each step ahead.

vArkham Knight on PC is a very fun, good-looking, and overall well-made game, performance issues aside. The game plays like its predecessors and improves on a variety of things. One notable addition is the Batmobile. Personally, I don't like being forced to use the Batmobile so much but it's fine since the Batmobile is so fluid, and smooth. The controls are intuitive, and the car itself is a beast. Really feels like you're driving THE Batman's car. The game itself is great, fantastic very deserving of its 91 metacritic score on the console side.  However, the performance as of the release date is a bit spotty. My computer runs it fine, i5-4690k, gtx 770 2gb, 8gb ram. It could put all the settings on max (note though textures missing high/ultra option, so are some of the other options). With all settings put to highest, I averaged around 50 fps (with the .ini max fps cap set to 60) in everything EXCEPT the Batmobile. As soon as I entered the batmobile, my fps dropped to around 1 - 15fps.  After setting all the settings to lowest, the game plays very smoothly with 60 fps, and Batmobile has improved vastly albeit still a little sluggish at times. Despite the settings on low, the game is GORGEOUS.   So bottom line, the game is great, and very playable for me (no crashes, minor stutter) with 1080p and 60 fps. Hopefully Rocksteady releases a patch soon that fixes some of this lag, and performance so that I can at least run it at normal settings. My computer should be able to. In the meantime, while not ideal, playing on lowest settings still results in a very well-made, beautiful, and fun game.

Here is an overview of my experience so far (only played roughly 6 hrs so far):  My setup: Intel i5 4690K (Codename: Devils Canyon) 3.50GHz Processor  ASUS Gryphon Z97 Motherboard  NVIDIA GeForce GTX 980 GPU  16GB of RAM  Installed on a 1TB HDD (Western DIgital)  Settings (in-game): 1920x1080, AA On, VSYNC On, Textures: Normal, Other settings are High as well (don't remember what they were). NVIDIA GameWorks: OFF except for Enhanced Rain. Also set my PhysX->GPU in the NVIDIA Control Panel.  Performance: So far, for me at least, the performance is going well. Definitely more than playable. I didn't edit any ini files, and I don't have the latest drivers installed (I have 353.06). I also deleted the pre-load data before the game unlocked because of all the nightmare re-downloading crap people have gone through. Installed the game from scratch when it unlocked (9:00pm PST) instead. Obviously the 30fps cap is crap considering its a PC game, but I'm not touching the ini files just to be safe. I'll live with 30fps for now, doesn't really bother me all that much to be honest.  Running around as Batman: Smooth fps for me, occasional hiccup when auto-saving though.  Driving the Batmobile: Yep, there are framerate dips from time to time, but for me its not NEARLY as bad as people make it sound. I expected the fps drops considering moving around in the Batmobile is more demanding then running around as Batman for the computer. Overall though, it's a fun and enjoyable experience.  Gliding: More fps drops then running around as Batman, but not as much as the Batmobile and its very quick, not blatantly obvious.  Graphics: This game is great looking to me, although not as gorgeous as I expected considering the hardware requirements and no ULTRA settings (unless that is what Normal is supposed to be). Haven't encountered the bright light textures that some encounter where all the character are emitting a bright light. No weird bugs, minus the normal clipping issues and Batman going through the Batmobile when I summon it. Overall very nice to look at.  Gameplay: Obviously just as good as the other Batman games. Great combat, storyline (so far), playability and lots of sidequest to do. Some people hate the Batmobile gameplay but I enjoy it. I try to balance between playing as Batman and driving the Batmobile because it seems they REALLY want you to use the Batmobile (maybe too much even, but meh, it is what it is). Also, some have experienced issues with their Xbox/PS4 controllers not working, but my Wired Xbox 360 controller works fine.  Overall, I'm really enjoying the experience so far regardless of the minor fps drops here and there, which I can live with. It does need a patch though, I will agree with that and changing the Pre-order Harley bonus for users who got the game with a GPU purchase (me) so that we don't get it is complete bull but I can live without it, considering it will be available later on and I've heard its not very long anyway. Hopefull they will rectify this over the next few weeks along with a patch. Also don't really like the fact that the PC version was ported via an outside company but I know this seems to be standard practice for companies nowadays.  I wish there was a middle of the road option when rating this review instead of just thumbs up or down. I'm inclined to give it a thumbs up because my own personal experience with the game so far has been very satisfactory.   Remember: This is my OWN personal experience and yours may differ from mine (more than likely). I would not have played through 5 hrs. of the game in one sitting unless the game was playing well. Hope this provides some insight and hope for people.

So, after playing for 13 hours straight today and playing for a few hours on release, I've completed the story of Batman: Arkham Knight. Now, straight off the bat of this review, this game DOES NOT deserve to be rated Mostly Negative. Literally a few weeks ago, Fallout 4's trailer was released and everyone was saying 'It's not all about the graphics and performance, it's about the story', then they buy this game, come across a 30FPS capped game (Which can be easily changed to 60 in the config file) and rate it down.  Anyway, the actual review. You take up the role of Bruce Wayne, aka Batman, who has the task of taking down Scarecrow and a whole army of drones, super-villans andyour general brutes. I have played and completed all Batam games created by Rocksteady Studios and I thought this game would end up like Assassins Creed, but this conclusion to the series blows the series out of the water. The story is amazing and so detailed. You'll have around 15-20 hours playing the main story mode and most likely another 15-30 hours finishing the other missions and collecting all the riddler trophies. With the new batsuit, batmobile, smooth fluid combat and a beautiful looking world, Arkham Knight is the best Batman Game of all time.   -| Minor Spoiler Part |- From all the predecessors of the Arkham series, Joker has always been the main bad guy, but in Arkham Knight, Joker is inside Batman's head the entire time of the game, just randomly popping up with dialogue and with his hopes of achieving his end goal to take over Bruce's body and mind. The Joker made this game go from great to perfect for me, because Joker is always there and because he's such a loveable character, it's great to constantly have him round.  -| Combat |- It's a Batman game, ofc the combat is going to be superb, but now with the batmobile, combat just takes this leap into utter greatness. The controls are a bit eh to get used to, but before you know it, you'll be drifting round corners and running over thugs.  -| Pros |-    Beautiful Looking Game    Combat is Fluid    Amazing Storyline    Joker Ofc    Doesn't Feel Boring to Play    Gliding Around    New Upgrades for Batman    No Bugs (That I Came Across)    Jonathan Banks as Commissioner Gordon   -| Cons |-    Frames Are Up & Down (45-60FPS for me)    Batmobile Controls Could be Better    Performance is Alright, But Could Be Better   -| Final Score |- Batman: Arkham Knight is the perfect end to the Arkham series. Rocksteady ended it very well and I respect that they didn't drag this series out, like how Assassins Creed is being milked like a cow.   4.5/5 - Perfect & Flawless Storytelling, Arkham Knight Won't Disappoint.   -| My Specs |- CPU: Intel Core i7 4790 RAM: 2x8GB GPU: AMD Radeon R9 270 HDD: 3TB Seagate  Ran between 45-60FPS constantly

Note: at no point in my completion of Arkham Knight on PC did I encounter any serious glitches or bugs, so I can't offer a review of the PC port's performance beyond saying it ran perfectly for me. Moving on...  As I played through the final moments of this series, I thought of one game I almost never do: it's predecessor, Arkham Origins. As competent and perfectly playable as that game was, it highlights a striking contrast with Arkham Knight: one of vision. Origins created a conservative, almost tepid version of the world's greatest detective, checking off all the obligatory boxes but never fully embracing the character's legacy. Knight, on the other hand, is brave, bold, the work of a developer clearly confident in their abilities. In Asylum and City, you felt like Batman. For the first time, in Arkham Knight, you truly become him.  This is not a statement to be made lightly. The game earns that praise through a number of smart decisions, starting with the Batmobile. Vehicle sections in otherwise action-oriented games tend to end up... off. Had the experience of driving the hero's iconic car consisted of finicky controls or lackluster power, it would have certainly damaged the game as whole. However, Rocksteady has nailed it in every concievable way; driving through the city is at once comfortable and breathtaking. The vehicle controls in a responsive way, and it's battle functionality enables both more precise movement and satisfying firepower. After mastering the basics, Rocksteady goes further: At any location in Gotham, a single button press summons the Batmobile in under 5 seconds. Moving the aiming reticule from a machine to a person automatically switches from explosive to incapacitating ammunition. The trunk stores not spare tires, but a fully protective roll cage for Batman's passengers. Colliding with a tree results not in sudden stop, but a shower of debris as you sail through it. It's details like these elevate that truly elevate the Batmobile beyond traditional transport.  Other reviews have voiced concerns that the driving doesn't 'feel like Batman', that blowing up unarmed drones somehow conflicts with the character's personality. I disagree. Every time you drive by one of Gotham's many goons, they run away, screaming 'The Bat's here!' 'He's got a tank!' This is Batman more than anything: the fantasy that everyone fears you, that nothing can stand in your way. It's empowering, in a word. Fantastically empowering.  The sense of power is further heightened through improvements indicative of a video game sequel. The map is bigger than City's, which means you fly higher and drive faster than before. You get more gadgets, which enables you even more navigational and offensive abilities. Even the menus have been upgraded, cleanly organizing side content in a managable, approachable way. None of this has come at the cost of core features or fun. Content and polish abound in Arkham Knight.  All of this would be for naught if Rocksteady dropped the ball concluding the story of their trilogy. Thankfully, however, they've succeeded at creating a satisfying and involving narrative, one that stands as a great Batman story in it's own right. After having just read how much bigger and grander the game is, I wouldn't blame you for fearing that the plot could run off the rails. However, this is where the game surprises most of all: while the city size and polygon count has risen dramatically, the focus of the story has shrunk and condensed. Past games could feel at times like a Batman wikipedia, cramming as many villains as possible into their storylines. While dedicated comic book fans may get a rush from seeing every character represented onscreen, it reduced their individual impacts in the narrative, creating caricatures instead of meaningful people.  Arkham Knight, on the other hand, reigns back the rogues gallery to the bare essentials. Oh, make no mistake, if you want to go fight Penguin, Two-Face, or Firefly, you can use that mission menu I mentioned earlier to guide you through their terrific, yet optional side stories. The main quest, however, is truly a Batman story, in that it's a story about Batman: a character study, an examination about why Batman does what he does. This would be moot if Arkham Knight was in any way a half-hearted or conventional affair. It's fitting, then, that the story revolves around admitting and facing your fears, because Rocksteady clearly has none in the portrayal of the caped crusader. This game is dark, deliciously dark, unafraid to suprise or frighten you with extended, artsy segments normally reserved for indie games, and it's this boldness that really sells the story's drama. Granted, the occasional plot beat may seem a bit familiar (your first guess at the Arkham Knight's identity won't be correct, but your second might), but, by-and-large, the story is full of interesting twists and memorable moments, and is one you surely won't want spoiled.  Another Batman trilogy capper, The Dark Knight Rises, proves that all the good intention in the world can't redeem base deficits or shaky foundations. Arkham Knight rises above that category of disappointing three-quels, offering compelling combat, gorgeous graphics, and a superb story. There may be no such thing as a perfect game, but Arkham Knight is the perfect Batman game.

If you are expecting something new to the Batman: Arkham series, then you'll enjoy the Batmobile. What I want to say first, however, is this;  I hadn't, from the beginning of this game to reaching ACE Chemicals, had any frame drops or skips, and I'm running an i7-4790k with a GTX 980, everything maxed. I'd advise touching ANYTHING with the game's ini files, as that does screw with how the port is optimized.  Is it a good port? I think so. Whether you want to beleve the heavy negative reviews or not is your choice. I got my money's worth. If anything to stray from in this game, its the fact that standard batmobile driving and steering is so bad that you're almost holding right click the entire time just to move -- the term I coin Batman: The Tank Batmobile Simulator.  Fighting is definitely much more fluid than Arkham City and Origins. I've had so much fun with it so far, and can see many who like Asylum and Origin's fighting systems to also enjoy this. If I had to nitpick, it's definitely a bit easier to fight, more so on the principle of occasionally right click whilst spamming left click.  The story... Well, so far the story isn't exactly revealed once you get to ACE Chemicals at the least. From what I'm seeing, its good so far. All I can say without spoiling. Now, for the part I love about this game; the mission select; Unlike Arkham Origins and City, you have a mission select that'll help you to track your missions much more fluidly - something desperately needed for the size of Gotham as, to be fair, many spots can be confusing to follow or to just track and find stuff. The mission select helps in regards to doing the 'side-quests' that Gordon gives you or the GCPD gives. This doesn't sound intuitive, as yeah this should've existed in City and Origins, but it definitely helps for the fast pace of driving the Batmobile has.  All-in-all, a good game, but for the love of god don't touch the .ini files for the game; that does screw with how the game works overall, ya know :/. Either that, or my computer is weird enough to not experience issues with this game, as my frames have always been a constant 30, no dips whatsoever.

Review Score    10  10     Batman Arkham Knight is the game we've all been waiting for. This game well consume you into the city of Gotham. From death defying adversaries to mind blowing combat Batman: Arkham Knight is the best game in the trilogy. I will elaborate my review by covering these main elements such as gameplay, graphics, performance, and game mechanics.  The gameplay in this game is absolutely terrific. The first notable thing was that the enviroments are completely destructible to a certain degree. While you may not be able to demolish an entire building you can definitely take huge chucks out of it. I love that the Arkham games have certain themes and this one takes place on Halloween. Combat has been redefined and tweaked to the point where it's feels like you are water flowing through the streets of Gotham because of how fluid it is, also it rans a lot in Gotham. There's a ton of new animations which makes the game look very polished. The Remote Batarang can now be deflected off of surfaces now. The Explosive Gel is more accurate when facing foes and can be fired as a projectile. You can now parry as well as counter. The list goes on with all the new moves implemented. Lastly, there's very minimum loading which makes the player not lose that immersion  Graphics are superb and makes you feel like dancing in the rain. The attention to detail is excellent; I noticed that every part on the Batsuit is very distinct and intricate. Subtle nuances are present in every aspect of the city Gotham. The debris that cover ground gives you that chilling feeling down your spine that you're in the atmosphere of chaos. The Physx introduces to this game even more spectacular effects. Phsyx incorporates extra debris, dynamic smoke/fog, water effects, and realistic cloth movement. Although Physx is very demanding the aesthetics really gives it a more realistic feel. The water look fantastic if you ever go by the Gotham Bridge.  Performance is an area where this game seemed to be the most negative. I did have performance issues when I preloaded the game. I was crashing at a specific point and received an error message saying that I was missing files. After verifying the integrity of cache I notice a significant improvement in peformance. Before I was getting around 30 to 20 frames maxed on an Nvidia GTX 970 EVGA SSC edition and Intel 4970k. After verifying the integrity my performance sky rocketed to 60 and 40 frames in heavy combat against drone tanks. I believe that most people who preloaded the game files got corrupted and Steam didn't decyrpt files correctly while installing. I can say my game now runs fine but could use some patches for stability.  Lastly, the game mechanics are phenomenal. I love the fact they allow you to drive the Batmobile. The Batmobile is a similar to having a worthy companion who doesn't say nothing and follows your every command. The way the Batmobile maneuvers is flawless. For those who complain that it's forced upon the player you must not be a Batman true fan; reason being Batman is nothing without his Batmobile. Some things are just impossible for Batman to do and the puzzles you have to solve with the Batmobile is great. The game user interface is elegant and modern. The sleek design makes Batman new iconic suit feels futuristic. The visuals elements for the suit A.I., artificial intelligence, is lovely. As someone who uses After Effects this really does take the pie for stunning visuals that and it give it a very modern look.  I conclude this review by saying the game looks great. The gameplay is marvelous, no pun intended. The graphics are eye popping. Batman: Arkahm Knight is full of content. The performance is optimal after verifying cache. Lastly, the game mechanics are revolutionary and adds tons of depth on top of previous titles. Have a good day and an Arkham Knight.

Ok, I understand that people have issues with this game on their PCs, but I have been fortunate enough to be spared from majority of them.  The issues I have with the game are related to i.e. the locking the frames per second down to 30, which was weird choice from Rocksteady, but easily bypassed for those who know how to do it. Also, the motion blur is really, really annoying and one of the main 'features' I always remove from any game I play if possible. Locking away the higher resolution textures in the game's own options menu was also an odd choice (I believe this may have something to do with the fact that while the recommended size allocation for the game is 45 gigabytes, the game itself takes only 39 gigabytes of space, so they might actually be missing). The game has also a tendency to crash at very random points, without any obvious reason.  But the game works - I get to play it. Although not at optimal settings, but it works. This is rare for AAA-games these days on the day they are released. Considering how visually impressive this game is and how many new things they've tried to implement into it, I'm rather surprised it all works as well as it does. Anyone who has developed games for PC, or knows someone who has/is in game development, knows that a game of this scale is nigh impossible to get out without running into problems once it's released. I will wait for about a week and see what Rocksteady says and does before I give my final verdict to this game, but so far I've been having fun playing it.  So yeah, I'd recommend this to my friends and anyone who is a fan of the previous games, though perhaps not at its current price tag of 49,99€. Still, for those who can't wait for the discount sales, I say 'Go for it!'  I'll come back and change my review should things not change or turn for the worse.

This is honestly one of the most frustrating gaming experiences I've had in a very long while. Now I'm playing after the patch, I never got a chance to deal with the horribleness of pre-patch. What I'm talking about is the actual gameplay itself. I've never seen a game that tries so hard to ruin itself, it's astonishing really. I feel like there were one or two guys on the design team who were bound and determined to make this experience terrible. What is so frustrating is you keep seeing the game this could have been, but then they disappoint you...again. So here are some very specific examples of what I'm talking about.  •Absolutely nothing is added to the experience of the batmobile being shoehorned into the game. It is only there to annoy you, in extremely aggrivating vehicle segments that never make you feel like Batman. They force you to deal with the batmobile CONSTANTLY, even when doing indoor puzzles! It's utterly ridiculous and whoever thought this was a good idea should be fired.  •The puzzles in this game are not clever, they're just irritating. See the next section as to why.  •This game does something that modern horror movies do that really pisses me off. It establishes a set of rules, and then breaks those rules arbirarily in the name of shock value or an attempt at being 'creative'.  •I won't spoil the story, but if you're any kind of Batman fan, this story is one you've seen before and you that you've seen done better. Honestly I'm pretty insulted as a fan that they thought they could get away with this crappy storyline.  •Most of the villains are portrayed as cartoonish, two-dimensional cardboard cutouts of their comic counterparts. They try hamhandedly to interject depth and fall vastly short  •Game has a great soundtrack, shame we barely ever get to hear it. Too busy listening to the CONSTANT innane chatter of every thug. After a couple hours you've heard it all and it's just irritating.  •The way they wrote Batman in this game is really quite terrible. He makes every single wrong choice he could possibly make, and honestly it doesn't even feel like Batman. This is worth noting just because of how exceptionally terrible it is.  •The most interesting character in the game stops being present before you even hit the halfway mark.  •It wasn't until I got this far into the review that I realize what this game feels like. It's like playing a game version of the 3rd Nolan Batman.  •At least it runs perfectly now after the patch, right?  All in all you're much better off just replaying Arkham Asylum or City. Better yet, pick up a copy of Under the Red Hood, or just read some Batman comics. Rocksteady, you should be ashamed.

Just thought I'd write a review discussing the performance for now incase anybody's wondering how well it runs and are on the fence about picking it up. I have played a good bit of the story, but rest assured I will keep this review 100% spoiler free.  I notice there are many negative reviews, but so far my experiences have been positive for the most part, and thus I recommend picking it up.  (Update: a patch was applied that made the game worse and rendered it unplayable. Therefore, I no longer reccommend this game, purely because it runs terribly, although so far I love everything else about it). I intend to update this review as I play for the sake of informing those who are curious as to the quality of the game on PC. I play at 1080p, and my rig contains a GTX970 with a i-5 4670 CPU, and 16 GB of RAM.  First, let me just say I haven't had any overwhelming issues akin to Arkham City's DirectX11 troubles. The game runs surprisingly well and is very playable. It isn't quite as good a port as, for example, Shadow of Mordor, but it is pretty decent.  There aren't many graphics options to choose from. The settings to customise are; texture resolution (low, normal, or high), anti-ailising (literally an 'on' or 'off' option), level of detail (low, normal, or high), and shadow quality (low, normal, or high). Then there are also the additional NVIDIA physix options to play around with; Enhanced Rain, Enhanced Light Shafts, Interactive Paper Debris, and Interactive Smoke and Fog, all of which are 'on' or 'off' options--I keep all of them set to 'off' apart from the 'enhanced rain' option for the sake of a relatively steady frame-rate. When I lock the game to 30 fps, I can keep them all enabled and still get a steady frame-rate, but I prefer to have 60fps.   I haven't encountered much stuttering, many people seem to be complaining about this, but I just haven't encountered any, apart from occasional fps drops to 30. I've also had some issues with screen tearing even with in-game VSync enabled. However, I've found that enabling Adaptive VSync with the NVIDIA Control Panel and disabling it in game got rid of it.   I've began to notice some delayed fade-in with the textures. Normally fade-in doesn't bother me, but it takes quite a while for them to correct, and it has happened in cutscenes as well as gameplay. This is perhaps the worst of the issues I've encountered. I still haven't found a fix for this, but if I do, I will post it. Hopefully the good folks at WB (ha ha) are cooking up a patch right now.  A 350mb patch was released for this game, and it appears to have made it less stable. The fps dropped to an unplayable level. However, setting all of the graphics settings to normal and disabling the additional NVIDIA stuff has made the game run at a very playable 50-60fps, even in the Batmobile.  This port is a train-wreck. However, if you want it to run slightly better, be sure to unlock the game's ridiculous 30fps cap (SteamApps/common/Batman: Arkham Knight/BMGame/Config/BMSystemSettings)  Also, I would have applied for a refund with this, but it came free with my 970, sooo

I always figured a simple list was better, people are less likely to trudge through words and thus I will try to be as concise as possible.  Cons - I start with these first and break tradition so the Pros are left with you and honestly, I have little to say regarding cons.  - Batmobile prescence at times.   As context, I can see that outside the story the use of the batmobile may become stale and samey for the most part, so far I have only seen a couple of weapons at its arsenal and I expect side missions will be relating mostly to stopping enemy tanks, which will most definitely get dull. - Combat  I am not so sure I can express this con, it's not so much a personal thing, I enjoy the combat. However it is not hard by any means, you can easily dispatch a group of over 10 thugs who haven't got guns with no fear of dying.  I am sure there are more, I have however, not played for long and will edit upon completion.  Pros  - Batmobile  Yes, it's a pro as well. This feature will probably cause you to write a positive or negative review in the end once you get past the problem with frame rate. You cannot avoid using it, it's a fundamental part of Batman. What I like is it feels powerful. The sounds when you drive, the destruction of the enviroment, comments from thugs as you chase their vehicles or appear on the scene. It's truly a great addition in my humble opinion and although it has been used a lot, I don't mind, I enjoy it's use and feel a lot more like Batman when I can glind between missions, or arm myself with missles, wheel spin out of a tunnel and blow cannon holes in a few walls to get there. Needless to say I also enjoy the side missions with this vehicle requiring your skills as a driver.  - Story  I won't ruin anything. It's been a pleasure though, the script portrays realistic reactions to certain sitiuations you face and the voice acting is simply amazing.   - General comments I can't subtitle.  The atmosphere is great in this, it really feels like Gotham is in trouble, it feels like even away from the story elements, driving and helping a police vehicle is also affecting the enviroment. Hearing 'It's the Batman' as you blow up someones car is strangely satisfying. Another element I love is the detective side, it's really well done and I enjoy using the scanning elements, it just really feels like you're in control of Batman.  I'm one of those players that likes walking slowly up to a group of people, letting them attack me while slowly beating them up, calling my Batmobile to then crash into them, or a well timed batarang as they are about to hit me with a punch to knock them out, which draws me to combat. Simply put, you're Batman, thugs wouldn't stand a chance, so who cares if it's easy, it makes beating up large groups that much more satisfying to do.  I haven't commented on everything and as said previously, will add more in time. However if it seems like you can get over frame rate issues then by all means buy this game. In spite of reviews they are mostly aimed at performance, which you really shouldn't ignore, pointless buying if you can't play. However I haven't experienced this and thought I would just clarify that beyond that is a great experience.  Best of luck.

I know a lot of people are having problems with this game because of the PC port issues on launch day, but I am one of the VERY lucky few who has NO issues whatsoever.  My computer specs:  Alienware 17 Processor: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4710MQ CPU Speed: 2.5 GHz Number of Cores: 8 Video Card: AMD Radeon R9 M290X Total Memory: 4.0 GB Memory: 16 GB Operating System: Microsoft Windows 8.1, 64-bit Display Resolution: 1920 x 1080  This is the first Arkham game I've owned on PC (previously played them on PS3) and I am very happy to have made the leap from the console to PC for this game.  This game looks beautiful. I cannot emphasize that enough. I find myself getting lost in the beauty of this game around every corner, and the art direction for this title is right up there with Arkham Asylum (which still has my favourite art direction in any video game to date). This game is gorgeous. I have the resolution cranked up as high as it will (currently) allow for the PC, and the gameplay is extremely smooth. Yes, they capped the PC version at 30 fps, but it personally doesn't bother me at all. (And if that is an issue for you, there is a way to work around it).  I have had no issues with lag or the frame rate dropping in the slightest (including the Batmobile sections, and heavy combat). This is one of the best games that I own for my PC, and I'm so happy to have pre-ordered myself a copy for launch day!  The Harley Quinn pre-order exclusive was a lot of fun, but admittedly, VERY short (around 30 minutes to complete entirely.) She's been one of my favourite characters in the DC Universe for years now, and they really knocked her design out of the park in this game. Her fighting style is a blast play with, as it's so satisfying to crack a baddie upside the head with her bat!  This feels exactly like how I want an Arkham game to feel like. Batman controls seamlessly, glides effortlessly, and the new Batmobile mechanics are a really fun add on to the franchise! (I'm a big fan of racing games, so driving around in B-Man's mobile is fun as hell!) The combat is perfect, as to be expected from an Arkham title. There are also some neat new ways to takedown enemies that feel like they've always been a part of the franchise. Rocksteady really knows how to add onto the series without ruining any aspects of the franchise that people have come to love (and expect) from these titles.  I have played the original Batman: Arkham Asylum over 5 times now, and the respective sequels at least twice. This game is a most welcome addition to the franchise, and I look forward to completing it! Well worth the wait!!  Pros: - Georgeous art direction and design. This game is simply stunning to look at. - Engaging story telling, and dialogue. The voice acting is top-notch. - New gameplay mechanics (The Batmobile, new combat takedowns, etc.) - Smooth controls, and flawless combat -- as fun as ever! - Great soundtrack  Neutral: - Occasionally hard to follow directions/waypoints (but that could just be me)  Cons: - Terrible launch from Rocksteady. The game is broken for the majority of PC players, and they knowingly released it regardless. - There are several reports of players not reciving their Pre-Order bonus despite having pre-ordered the game. (In that same line, those who purchased specific graphics cards were given free copies of the game, only to have the pre-order bonuses taken away from them 1 hour before launch -- despite technically pre-owning the game)  [These cons may be edited out depending on how Rocksteady handles the complants. As of day 1, it's been a tough launch for this game]  For those having issues: have patience!! It's only day one, and yes it's terrible of Rocksteady to release a game with so many issues, but once they get it working properly for everyone, I hope that this game gets the proper credit it deserves!

Update:  After all the testing and tweaking, the Batmobile shows up and nukes everything. The game is unplayable with the Batmobile involved in processing. My Settings: Full Screen 1920x1600 v-sync: off AA: off (The in-game depth of field and motion blur soften the lines enough for me) Texture Res: normal (I have a 2GB gfx card. Can't go any higher) Shadow Detail: low (There was visually no decernable difference to me between low and normal, especially as I was beating the crap out of thugs) Level of Detail: high All nVidia Gameworks settings: On  I'm loving the story and atmosphere. Many surprises. Combat is as smooth and satisfying as it ever was. Once some new moves are mastered, even more satisfying! A forthcoming patch is inevitable and can only improve things.  Developer Improvements: -The texture streaming needs to be improved.  -Gfx card overclock settings need to be recogized. Currently they are ignored and the card runs at out of the box vanilla.

Review edit on January 1, 2016:  I repurchased AK after awaiting the patches and getting a new graphics card (Radeon R390). The game is really smooth now, so I can leave the complaints behind and focus on the content. I understand, though, that it's still a troublemaker for quite a few PC setups, so there's that still.  Anyways, I will make this fairly short. It's a polished title whose tried-and-true mechanics work like a charm. It's definitely worth playing, and there's lots to do, with crime scene investigations, Riddler shenanigans, tank battles, Predator sequences that have been seamlessly integrated into the games environment and thus feel less like set pieces... I recommend it, because it's fun.   Having said that, let me focus on what I didn't like. It's quite a lot, actually, and this will make it sound like it's a bad game. Let me reassure you, it's not. But it's a good game held back from being great by a bunch of design flaws.  1. The character models. WTF happened? They are all uglier than their previous counterparts. Yes, they're incredibly detailed, but... where should I start? Catwoman's pug nose? Batman's 'stomach ulcer' jowls? Poison Ivy's ragged heroin undernourished ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ look? I load up Arkham City and weep.   2. The car. Oh, the car. The developers gave it their all, and thus, it seems like Batman got a favourite toy that he just doesn't want to let go of. Don't get me wrong: it's well-implemented, although the driving itself takes some getting used to. The battles are tactical and fun, chase scenes are gripping, and it plays a part in some riddles, giving these a genuinely new dimension. But damn, it takes up so much playtime, that I was always glad to eject it and go flying over Gotham like I used to. In fact, I left the car behind whenever I could. Take note that it turns AK into a driving game (at least 40% of it).   3. Riddler riddles are getting old. And I just find it hard to believe that the Riddler would go to all these lengths AGAIN, never mind the plausibility of the first few games. But going after those question marks again... maybe I'll just leave Catwoman with him and call it a (k)night. Pure ennui.  4. There's too much of everything. Yes, open world games constantly try to better one another by having a tonful of content for you to 'enjoy'. More often than naught, this amounts to doing the same tedious things over and over and over. And then there's the decisions to be made that constantly undermine the game's believability. Oh yeah, Barbara is about to be murdered by a maniac, but let me calmly check out these victims instead. Not to mention collecting little question marks - these have to take precedent, sorry, Babs.   5. Rehashing old enemies instead of introducing some lesser known, but still interesting foes. Now, some really hated the Joker in this game, but I thought it was only fair, seeing as this is the conclusion of a trilogy that had the Joker take center stage for two games. But Firefly? Again? I never liked firefly, and writers have always struggled to make him interesting. Riddler? Penguin? Yawner.   6. The controls. Yes, a PC gamer's favourite gripe. But there are so many combos now, that it takes quite a while to master them. And even if you have (nothing against a learning curve if it makes sense), you'll still be hard put to unleash certain combos in the heat of battle (ALT-3? Really? Are you kidding??)  7. The ending. Well, yeah, of course the AK identity was clear to anyone who's followed the Dark Knight's adventures for the past 30 years, I didn't mind that at all. But... well, I won't give it away. Suffice to say that it was so out of character... I found it jolting.   So yeah, worth playing, but short of being great... by a mile. Arkham City remains my favourite.

In a nutshell: They really put every ounce into squeezing out every game mechanic they could think of that the previous games lacked. Some mechanics made the tedious Predator battles more tolerable as you didn't need over-spend time in every encounter. Sometimes it's nice to clear the room faster and get to your destination.  With every risk comes a gamble. Unfortunately, throwing your eggs in one basket is a risk that didn't quite pay off. Rocksteady really went all-out with the Bat tank. Very cool mechanic but grossly over-used as the game becomes a race track/tank battle arena.  What annoyed me the most was incorporating car SFX with Batman's punches. 'Yes, the Bat tank is cool' but not that cool.  As traditional with Arkham games were epic boss battles. You will get none of that In Arkham Knight. Not necessarily a bad thing if you can balance out Batman's encounters and detective work as well as a good story with fleshed out villains.  In short, not the best Arkham game, but definitely worth it.

Probably one of the best open world superhero games in existence. A great cinematic storyline that unfolds as you progress without keeping the player bound to a linear progression throughout the game itself. The addition of the Batmobile to the game is incredible in both performance and execution. This is the definitive Batman game so far.  If you are a fan of this series, I wouldn't pay heed to performance issues as it is playable on low spec machines. As long as you have a 2 GB 3D accelerated card (I'd recommend at least a Geforce GT 610 w/2GB) it should be playable without hiccups or stutters. I run it on an 8MB LGA775 based Quad core at 2.5 Ghz w/GT730 and it yields a pretty decent framerate at 1280x720.  Multiple skins for Batman, Robin, Catwoman and the Batmobile which can be used in Campaign mode. Once you've completed the main campaign, you can even play with all of the historic Batmobiles in the campaign world. So that means driving the Batmobile from the 1960s television series, the 1980s Batmobile, the Tumbler from the Dark Knight and even the Superman vs Batman Batmobile as well. That alone is an awesome feature let alone getting to choose which Batman you prefer for the campaign. If Rocksteady is indeed contracted to bring Superman (or Justice League) to an open world storyline, based upon my experiences with Arkham Knight, I'd bet that it would be awesome. If Marvel pays attention, they'll meet the open world gaming concept with an offering of their own with the Avengers or a key character like Iron Man or Captain America. They'll have a fair bit to live up when it comes to matching the great experience of playing Arkham Knight.  Great pacing and loads of content if you buy the version with all the DLCs included. Great replayibility even after you've finished the main campaign.  Highly recommended.

Apparently, all the complaints about framerate, bugs, and being a bad port have been fixed, because I just purchased it a week ago and have been playing quite a bit. I have to say it runs well, is extremely fun (right up there with Arkham City) and I have not found driving the batmobile to be at all tedious. Rather the opposite, I'm having a blast with the batmobile!   Granted, the game as a whole has Batman (and his car) being unbelievably violent for someone who is driven to never try to kill anyone (that criticism still stands), but one can (for the sake of a cool game and decent story) suspend one's disbelief and go with the sci-fi invented punches. There is even a story element to perhaps explain the Bat's escalating violence.   The worst part of the game for me remains the beginning (no spoilers) which is easily a hard R horror movie compared to the vast majority of the rest of the game (and I've played through about 70% of the main plot and finished several side plots). If you are shocked by the beginning, just hang in there. But be warned: if you don't like horror, you may find a few of the enemy characters to be well, well beyond the 'comic book violence' standard (especially due to a few torture scenes, both portrayed and heavily implied).

You better have a good rig to run this game, otherwise you're in for some serious lag and stuttering. Even on my mid-to-high range pc, I couldn't maintain sixty on high. But framerate is the least of your problems. The game will not stop crashing. I didn't have this problem when I was starting my save, but after I completed the main storyline and all of the DLC and Most Wanted save the Riddler, I was trying to get all of the trophies and the game continously crashes after ten minutes of play. Again, it was running reasonably well my first 25 hours, but then suddenly I complete the story and everything goes to hell. But that's ok. You're probably wondering why I am still recommending this game.  It's because, as a big fan of the Arkham series, this game is amazing. All of the criticism I heard when going in, about the Batmobile and how it was used too much, and how the story isn't good or whatever people are saying, it proved to be completely unfounded. I REALLY loved this game, and I had a ton of fun playing it. The formula hasn't changed since City, you are still the Batman, fighting arena-style combat against hordes of enemies. There are a couple new types, like the medic, the charging guys, and the big guys that aren't berzerkers but still can't be taken out with silent takedowns (they are pretty annoying). The game is well designed and looks really good, especially because everything takes place in a rainy Gotham at night. I thought the Batmobile was amazingly fun to play and to upgrade, and I felt that it wasn't overused at all. It's only really the side missions that see the Batmobile used a lot, and they were still fun.  There are several DLC missions that help to pad the length of kind-of a short campaign, and I feel that they were worth it to buy. That's why I got the season pass (on sale) and I think I got my money's worth. However, none of the missions were particularly memorable to me. I thought they were ok, but after getting to play them, I don't think I would bother getting them at full price. But if this game is on sale, and you're a fan of the Arkham games or just like Batman, then this game is a really good addition to the series and the franchise in general. If you can handle the performance, at least.

It is a part of the game that should have been entirely optional for crap like pictures of characters and costumes and other perks, but not a requirement.  2. The ending is just pure crap. I really shouldn't have been surprised by a company that actually kills Batman villians. I won't give spoilers for the endling, but it was a let down. I realize that Rocksteady and DC have presented this as a new story based upon the comics, but that statement that is even more crap. They use all of the actual comic book lore but decide to do something radical like kill a character or other moves that are clearly meant to drive sales and then chalk it up to that lame excuse.  3. If you are guilable enough to beleive all of the hype about the Arkham Knight being an all-new character, be ready for more disappointment. It is a rip-off of an existing Batman comic book character with a new name and outfit attempting to sell it as something new but pretty much reverts it all back to the comic book story as it plays out.  Other than those three points, the rest of the game play, characters, missions and story are amazing with pretty awesome graphics and sound. Just be ready for a game that takes you on an awesome ride only to end it with disappointment.

Batman: Arkham Knight, a game that manages to accomplish many feats, despite the hurdles it faced due to its (not so steady as a rock) launch.  As a rather well-seasoned reader of the Batman comic books and graphic novels, an experience such as this and the other games in the Arkham series is most welcome. Having been waiting for this game in particular for years, since the tremendously thrilling and rather daring ending to Arkham City, which is still one of my favourite games, as I continue to cherish its brilliance. After the long years of waiting for this epic conclusion, I can't for a second say that I was disappointed. The game itself - As a game, a playable experience, Batman: Arkham Knight takes the player, playing as Batman/Bruce Wayne himself on a journey mostly unlike every other adventure he's ever been on. The level design is incredible, pitting you against your foes in imaginative ways, still, the levels are usually as open as you'd like them to be. The city of Gotham has never been depicted in such a beautiful manner, with it constantly being reshaped to keep the game looking fresh as well as giving you other things to adjust to and different sights to behold. The combat that Rocksteady has become famous for, which has often been said to set the bar for combat systems in such third-person adventure games, continues to improve. It feels faster and more fluid than ever before and makes you feel invulnerable once you master the technique of beating Gotham's scum in every way one could imagine, whilst also punishing you, should you become overconfident and forget your basics. The Batmobile is drivable, as you should know if you've already made your way to this review. It is a welcomed addition, due to its genuine Batman feel and empowers the player with the power of what is essentially a high-speed tank. However, personally, the game seems to overuse the batmobile at some points in ways that don't quite seem believable even in the world of Bamtan, for instance: Riddler's race tracks replacing most of his logic puzzles.  The story - Personally, I believe this to be one of the best stories within a game that I've ever witnessed, with the twists and turns that keep it exciting, brutalising Bruce's memories to draw sympathy from the player, immersing them in the want to defeat the villains at hand. The story follows Batman as he tries to stop the Scarecrow from releasinga new, more potent and disastrous version of his infamous fear toxin. As he closes in on the scarecrow and his evil plans, the evil-doer's brand new henchman steps in, in all his mystique. Obviously with a vendetta against the Bat of Gotham, the mysterious new Arkham Knight maintains a sense of urgency throughout the game, as you attempt to uncover the terror that lies beneath his mask. This offers an interesting and exciting section to the main campaign,at times seeming strong enough to support its own subplot. Graphics - Depending on what device you play Batman: Arkham Knight, you can see huge differences in the level of detail some of these world-renowned developes have gone to. It was a true shame that the launch of the game was completely undermined on PC by the apparently appalling port from consoles.However, having played and completed the game on both the Xbox One and PC (post-patch), I can honestly say that it was worth the wait. The game's beauty hides in the darker details of the characters and the city itself. And if you get the final DLC 'Season of Infamy', the beard gracing Jervis Tetch's face forced my jaw down in awe. DLC - Sadly, this is the main gripe that I have with the game, although it doesn't spoil the game itself. The vast majority of the dowloadable content is utter tripe, if you really crave more of the side characters, such as Batgirl, Robin, Nightwing and so on, then the first few DLC packs are just for you. Hoever, they are around twenty minutes in length and are as shallow as that 17 year-old blonde girl in high school that everyone liked a little more than made sense. They offer no closure to the stories within the campaign itself and aren't satisfying in the slightest and feel more like a chore than an enjoyable extension of the game. However, the final downloadable content pack called 'Season of Infamy' is the complete opposite, as it offers closure to several characters, such as Mad Hatter, Killer Croc, Mr. Freeze and the tie-up I had really been waiting for since Arkham City: Ra's Al Ghul. Conclusion - In my opinion, as this entire review is, Batman: Arkham Knight is a gaming masterpiece, its story fulfills the perfect setting to highlight the experience that a developer such as Rocksteady can immerse a player in, providing a gratifying conclusion to the Arkham series. As a game and an overall experience, Arkham Knight delivers on every level. As this review was written a year and six days after its release, I feel like it is more of an attempt at thanking the hard-working developers at the Rocksteady. And so, thank you for reading, and if anyone at Rocksteady is reading, thank you so much for creating some of the most enjoyable content to me. If you genuinely wanted a review to see if it's worth buying, I'd say so, whether or not you're a big fan of the Dark Knight. By now, it's pretty cheap , and if you want more, definitely invest in the 'Season of Infamy' as it was a satisfying closure to the masterfully created series, Thanks.
