My second favorite Arkham game, right after the original Asylum. I had a few performance issues which were probably caused by me running the game with all settings on max on an ancient computer into which I shoved a newer graphics card, and save for one or two crashes, I encountered nothing severe. The graphics are gorgeous, the core gameplay is more of the same old good fun, and the Batmobile sections are a very good break from that which alleviates the slight repetitiveness of the previous Arkham games. Also, having both the Batmobile and the grappling hook boost available means traversing a larger world is not a problem. The story is a bit bland, true, but the gameplay and the feel of the world makes up for it, and the sheer amount of side missions and riddles provides plenty of good fun.

I managed to finally get into this game after waiting a substantial length of time for a patch to fix PC issues as well as get a decent rig to start playing the higher up pc games in my library. While I haven't logged any hours on my profile, I played through on my relative's with 120% completion rate and unlocked all the endings. Batman Arkham Knight is a great game, when you peel back some of the annoying layers covering it; from the horrid PC release to the seemingly rushed release, this game is still comparable to the first two games (I don't believe Arkham Origins really counts) and is a great conclusion to the Arkham series. First, the good. The story; definitely, especially after having seen the animated series throughout and seeing how it came through to this end. The ending may confuse some people, but I think it was well done and quite satisfying. Moreover; the emotional beats this game hit compared to the others is worthy of praise. I was feeling very tense and emotional at key points during the story; the music definitely adds to this and is appreciated.  The cast of characters; with the Season of Infamy DLC, many villain arcs have come to a close and the quests were fun to play. The quest for Mr Freeze was especially heartwarming and one of my favourite sidequests. The other sidequests were... not so well done, but I'll get to that later. The combat and predator encounters are improved upon further. Throw counters and more special moves added to Batman's arsenal and actually become very useful; especially fear takedowns, which you'll need to use against the improved mooks. They actually go to every length possible to beat you with new tactics including vantage point mining, sentry guns, scanning drones, better awareness of grates, and buddying up with each other. This makes the predator encounters more dynamic and challenging without being too frustrating, given the wider options Batman has as well. Voice acting; as great as ever. And Mark Hamill's addition was great and appreciated. The visuals were definitely the best yet, but unfortunately require a decent computer to handle. Still, seeing Gotham in all its glory was breathtaking as you'll fly to the tops of huge towers and drive through vast plazas and streets; fully realising a big city like Gotham as the environment. Now for the bad parts. Unfortunately, the tracking of sidequests was handled poorly, as most are more often than not fetch quests for extra objectives that span throughout the entire game. These become an annoyance because you can't always complete a quest the first time you receive it; most just end up piling up and getting annoying as I want to finish them off early, but you almost never can. Finding these objectives can be equally frustrating as only solving Riddler challenges lets you get map trackers on them.  Speaking of; Riddler challenges were not enjoyable here. Despite having less challenges than Arkham City; each one was overall more annoying than challenging as often switches you step on give you no feedback on what has changed; leaving you running around more than you should to find what you're supposed to be doing. The riddles were worse. In the open city, it only gives you the general area of a revealed riddle. Now this is a problem as there are so many things of interest to look at (which would otherwise be a good thing) to be annoying distractions as you often have little idea of what you're looking for. It could be a small poster in a whole city block; or a distant object that might have nothing to do with the riddle you're solving. This could have been alleviated by giving the exact location of the riddle in the open city like it was in Arkham City. The Batmobile was kind of a mixed bag. At first, and especially throughout with car chases, using the Batmobile was refreshing and was always fun when chasing down mooks and APCs with tracking shots. However the tank battles got quite repetitive towards the end; not challenging enough or dynamic enough to keep my full attention for the whole thing. The more insulting thing about the Batmobile is that the majority of any boss battles are for the Batmobile. Disappointing, to say the least. Still, I enjoyed Arkham Knight very much and it's clear now how much work was put into this game. Rocksteady still did a great job and I'm surprised by how hard many reviewers are being. Probably to do with the shoddy release, but this is a great conclusion and worth getting once you can get past the release problems and somewhat frustrating riddler crap (I had to resort to looking things up online). Thank you, Rocksteady.

Batman Arkham Knight is the final game in the Arkham trilogy. It has a new large map with upgraded graphics and the batmobile.   The Plot  I will be talking about events which happened in previous Arkham Games so im going to write this in a way thats assuming you've played them. The main story is probably the best out of the Arkham games. It is no longer set in mainland Gotham but on the islands on the edge of Gotham. Scarecrow is the main villian and he just threatened the entire population of Gotham with his fear toxin. Everyone is evacuated and coincedentally, the story is set on Hallowe'en. The only people left behind are those who enjoy violence and terror. Scarecrow has hired a whole Militia run by an engima known as 'The Arkham Knight'. Very liitle is known about him and he has a very strong grudge against Batman. There are also other people who are interested in taking down the Bat. This includes Two-Face, Penguin, Riddler and more. Playing as Batman(Obviously) you must takedown Scarecrow and the Knight. In Arkham City, when Joker dies, Batman becomes guilt ridden and believes he is responsible for his death. Joker always said that Batman was his equal, that he had the mind of a killer like him, that they are both the way they are becuase of 'Them'. This is Batman biggest fear: Turning into Joker. Due to this, Joker hops into dialogue frequently, talking to Bruce. This is a great feature, I was worried there wasn't going to be anymore Mark Hamill. It has alot of side missions with alot of available DLCs. However, in order to unlock the games full ending you must complete EVERY sidemission which means you have to complete EVERY RIddler challenge. After over 100hrs, i still have not gotten everything as it is too long and boring. In Arkham City I actually enjoyed collecting the Trophies because the tasks were actually interesting.  Gameplay The gameplay is great, as you can tell by my playtime. It keeps the same freeflow combat as before and the AI(Enemies) has been improved. The counters are no longer delayed and the combat flows so much better. There are new combo takedowns and new enemies. These enemies include medics who can revive neutralized opponents, and Martial Artisits who have very complex move patterns. The biggest upgrade is the Batmobile. You're going to end up having a love/hate relationship with the Batmobile. Let me first explain what it does. It has a 60mm cannon and a machine gun. It also has a missile barrage, an emp shock and a virus to stop drones. The new UI includes new WayneTech upgardes for the batmobile which will enhance it in combat. The batmobile is very entertaing at the start of the game but then it gets overused. The game forces you to use it and it becomes a very tedious chore.   Performance At its launch.... Im sure you know about those days. But now most bugs have been patched and the game runs perfectly. It really eats away at your RAM so I suggest using a memory cleaner if you have below 8GB RAM. The graphics are really good, no jagged edges or bad lighting and smooth animations, so... You're going to need a good GPU. I'd say 2GB minimum which will only support lowest settings. 4GB for 30-50fps on High settings and for optimal performance use a 6GB GPU which will get you 90 fps or even 120(You can change the Max Fps in Bmsetting.ini file. The directory is ProgramfilesX86/Steam/steamapps/common/BatmanArkhamKnight/Bmgame/) You're also going to need a good CPU, Id say and Intel core i5 2500 3.3Ghz or an AMD equivalent. Match this criteria and you're good to go.  Overall  It has a great dark story, unique combat and beautiful visuals. A great way to finish the Arkham series which has a bitter-sweet ending. Get it on sale and savour every moment of gameplay. I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a great story or a Die-Hard Batman fan.

After avoiding this game like the plague because of bad reviews for the PC version I caught it on sale. I went ahead and bought it. And the season pass. It's late, it means I get it all. I haven't been dissapointed by it. And also that it has had time to be updated. I'm an early adopter of lot's of things, games are usually not on that list. It has the same feel as the other games in this run. The art is good, the gameplay is what you'd expect out of a somewhat sandbox game. If you are the type of person who wants completion... it's that kind of game. The story runs flat in a few spots, but so did the other games in some degree or another.   On the art and graphics I give it an 8.5 out of 10. It's dark and the rain looks good. I just recently got my hands on a new i5 mid-to-upper processor and GTX 970. I get to run it full on at 1080 and it looks good at 60-75fps. The usual wear and tear on the character model through the game is there and unique to this game. The new suit is nice. The design of the batmobile is rugged and tough feeling. Hands down the DLC for the Mad Hatter is the best art style I've seen in a while... and after just 14 hours and around 37% completion... yeah, it's pretty.  On the gameplay I give it 9 out of 10. It has the same feel as the other large scale Batman games in the run. There are things to do but the random 'I'm gonna go fight a group of people at random' feels diminished because of the batmobile's toughness. There are though plenty of good fights in the main gameplay and the big ol' VR missions section if that's what ya want. The DLC adds a bit of extras but it's not a whole lot. Just enough to round out the game, but I'm not even at 40 percent yet. The riddler challenges are definitely hit or miss as always. They do make you think about it, and much like the others those reflexes and repitition are gonna be there. The batmobile in general has changed the landscape of this game series. The 'tank mode' makes it feel much better in terms of control for a vehicle but it can be a bit off-putting in the beginning. Even after 14 hours I still hit the left trigger for the brake instead of the x button in 'pursuit mode'. I am learning game design and programming and I honestly couldn't suggest a better control scheme, so it's just one of those things. A few new surprises in the gadgets.   On the tech side I give it a 6 out of 10. Sorry the early adopters suffered, and even I ran into some issues this late on. It would crash before launch. And I do mean I got a splash screen and then a crash. No fix the resolution pre-game menus... just a crash. I think mine was the DX installers or something that I usually see before every new Steam install that were missing. Luckily I fix PC's for side cash and managed to get it fixed in under 20 minutes after 3 out of 4 methods. For the non-technical PC gamers I'm sure this is still a problem. Search the Steam forums for a couple of good tips if it happens to you. This is the exact reason I waited to purchase this game. (as in you didn't get good mark up on the sell because I will not pay full price for buggy software). PC hardware is getting pretty standard and these are near unforgivable issues. I expected better after this long. A lot of new games suffer nowadays at launch and it's not acceptable. Once it was up and running though... not a crash to be seen except while attempting to allow background downloads while playing. Framerate suffered horribly for my next game greed while wanting to play some Batman.  In summary, it's like the others. Fans of this series will likely be pleased by the 'back to it' feel of Arkham Knight if the game runs 'out of the box', and will enjoy it as much if not more than other games. If you have the hardware to run it full tilt it will look good if not a bit 'shiny' due to the shaders. But most modern games have that. It's a button mashing good time in fights and there are things to do and it still breaks patterns now and then. If you just want a story it may let you down (I like it), but if you want that 100% it will make you try for it and you will get your dollars worth... race what is basically a tank through a shifting maze under a timer and you will have to try at it more than once but not 20 times and most times not more than 5 times on some of the harder puzzles. I'll admit that I'm impressed by a good bit of this game and the difficulty feels about right so far. The amount of dialogue and random pop up remakrs make this game better overall if you take the time to explore and press A alot. I don't regret waiting for it but would have been let down if I bought this early with all the fixings and had to deal with the tech issues more than I did.

This is goingto be more of a review of the series than the game.  I love this game series and I love this game. It's not my favourite (Asylum stil holds that due to atmosphere) and it's not my least favourite (City broke flow way too often). People didn't like the inclusion of the batmobile, but for me it felt like a logical progression. Asylum was all about atmosphere and sneaky stealth. City took what was great and built and adapted it, adding many new things, but for me felt devoid of heading, other than the ending to create Knight. Origins is the black sheep but my second favourite, mixing elements of Asylum and City and felt like what City should have been. Knight again took what was before and expanded on it, making it feel so different. gone was the sneaky stealth and instead we have fast action and brutal beatdowns, batman almost falling off the cliff to go darkside (or should that be Darkseid >.<).  Preordered it, played it from day 1, didn't return/refund it because...I had no problems. The only thing I can think of as to why i had zero problems is because i have 32gb of RAM (don't ask). As a standalone game it is still great, but becomes so much more when you look at the previous games, not just what happened in the story, but how it was acheived and the evolution of the series by rocksteady.

Since there is only so many times you can redo the same game I really hope Rocksteady expands into other DC heroes. I would love to play a game like this focused on Green Arrow, The Flash, or Martian Manhunter.

EDIT:  For a $60 AAA title, I could not recommend this game, but if you've got the teraflops and the time, it's a steal for $10. Definitely $10 worth of value if you have at least a 6th gen i5 or i7 and a 2 GB graphics card. I still stand by it being subpar.  GAMEPLAY: I think it's fair to say this game is bothersome. Talking from a PC gamer standpoint, the operability is disappointing. True, you *can* run it, and I didn't really complain with my ability to do so, but for the average gamer, I cannot recommend you buy it. There's a lot of intuitive bugs here. However, the fighting mechanics are in their prime here. I think I had the most fun in the challenge room. But there's only a handful of maps, so that was a bummer. The car was more annoying, by 3 hours in, than cool. SPOILER:    I actually was relieved when they blow up the car, but then it comes back...    So on gameplay, it gets a big 'meh' which is not really enough to recommend a purchase.  STORY: Horse crap. I'm not gonna lie, I really did not like the story. Lots of moving parts and no real enjoyable substance. It was more frustrating than interesting. You know in Arkham City when    Ra's al-Ghul is destroying the city with the Tyger helicoptors?    Yeah, there's nothing emotionally comparable to that here. Lots of homages to Batman comics, movies, and the game series, as well as several    BLATANTLY STOLEN COMIC BOOK PLOTS    but overall, it still gets a 'no' from me. The only wonderful moment was the return of the sweet serenading of Mark Hamill. That was really the only positive to my three-night binge of Batman. Maybe I was just so shocked with the idiocy of the story that I thought less of it, so I might give it another go later on, but I would definitely say it is sub-par when comparing it to its older brothers.  CONCLUSION: Arkham Knight? No. If you're a completist, I guess? But you probably would have this game anyway. If you're starting new, stick to Arkham Asylum, City, or if you need better graphics, Origins. All are solid games and have merits in their own respect. The only reason you might *like* this game is if you genuinely enjoy the source material (not my favourite stories, frankly), and you want to be the most intensely violent Batman ever presented (including Batman v Superman). I bought it on sale and would in no way recommend buying it for any less. In the end, yeah, I guess I was entertained. I never thought I would say it, but Arkham Origins looks REALLY good right now.

Arkham Knight really does achieve something when it comes to being incredibly cinematic and really breath some morbid life into the streets of Gotham. In spite of a ludicrous amount of riddler trophies strewn in almost every possible spot some insane developer thought would make a great challenge, this game otherwise performs wonderfully. Though it almost over performs. Between being able to take control of the batmobile, take down some rather obscure villains, tons of gadgets at your disposal and plenty of other activities aside from the already somewhat lengthy story main story and side stories availaible with the dlc... You see where I'm going with this? This game is great but it's a run on sentence. It wants to do so much but doesn't quite settle in everything it wants to do.  On the techinical side, I've heard this game was performing like a wet lump of rice on asphault in the middle of a busy highway. But it's been patched and such and for me, it performed like a charm. Being able to almost pump all the graphics settings in the game, save for anti-aliasing and the highest possible texturing, this game looks beautiful. It's worth mentioning because of how good Arkham Knight looks. From it's opening scene do the developers showcase their abilities. As for combat, it plays very much like it's previous titles but finely polished. Even with the over abundance of gadgets it manages to find a smooth but tight place in every gamers buttocks without being painful to sit on.  The batmobile feels worked into the game on it's own right, some missions strictly requiring the batmobile are numerous, but never feel like their just showing it down your pie hole, screaming about how they put a vehicle in a Batman game. But it has it's uses and many of which feel organic to the game, discounting riddler trophies which are a pain like no other.  Pros: -Eye candy -Overall polished game mechanics over previous titles -Plenty to do with a variety of interesting side missions -Batmobile is implemented well -Good sized map  Cons: -Riddler trophies are ridiculous -Game doesn't feel suited for mouse & keyboard, you may want a controller -The Riddler -The Riddler -The Riddler -Vehicle/tank combat feels janky -Game never feels like it knows what it wants to do -Un-necessary amounts of collectables  I really and truly enjoyed this game and for the price, it's an okay purchase if your computer can handle it, as there were a few scenes here and there that really played with the frames, but few enough to not be an issue. I did have a few crash to desktops with no error message which I found was gpu overheating on this game. I set my fan curve to cool at a lower temp and zero ctds after ten hours. I bought the game with strong apprehension since the PC version of Arkham Knight has garnered a very bad rep at launch due to very poor optimization and bugs. Only when the game and the season pass were offered at 75% discount that I decided to finally get into the fray. . . and it has been a wonderful ride. While my 2GB GPU can only run the game on low textures, the game looks beautiful nonetheless.  I set the maximum fps to 30 to avoid heating my GPU too much for prolonged period of time while playing the game and I've found no reason to dislike the 30 fps cap that if you like, can be set to 60 fps. The game feels very fluid at 30 fps without any noticable drop in framerate even while playing the Batmobile.  The Arkham City looks stunning although still devoid of citizens due to a general evacuation as the story is told.  I don't hate the Batmobile play much although I could see issue arising from too many repititive tank battles in the Batmobile. Great game, love the combat and storytelling. The environment is open world, and it's about five times the size of the map in Arkham City. Didn't have most of the technical issues I'd read about that had put me off buying the game until recently. Game is lengthy and full of content - I haven't had a look at any DLC yet. Killing the Thugs I get a feeling that this departs from the original story where Batman never kills. I think I've run over and shot multiple thugs.
